role_name: Aerobic C4-dicarboxylate transporter for fumarate, L-malate, D-malate, succunate
Biotin carboxyl carrier protein of oxaloacetate decarboxylase
Membrane protein associated with oxaloacetate decarboxylase
notes:
Notes on reaction reversibility:

All the reactions catalyzed by enzymes of this node are annotated as reversible in KEGG, which is not really the case under physiological conditions.   Pyruvate carboxyl transferase (EC 6.4.1.1) and Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxylase (EC 4.1.1.31) operate strictly in the direction of C3-carboxylation.  Oxaloacetate decarboxylase (EC 4.1.1.3) is a strictly C4-decarboxylating enzyme.   The following enzymes catalyze reversible reactions, but their primary function in vivo is C4-decarboxylation:  Malic enzyme, Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase.   Pyruvate kinase is a glycolytic, while Pyruvate,phosphate dikinase and Phosphoenolpyruvate synthase function in the gluconeogenesis. 

Malic enzyme (ME, ME-P):

It is impossible to distinguish between the three variants of malic enzyme based on the protein sequence alone.  Substrate specificity (NADP vs NAD) is well established only in the following phyla, where experimental measurements have been performed for at least one representative:  E. coli and other enteric bacteria, B. subtilis, Rhizobium sp., Pseudomonas sp., Alcaligines faecalis, and Agrobacterium tumefaciens, Cyanobacterias, some Archaea.  Lactic acid bacteria (with a few exceptions) possess Malolactic enzyme (EC 1.-.-.-), which converts malate directly to lactate, instead of malic enzyme.  In other species substrate specificity listed here can be incorrect. 

Oxaloacetate decarboxylases (ODC)  fall into four classes: 

1. The 3-4 subunit membrane-bound Na+-translocating ODC [e.g. of Klebsiella sp. (Dimroth 1986)];  
2. The divalent-cation-dependent cytoplasmic ODC [e.g. of C.glutamicum (Jetten et al., 1995)].  As of August 2006, no protein sequence has been associate with this enzyme.
3.  An unusual ODC that belongs to malic enzyme family, and is specifically involved in citrate fermentation [e.g. E. faecalis (Sender et al., 2003)], with the corresponding genes clustering with citrate metabolic genes
4.  The ODC activity of a diverse group of enzymes like pyruvate  kinase, malic enzyme, malate dehydrogenase, pyruvate carboxylase and PEP carboxykinase (Creighton  & Rose 1976; Ivanichev & Kurganov 1993)

Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxylase (PEPC):

A novel type of PEP carboxylase has been recently discovered in Archaea (Patel et al., 2004).  It has no discernable evolutionary relationship with previously described PEPCs.  Its homologs are present in most archaeal genomes, but only in three bacterial (Clostridium perfringens, Oenococcus oeni, and Leuconostoc mesenteroides) and in no eukaryotic genomes.  Each PEPCa-containing organism lacks a �classic� PEPC homolog (Patel et al., 2004). 


References

Many. But we would like to acknowledge especially an excellent review by U.Sauer and B.Eikmanns (FEMS Microbiol. Rev., 2005)

notes:
SEE

J Bacteriol. 2002 Jul;184(13):3640-8.Click here to read Click here to read Links
    Activation of prophage eib genes for immunoglobulin-binding proteins by genes from the IbrAB genetic island of Escherichia coli ECOR-9.
    Sandt CH, Hopper JE, Hill CW.

    Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Pennsylvania State College of Medicine, Hershey, Pennsylvania 17033, USA. csandt@psu.edu

    Four distinct Escherichia coli immunoglobulin-binding (eib) genes, each of which encodes a surface-exposed protein that binds immunoglobulins in a nonimmune manner, are carried by separate prophages in E. coli reference (ECOR) strain ECOR-9. Each eib gene was transferred to test E. coli strains, both in the form of multicopy recombinant plasmids and as lysogenized prophage. The derived lysogens express little or no Eib protein, in sharp contrast to the parental lysogen, suggesting that ECOR-9 has an expression-enhancing activity that the derived lysogens lack. Supporting this hypothesis, we cloned from ECOR-9 overlapping genes, ibrA and ibrB (designation is derived from "immunoglobulin-binding regulator"), which together activated eib expression in the derived lysogens. The proteins encoded by ibrA and ibrB are very similar to uncharacterized proteins encoded by genes of Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi and E. coli O157:H7 (in a prophage-like element of the Sakai strain and in two O islands of strain EDL933). The genomic segment containing ibrA and ibrB has been designated the IbrAB island. It contains regions of homology to the Shiga toxin-converting prophage, Stx2, as well as genes homologous to phage antirepressor genes. The left boundary between the IbrAB island and the chromosomal framework is located near min 35.8 of the E. coli K-12 genome. Homology to IbrAB was found in certain other ECOR strains, including the other five eib-positive strains and most strains of the phylogenetic group B2. Sequencing of a 1.1-kb portion of ibrAB revealed that the other eib-positive strains diverge by </=0.1% from ECOR-9, whereas eib-negative ECOR-47 diverges by 16%.

    PMID: 12057959

docs.description:
Under iron-limiting growth conditions Pseudomonas  aeruginosa produces two major siderophores: hydroxamate siderophore pyoverdin (Meyer & Abdallah, 1978; Cox & Adams, 1985) and catechol siderophore pyochelin (Cox, 1980; Rinehart et al., 1995).  Of the two pyoverdin has a greater  affinity for Fe(II1) than has pyochelin (Cox & Graham,  1979).  It is encoded in a separate SS: "Pyoverdine biosynthesis new"

Pyochelin is derived from one molecule of salicylate and two molecules of cysteine.  The enzymes for the synthesis (PchBA) and activation (PchD) of salicylate as well as a putative thioesterase (PchC) are encoded by pchDCBA operon.  This operon also includes two coregulated genes, pchEF, encoding peptide synthetases.  The pchE is required for the conversion of salicylate to dihydroaeruginoate (Dha), the condensation product of salicylate and one cysteine residue, and pchF is essential for the synthesis of pyochelin from Dha (Reimmann et al., 1998). The deduced PchE (156 kDa) and PchF (197 kDa) proteins have adenylation, thiolation and condensation/cyclization motifs arranged as modules which are typical of non-ribosomal peptide synthetases forming thiazoline rings.

When secreted to the extracellular environment, pyochelin chelates iron and transports it to the bacterial cytoplasm via specific outer-membrane receptor FptA and the inner-membrane permease FptX.  Exogenously added pyochelin also acts as a signal which induces the expression of the pyochelin biosynthesis and uptake genes by activating PchR, a cytoplasmic regulatory protein of the AraC/XylS family.

In addition to P. aeruginosa, pyochelin production was documented in Burkholderia sp. (Darling et al., 1998; Visser  et al., 2004), and pyochelin biosynthetic genes are highly conserved in the sequenced genomes of multiple Burkholderia species.  Notably, the presence of an operon similar to fptABCX in Rhodospirillum rubrum indicates that it might be able to utilize pyochelin as a heterologous siderophore for iron uptake (Michel et al., 2007)

Another interesting insight into such siderophore piracy was provided recently by discovery of enantio-pyochelin, an optical antipode of pyochelin, which is produced by Pseudomonas fluorescens strains Pf-5 and CHA0 produce (Youard et al., 2007).  The two different pyochelin enantiomers (produced by P. fluorescens CHA0 and P. aeruginosa PAO1) cannot be utilized as an iron source in the heterologous background. This strategy is believed to prevent potential competitors occupying the same ecological niche from stealing heterologous iron-siderophore complexes (Youard et al., 2007)

docs.description: This Subsystem has been encoded for the review "Evolution of Proline biosynthesis: Enzymology, bioinformatics, genetics and transcriptional regulation" (Journal ??). You are now in the Subsystem viewer of the SEED database. The narrow green banner above provides links to genome analysis tools and data. Please use them to see - I. The �Spreadsheet� Tab contains a Table where each row represents a genome, each column corresponds to a Functional Role (FR), and each cell is populated with the gene(s)/protein(s) that implement this Functional Role in each organism. Each gene/protein is identified with a blue number � the Protein-Encoding Gene (PEG) ID - which is linked to an underlying detailed PEG page. Multiple, serially numbered gene IDs may appear in the same cell in eukaryotic genomes. These correspond to multiple gene models called for the same locus. This complexity reflects the uncertainty attending gene prediction in Eukaryotes, and is expected to diminish with time. 'Variant codes' in the SEED database capture most common variations in a 'lay-out' of a pathway (e.g. proline biosynthesis in this SS) that might occur in different taxa. A specific variant code is associated with every genome in the Spreadsheet; hovering over it brings up its brief explanation (also given below in the "Variants" section) II. The �Functional Roles� Tab above contains the list of protein families included in this Subsystem, and explains abbreviations used in the heading of the Subsystem Spreadsheet. Follow blue links on the left ("show FR") to web pages with detailed descriptions of each Functional Role (protein family) III. Further help in navigating the SEED database is available here - SEED_Viewer_Tutorial Glossary

role_name: Uncharacterized cyanobacterial protein, sll0461 homolog, ProA-like, but lacks essential Cysteine residue at catalytic site
notes: Proline is not only an essential component of proteins but it also has important roles in adaptation to osmotic and dehydration stresses, redox control, and apoptosis. Here we review pathways of proline biosynthesis in the three biological domains. Pathway reconstruction from genome data for hundreds of eubacterial and dozens of archaeal and eukaryotic organisms in this Subsystem revealed evolutionary conservation and variations of this pathway across different taxa. In the most prevalent pathway of proline synthesis, glutamate is phosphorylated to gamma-glutamyl phosphate by gamma-glutamyl kinase, reduced to gamma-glutamyl semialdehyde by gamma-glutamyl phosphate reductase, cyclizes spontaneously to delta-1-pyrroline-5-carboxylate and reduced to proline by delta-1-pyrroline-5-carboxylate reductase. In higher plants and animals the first two steps are catalyzed by a bi-functional delta-1-pyrroline-5-carboxylate synthase. Alternate pathways of proline formation use the initial steps of the arginine biosynthetic pathway to ornithine, which can be converted to delta-1-pyrroline-5-carboxylate by ornithine aminotransferease and then reduced to proline or directly to proline by ornithine cyclodeaminase; in some organisms, the latter pathways contribute to or could be fully responsible for the synthesis of proline (Fichman et al., 2013)

docs.description:
Sarcosine oxidase (EC 1.5.3.1) catalyzes the oxidative demethylation of sarcosine to produce formaldehyde, glycine and hydrogen peroxide.  This enzyme, together with the other enzymes such 
as creatininase and creatinase, have been used in clinics for determination of creatinine, which is an important parameter to estimate the function of kidney (Bacon and Pardue, 1991).

Enzymatic activity has been demonstrated in bacteria (Kim et al. 1987; Matsuda et al. 1987; Mori et al. 1980; Nishiya and Imanaka 1993; Ogushi et al. 1988; Suzuki 1981), mammals (Chikayama et al. 2000; Reuber et al. 1997), and plant (Goyert et al. 2004). The enzyme has been isolated from various sources and three types in its organization have been reported, i.e., monomer, heterodimer and heterotetramer. 

Heterotetrameric SOX consists of four non-identical subunits and contains both covalently and non-covalently bound flavins. The enzyme was first purified from Corynebacterium sp. U-96, then from various sources, such as Corynebacterium sp.P-1, Arthrobacter ureafaciens, and Arthrobacter sp.1-IN.

Monomeric form has ben characterized in Bacillus sp. NS-129 (Kayama et al. 1991), and Bacillus sp. B-0618 (Suzuki et al. 1994), and the corresponding genes have been cloned and expressed.
notes:
References

1. Guo K, Ma X, Sun G, Zhao Y, Li X, Zhao W, Kai L. Expression and characterization of a thermostable sarcosine oxidase (SOX) from Bacillus sp. in Escherichia coli. Appl Microbiol Biotechnol. 2006 Dec;73(3):559-66. Epub 2006 Sep 15.

2. Suzuki H, Tamamura R, Yajima S, Kanno M, Suguro M. Corynebacterium sp. U-96 contains a cluster of genes of enzymes for the catabolism of sarcosine to pyruvate. Biosci Biotechnol Biochem. 2005 May;69(5):952-6.

3. Goyert A, Johnson TL, Olsen LJ, Collakova E, Hill YS, Rhodes D, Hanson AD (2004) Characterization and metabolic function of a peroxisomal sarcosine and pipecolate oxidase from Arabidopsis. J Biol Chem 279:16947�16953

docs.description:
The missing piece of the type II fatty acid synthase system from Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Only Mycobacteria contain hadC ortholog, but the hadA and hadB genes are conserved among other mycolate-producing genera, Rhodococcus and Nocardia (PMID:17804795). Consistently, both genes either overlap or fuse in a long unique gene, suggesting that their cotranscription and the association of their products are crucial for the physiology of the Corynebacterineae" (PMID:17804795)

HadAB gene cluster happens to be located next to LSU ribosomal protein L33p.  Albeit functionally unrelated, this Role was included in this SS (as an auxiliary member), because it helps with recognition and annotation of hadA and hadB orthologs
docs.subsystem_name: Mycobacterial HadABC proteins ((3R)-hydroxyacyl-ACP dehydrates of FASII)
notes:
Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2007 Sep 11;104(37):14628-33. Epub 2007 Sep 5.
The missing piece of the type II fatty acid synthase system from Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
Sacco E, Covarrubias AS, O'Hare HM, Carroll P, Eynard N, Jones TA, Parish T, Daff� M, B�ckbro K, Qu�mard A.
Abstract
The Mycobacterium tuberculosis fatty acid synthase type II (FAS-II) system has the unique property of producing unusually long-chain fatty acids involved in the biosynthesis of mycolic acids, key molecules of the tubercle bacillus. The enzyme(s) responsible for dehydration of (3R)-hydroxyacyl-ACP during the elongation cycles of the mycobacterial FAS-II remained unknown. This step is classically catalyzed by FabZ- and FabA-type enzymes in bacteria, but no such proteins are present in mycobacteria. Bioinformatic analyses and an essentiality study allowed the identification of a candidate protein cluster, Rv0635-Rv0636-Rv0637. Its expression in recombinant Escherichia coli strains leads to the formation of two heterodimers, Rv0635-Rv0636 (HadAB) and Rv0636-Rv0637 (HadBC), which also occurs in Mycobacterium smegmatis, as shown by split-Trp assays. Both heterodimers exhibit the enzymatic properties expected for mycobacterial FAS-II dehydratases: a marked specificity for both long-chain (longer or equal C-12) and ACP-linked substrates. Furthermore, they function as 3-hydroxyacyl dehydratases when coupled with MabA and InhA enzymes from the M. tuberculosis FAS-II system. HadAB and HadBC are the long-sought (3R)-hydroxyacyl-ACP dehydratases. The correlation between the substrate specificities of these enzymes, the organization of the orthologous gene cluster in different Corynebacterineae, and the structure of their mycolic acids suggests distinct roles for both heterodimers during the elongation process. This work describes bacterial monofunctional (3R)-hydroxyacyl-ACP dehydratases belonging to the hydratase 2 family. Their original structure and the fact that they are essential for M. tuberculosis survival make these enzymes very good candidates for the development of antimycobacterial drugs.

PMID:17804795

CytR is a global transcription regulator of pyrimidine nucleotide metabolism in many gamma Proteobacteria.  It functions in association with Cyclic AMP receptor protein (Crp).  Usually viewed as a repressor, it can also be an activator.

For example, see:

Rasmussen, P. B., Holst, B., and Valentin-Hansen, P.  1996.  Dual-function regulators: the cAMP receptor protein and the CytR regulator can act either to repress or to activate transcription depending on the context.  Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 93:10151-10155.

KEGG and UniProt call this protein "regulator for deo operon, udp, cdd, tsx, nupC, and nupG".

CytR is similar to many transcriptonal regulators, and the circumscription is uncertain.

notes: P-II indirectly controls the transcription of the glutamine synthetase gene (glnA). P-II prevents NR-II-catalyzed conversion of NR-I to NR-I-phosphate, the transcriptional activator of GlnA. When P-II is uridylylated to P-II-UMP, these events are reversed. When the ratio of Gln to 2-ketoglutarate decreases, P-II is uridylylated to P-II-UMP, which causes the deadenylation of glutamine synthetase by GlnE, so activating the enzyme.

Five contiguous open reading frames encoding proteins for vibrioferrin biosynthesis, transcribed in an opposite direction relative an operon of six ORFs enconding functions for the transport of the ferric complex into the cytosol.
Regulated by the Fur protein in response to exogenous iron concentration.
Vibrioferrin synthetic genes show very extensive homology to a similar cluster in Xanthomonas, although the precise structure of the siderophore in Xanthomonas is not the same.  
In Vibrio there is a dedicated transport system for vibrioferrin, which is included in this subsystem. Other organisms with very similar iron siderophores biosynthetic genes may use some other of the highly homologous Iron transport systems.

docs.description:
Violacein is a violet pigment produced by Gram-negative bacteria living in tropical aqueous environments and soils. It is produced from the condensation of two L-tryptophans and the addition of molecular oxygen. The structure of violacein is made up of three structural units:  a 5-hydroxyindole, an oxindole, and a 2-pyyrolidone. The function of violacein may be to protect the bacterium from UV radiation. This pigment has potential medical applications as antibacterial, anti-trypanocidal, anti-ulcerogenic, and anticancer drugs.
A 14-electron oxidation pathway yields the final chromophore. The flavoenzyme VioA and the heme protein VioB work in conjunction to oxidize and dimerize l-tryptophan to a nascent product that can default to the off pathway metabolite chromopyrrolic acid. In the presence of VioE, the intermediate instead undergoes on-pathway [1,2] indole rearrangement to prodeoxyviolacein. The last two enzymes in the pathway are flavin-dependent oxygenases, VioC and VioD, that act sequentially. VioD hydroxylates one indole ring at the 5-position to yield proviolacein, and VioC then acts on the other indole ring at the 2-position to create the oxindole and complete violacein formation.

docs.description:
Chorismate is a branch point in the synthesis of the aromatic amino acids, phenylalanine, tyrosine and tryptophan. Chorismate is also a major branch point for other important aromatic compounds, including antibiotics, vitamins to name a few. This subsystem covers the genes and proteins that lead from chorismate to the biosynthesis of L-phenylalanine and L-tyrosine. Chorismate mutase (AroH) takes chorismate to prephenate. There are several non-homologous-types of AroH: 1) AroHI, and a periplasmic precursor (*AroHI) which are homologs; 2)AroHII in bacteria and Archaea; and 3) the plant type, AroAIII). 

Prephenate is another branch point which takes prephenate to either phenylalanine or tyrosine. The enzyme steps to phenylalanine include an aminotransferase and a dehydatase which can occur in either reaction order. Prephenat dehydratase (PheAIp) takes prephenate to phenylpyruvate which is then transaminated in the presence of an amino acid donor such as L-glutamate to form L-phenylalanine.  In the opposite order of reaction steps, prephenate is transaminated to form L-arogenate and arogenate dehydratase (PheAIa) then uses the L-arogenate to produce L-phenylalanine. There is also a periplasmic precursor cyclohexadienyl dehydratase (*PheAIIc).

For the tyrosine pathway, prephenate dehydrogenase (TyrAp) takes prephenate to 4-hydroxyphenyl-pyruvate which is then transaminated to form L-tyrosine in the presence of the amino acid donor. The reverse order of reaction steps occur when prephenate is first transaminated to form L-arogenate, followed by arogenate dehydrogenase (TyrAa) which forms L-tyrosine from L-arogenate. Cyclohexadienyl dehydrogenase (TyrAc) uses either of the two substrates (prephenate or arogenate) to ultimately synthesize L-tyrosine. These dehydrogenases use either NAD, NADP or both (NAD(P)H) and are sorted as such in the subsystem.

The aminotransferases are divided into several classes: Biosynthetic Aromatic amino acid aminotransferase alpha (AroJIα), Biosynthetic Aromatic amino acid aminotransferase beta (AroJIβ), periplasmic aromatic amino acid aminotransferase beta precursor (*AroJIβ), and Aromatic amino acid aminotransferase gamma (AroJIγ).

Auxiliary functional roles include homologs that may be confused with the actual pathway functional role such as 4-amino, 4-deoxychorismate mutase (PapB) and Isochorismate mutase (PchB) which are homologs of chorismate mutase; and 4-amino, 4-deoxyprephenate dehydrogenase (PapC), a homolog of  prephenate dehydrogenase.

Bacterial RNA polyadenylation apears to be a signal for RNA degradation.

Variants:
1 = poly(A) polymerase without Hfq
2 = poly(A) polymerase and Hfq

Hfq is included because of evidence for a functional association with poly(A) polymerase:

Mohanty, B. K., Maples, V. F., and Kushner, S. R.  2004.  The Sm-like protein Hfq regulates polyadenylation dependent mRNA decay in Escherichia coli.  Mol. Microbiol. 54: 905-920.

Hfq protein has limited phylogenetic distribution.  PSI-BLAST very impressively finds a set of proteins, and nothing else close.
Present in Aquifex
Present in Thermotoga
Present in many, but not all Proteobacteria (no epsilons, not rickettsia group)
Present Leptospira, but not Treponema
Present in Bacillus and relatives, but not in most low G+C gram positives
not in high G+C gram positives
not in cyanobacteria
not in Chloroflexus
not in Deinococcus and Thermus
not in Chlamydia group

Polyribonucleotide nucleotidyltransferase is included because of evidence for functional association.

tRNA nucleotidyltransferase (EC 2.7.7.25) is included because it is a difficult-to-separate paralogue of Poly(A) polymerase (EC 2.7.7.19).

docs.description:
In some Bacilli, the distinct outermost layer of spores are well separated from the spore coat. The exosporium is composed of one or more paracrystalline layers surrounded by an outermost 'hairy nap' layer.

The precise function of the exosporium is not known. However, as it makes up the surface of the endospore that is exposed to the environment, it may be important in attachment and colonization. The exosporium is also the site of major spore surface antigens. In B. anthracis it may contribute to protection of the spore from the macrophage, masking epitopes recognized by the macrophage, although it is not essential for virulence. The exosporium is composed of proteins, lipids and carbohydrates, and it is synthesized and assembled concomitantly with the cortex and the coat.

The exosporium is a loose-fitting, balloon-like structure composed of a paracrystalline basal layer and an external hair-like nap. The filaments of the hair-like nap are formed by a single collagen-like glycoprotein called BclA, whereas the basal layer is composed of a number of different proteins in tight and loose associations.

The basal layer proteins also include three enzymes: alanine racemase, inosine-uridine-preferring nucleoside hydrolase, and superoxide dismutase. These proteins may not be structural elements but merely very strongly adsorbed. The first two enzymes degrade the germinants L-alanine and inosine, respectively, and may function to suppress germination. Superoxide dismutase could protect the spore from reactive oxygen species during infection, participate in oxidative cross-linking of coat or exosporium proteins, or moderate germination efficiency upon exposure to superoxide.

A processed CotE spore morphogenetic protein is also located in the exosporium (CotE is a major morphogenetic protein in spore coat assembly and is situated between the inner and outer coat layers of the mature spore).

Besides the BclA glycoprotein, at least 10 more proteins are tightly associated with the exosporium of B. cereus ATCC 10876, as identified by N-terminal sequencing of proteins from purified, washed exosporium. Eight genes encode likely structural components (exsB, exsC, exsD, exsE, exsF, exsG, exsJ, and cotE). ExsJ is a glycoprotein. Most of the exosporium genes are scattered on the genome.

"Cobalamin biosynthesis protein CobC"  (instead of CobD).  The source of the confusion is not
clear, but the function identification was in Salmonella, where the gene is CobD.

CobU = Adenosylcobinamide-phosphate guanylyltransferase (EC 2.7.7.62) was originally thought
to include Adenosylcobinamide kinase (EC 2.7.1.156) activity.  The above pathway produces
the phosphorylated form already, so the kinase activity is now removed from the annocation.

docs.description:
This Subsystem was originally encoded by Claudia Reich, whose contribution we gratefully acknowledge
 
Lysozymes (EC 3.2.1.17) hydrolyse the β-(1,4) glycosidic bond between N-acetylmuramic acid and N-acetylglucosamine in peptidoglycan, the major cell wall polymer in the Bacteria. Lysozymes are implicated in defensive and offensive bactericidal systems in a wide range of taxonomically diverse organisms including fungi, protozoa, plants, invertebrate and vertebrate animals and even bacteriophages. Bacteria have in turn evolved mechanisms to evade or subvert this threat, most commonly by peptidoglycan modification. A different bacterial strategy to evade the bactericidal action of lysozyme is the production of lysozyme inhibitors.
The location of the bacterial lysozyme inhibitors either in the periplasm (Inhibitor of vertebrate lysozyme precursor Ivy and Periplasmic lysozyme inhibitor of c-type lysozyme PliC) or anchored to the luminal face of the outer membrane (Membrane-bound lysozyme inhibitor of c-type lysozyme MliC) is consistent with a role in protecting peptidoglycan from hydrolysis by exogenous lysozymes.

docs.description: Denitrification is the process of reducing nitrate to dinitrogen gas.  The intermediates of this process are Nitrate -> Nitrite -> Nitric Oxide -> Nitrous Oxide -> Dinitrogen.  Four gene clusters control each step of denitrification:  the nar gene cluster (nitrate reductase), the nir gene cluster (nitrite reductase), the nor gene cluster (nitric oxide reductase), and the nos gene cluster (nitrous oxide reductase).

docs.description: F-type H+-ATPase (F0F1) and vacuolar type H+-ATPase (V0V1) are two classes of a superfamily of H+-translocatig ATPases. F0F1 is responsible for ATP synthesis and is present in inner membranes of mitochondria, thylakoid membranes of chloroplasts, and plasma membranes of bacteria. These enzymes are composed of a hydrophobic membrane part (F0) and a hydrophilic catalytic part (F1). F0 forms a proton channel across the membranes and is composed of at least three kinds of transmembrane subunits, one of which is the most evolutionarily conserved 8-kDa proteolipid subunit. F1, which can easily be separated from the membranes and shows ATPase activity, is composed of two kinds of nucleotide binding subunits,alpha  and beta, and three minor subunits, gamma, delta, and epsilon with a stoichiometry alpha3beta3gamma,delta,epsilon. The gamma subunit penetrates the central cavity of the hexagonal alpha3beta3 like a shaft and rotates when F1 hydrolyzes ATP

docs.description:
Fluoroquinolones are synthetic derivatives of nalidixic acid and exhibit broad-spectrum and powerful antibacterial activity. Quinolones act by converting their targets into toxic enzymes that fragment the bacterial chromosome. Quinolone resistance normally arises by mutations in the molecular targets (DNA gyrase GyrA and topoisomerase IV) or chromosomal genes for type II topoisomerases (GyrA, GyrB). It can also be achieved through, efflux pumps and their regulatory genes or by plasmid/chromosome-mediated DNA gyrase protection through pentapeptide repeat proteins. Two other resistance mechanisms are mediated by aminoglycoside acetyltransferase AAC(6')-Ib-cr and QepA and described in the subsystem "Resistance to the fluoroquinolones norfloxacin and ciprofloxacin".

MfpA, a member of the pentapeptide repeat family, causes resistance to ciprofloxacin and sparfloxacin. This protein binds to DNA gyrase and inhibits its activity. Its three-dimensional structure reveals a fold, that exhibits size, shape, and electrostatic similarity to B-form DNA. This represents a form of DNA mimicry and explains both its inhibitory effect on DNA gyrase and fluoroquinolone resistance resulting from the protein's expression in vivo.

docs.description: Vibrio cholerae contains multiple systems for iron acquisition, essential in the human host as well as in its other environmental niches, including the TonB-dependent transport of heme, a Feo system for the transport of ferrous iron and an ABC transporter, ferric iron transporter Fbp. It also utilizes endogenous siderophore vibriobactin and several siderophores that are produced by other microorganisms (Wyckoff et al., 2007).

docs.description: The omptins are a family of enterobacterial surface proteases/adhesins that share high sequence identity and a conserved beta-barrel fold in the outer membrane. The omptins are multifunctional, and the individual omptins exhibit differing virulence-associated functions. The Pla plasminogen activator of Yersinia pestis contributes by several mechanisms to bacterial invasiveness and the systemic, uncontrolled proteolysis in plague. Pla proteolytically activates the human proenzyme plasminogen and inactivates the antiprotease alpha2-antiplasmin, and its binding to laminin localizes the uncontrolled plasmin activity onto basement membranes. These properties enhance bacterial migration through tissue barriers. Pla also degrades circulating complement proteins and functions in bacterial invasion into human epithelial cells. PgtE of Salmonella enterica and OmpT of Escherichia coli have been shown to degrade cationic antimicrobial peptides from epithelial cells or macrophages. PgtE and SopA of Shigella flexneri appear important in the intracellular phases of salmonellosis and shigellosis, whereas functions of OmpT have mainly been associated with protein degradation in E. coli cells. The differing virulence roles and functions have been attributed to minor sequence variations at the surface-exposed regions important for substrate recognition, to the dependence of omptin functions on lipopolysaccharide, and to the different regulation of omptin expression.

The Bacillus subtilis fadR regulon involved in fatty acid degradation comprises five operons, lcfA-fadR-fadB-etfB-etfA, lcfB, fadN-fadA-fadE, fadH-fadG, and fadF-acdA-rpoE. Three of these: lcfA-fadRB-etfBA, lcfB, and fadNAE operons are directly participate in the β-oxidation cycle ((PMID:21398533; PMID:17189250)
This Subsystem encodes one of them, namely the fadN-fadA-fadE (formely yusJ-yusK-yusL)

The fadNAE (and lcfA-fadRB-etfBA, lcfB operons) have been reported to be induced upon glucose starvation (PMID:15809868) and they are catabolite repressed (PMID:21398533).  The catabolite repression is dependent on CcpA and mediated by the respective cre located in the lcfA, lcfB, or fadN gene (PMID:21398533).  Furthermore, the fadNAE operon is induced at the onset of sporulation (PMID:12817086). This induction requires the YvbA protein involved in cannibalism by sporulating cells.
notes:
J Bacteriol. 2011 May;193(10):2388-95. PMID:21398533
Catabolite repression of the Bacillus subtilis FadR regulon, which is involved in fatty acid catabolism.
Tojo S1, Satomura T, Matsuoka H, Hirooka K, Fujita Y.
Abstract
The Bacillus subtilis fadR regulon involved in fatty acid degradation comprises five operons, lcfA-fadR-fadB-etfB-etfA, lcfB, fadN-fadA-fadE, fadH-fadG, and fadF-acdA-rpoE. Since the lcfA-fadRB-etfBA, lcfB, and fadNAE operons, whose gene products directly participate in the β-oxidation cycle, had been found to be probably catabolite repressed upon genome-wide transcript analysis, we performed Northern blotting, which indicated that they are clearly under CcpA-dependent catabolite repression. So, we searched for catabolite-responsive elements (cre's) to which the complex of CcpA and P-Ser-HPr binds to exert catabolite repression by means of a web-based cis-element search in the B. subtilis genome using known cre sequences, which revealed the respective candidate cre sequences in the lcfA, lcfB, and fadN genes. DNA footprinting indicated that the complex actually interacted with these cre's in vitro. Deletion analysis of each cre using the lacZ fusions with the respective promoter regions of the three operons with and without it, indicated that these cre's are involved in the CcpA-dependent catabolite repression of the operons in vivo.


J Biol Chem. 2007 Feb 23;282(8):5180-94. Epub 2006 Dec 22. PMID:17189250
Organization and function of the YsiA regulon of Bacillus subtilis involved in fatty acid degradation.
Matsuoka H1, Hirooka K, Fujita Y.
Abstract
The organization and function of the Bacillus subtilis YsiA regulon involved in fatty acid degradation were investigated. Northern and primer extension analyses indicated that this regulon comprises five operons, i.e. lcfA-ysiA-B-etfB-A, ykuF-G, yhfL, yusM-L-K-J, and ywjF-acdA-rpoE. YusJ and AcdA, YsiB and YusL, and YusK presumably encode acyl-CoA dehydrogenases, 3-hydroxyl-CoA dehydrogenase/enoyl-CoA hydratase complexes, and acetyl-CoA C-acyltransferase, respectively, which are directly involved in the fatty acid beta-oxidation cycle. In addition, LcfA and YhfL are likely to encode long chain acyl-CoA ligases. On gel retardation and footprinting analyses involving the purified YsiA protein, we identified cis-sequences for YsiA binding (YsiA boxes) in the promoter regions upstream of ysiA, ykuF, yusL, yhfL, and ywjF, the equilibrium dissociation constants (K(d)) for YsiA binding being 20, 21, 37, 43, and 65 nm, respectively. YsiA binding was specifically inhibited by long chain acyl-CoAs with 14-20 carbon atoms, acyl-CoAs with 18 carbon atoms being more effective; out of long chain acyl-CoAs tested, monounsaturated oleoyl-CoA, and branched chain 12-metyltetradecanoyl-CoA were most effective. These in vitro findings were supported by the in vivo observation that the knock-out of acyl-CoA dehydrogenation through yusJ, etfA, or etfB disruption resulted in YsiA inactivation, probably because of the accumulation of long chain acyl-CoAs in the cells. Furthermore, the disruption of yusL, yusK, yusJ, etfA, etfB, or ykuG affected the utilization of palmitic acid, a representative long chain fatty acid. Based on this work, ysiA, ysiB, ykuF, ykuG, yhfL, yusM, yusL, yusK, yusJ, and ywjF can be renamed fadR, fadB, fadH, fadG, lcfB, fadM, fadN, fadA, fadE, and fadF.

docs.description:
The shikimate pathway, including seven enzymatic steps for production of chorismate via shikimate from phosphoenolpyruvate and erythrose-4-phosphate, is common in various organisms for the biosynthesis of not only aromatic amino acids but also most biogenic benzene derivatives. 

3-Amino-4-hydroxybenzoic acid (3,4-AHBA) is a benzene derivative serving as a precursor for several secondary metabolites like grixazone produced by Streptomyces griseus. The biosynthesis pathway of grixazone led to identification of the biosynthesis pathway of 3,4-AHBA from two primary metabolites. GriI and GriH, within the grixazone biosynthesis gene cluster were found to be responsible for the biosynthesis of 3,4-AHBA. GriI catalyzes the aldol condensation between two primary metabolites, l-aspartate-4-semialdehyde and dihydroxyacetone phosphate, to form a 7-carbon product, 2-amino-4,5-dihydroxy-6-one-heptanoic acid-7-phosphate, which is subsequently converted to 3,4-AHBA by GriH. The latter reaction requires Mn(2+), but no other cofactor. This pathway is independent of the shikimate pathway, representing a novel, simple enzyme system responsible for the synthesis of a benzene ring from the C(3) and C(4) primary metabolites.

Alternative biochemistry:
6-deoxy-5-ketofructose 1-phosphate and l-aspartate semialdehyde are precursors to DHQ. The sugar, which is derived from glucose 6-P, supplies a "hydroxyacetone" fragment, which, via a transaldolase reaction, undergoes an aldol condensation with the l-aspartate semialdehyde to form 2-amino-3,7-dideoxy-D-threo-hept-6-ulosonic acid. Despite the fact that both hydroxyacetone and hydroxyacetone-P were measured in the cell extracts and confirmed to arise from glucose 6-P, neither compound was found to serve as a precursor to DHQ. This amino sugar then undergoes a NAD dependent oxidative deamination to produce 3,7-dideoxy-d-threo-hept-2,6-diulosonic acid which cyclizes to 3-dehydroquinate. The protein product of the M. jannaschii MJ0400 gene catalyzes the transaldolase reaction and the protein product of the MJ1249 gene catalyzes the oxidative deamination and the cyclization reactions.
notes:

DAHPS - "The biosynthetic reaction is a condensation of P-enolpyruvate and D-erythrose-4-P to form orthophosphate and 3-deoxy-D-arabino-heptulosonate 7-phosphate.  The latter designation has been used in accordance with both the Carbohydrate Committee rules and Chemical Abstracts usage since 1960.  However, the Enzyme Commission has adopted a different systemic name (7-phospho-2-oxo-3-deoxy-D-arabino-heptonate D-erythrose-4-phosphate-lyase (pyruvate phosphorylating), EC 4.1.2.15) and recommemded the use of the trivial name, phospho-2-keto-3-deoxyheptonate aldolase. In spite of the fact that the reaction catalyzed by 3-deoxy-D-arabino-heptulosonate 7-phosphate synthase is irreversible, the E.C. name is based upon the reverse reaction.  It is also clear that the reaction is not an aldol condensation. The E.C. name is further inappropriate because of the implication that pyruvate would be phosphorylated, even though pyruvate is not a participant in the reaction."

docs.description:
The macromolecular synthesis (MMS) operon contains three essential genes (rpsU, dnaG, rpoD) whose products ribosomal protein S21 (rpsU), DNA primase (dnaG), and the 70-kDal sigma subunit of RNA are necessary for the initiation of protein, DNA, and RNA synthesis respectively." (PMID: 8316085 Versalovic et al)
Originally observed in Escherichia coli and Salmonella typhimurium (PMID: 3005129 Erickson, et al) it is present in a variety of organisms.
notes:
This SS was started by Ross Overbeek.

    Mol Microbiol. 1993 Apr;8(2):343-55.Links
    Conservation and evolution of the rpsU-dnaG-rpoD macromolecular
    synthesis operon in bacteria.

    Versalovic J, Koeuth T, Britton R, Geszvain K, Lupski JR.

    The macromolecular synthesis (MMS) operon contains three essential
    genes (rpsU, dnaG, rpoD) whose products (S21, primase, sigma-70)
    are necessary for the initiation of protein, DNA, and RNA
    synthesis respectively. PCR amplifications with primers
    complementary to conserved regions within these three genes, and
    subsequent DNA sequencing of rpsU-dnaG PCR products, demonstrate
    that the three genes appear to be contiguous in 11 different
    Gram-negative species. Within the Gram-negative enteric bacterial
    lineage, the S21 amino acid sequence is absolutely conserved in 10
    species examined. The putative nuteq antiterminator sequence in
    rpsU consists of two motifs, boxA and boxB, conserved in primary
    sequence and secondary structure. The terminator sequence, T1,
    located between rpsU and dnaG is conserved at 31 positions in nine
    enterobacterial species, suggesting the importance of primary
    sequence in addition to secondary structure for transcription
    termination. The intergenic region between rpsU and dnaG varies in
    size owing to the presence or absence of the Enterobacterial
    Repetitive Intergenic Consensus (ERIC) DNA element. The rpoD gene
    contains rearrangements involving a divergent sequence, although
    two carboxy-terminal regions which encode functional domains are
    conserved in primary sequence and spacing. Our data suggest that
    primary sequence divergence and DNA rearrangements in both coding
    and non-coding sequences account for the interspecies variation in
    operon structure. However, MMS operon gene organization and
    cis-acting regulatory sequences appear to be conserved in diverse
    bacteria.

    PMID: 8316085

notes:
Notes copied from Bacteriophage_Mu50B-like_prophages_in_Staphylococci:
The three temperate S. aureus bacteriophages Phi11 (Iandolo et al., 2002), phi-ETA (Zou et al., 2000) and Mu50B (Kuroda et al., 2001) appear to be closely related on the sequence level and even share the same attP site (CCATGGGA).  They are believed to have been identical until recently (Iandolo et al., 2002).  Phi11 and Mu50B are especially close, while phi-ETA, which has less sequence similarity might have diverged from other at an earlier time.   This SS encodes the phi-11 and Mu50B- related prophages in various S. aureus strains.

The sequences of phi-11 and Mu50B were extracted from the whole-genome sequence of their SA host strain and read from attL to attR (Iandolo et al., 2002).  ORF numbering and the majority of annotations are according to those suggested for the S. aureus NCTC 8325 phi-11 prophage by Iandolo et al., 2002.
The subsets of roles are VERY approximate and reflect merely the cassette arangement of SA bacteriphage genes and NOT actual functional assignments (unknown for the majority of phage genes)

Variant codes:

-1 = no phi-11/phi-Mu50B-related prophages can be identified in a genome
 1 = genome contains at least one prophage closely related to phi-11 and phi-Mu50B
 2 = bacteriophage genomes

References:

1.  Iandolo JJ, Worrell V, Groicher KH, Qian Y, Tian R, Kenton S, Dorman A, Ji H, Lin S, Loh P, Qi S, Zhu H, Roe BA. 2002. Comparative analysis of the genomes of the temperate bacteriophages phi 11, phi 12 and phi 13 of Staphylococcus aureus 8325. Gene, 289(1-2):109-18

2. Kuroda M, Ohta T, Uchiyama I, Baba T, et al., and Hiramatsu K.  2001.  Whole genome sequencing of meticillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Lancet, 357(9264):1225-40.

3. Zou, D., Kaneko, J., Narita, S., Kamio, Y., 2000. Prophage, phiPV83-pro, 
carrying panton-valentine leukocidin genes, on the Staphylococcus aureus P83 chromosome: comparative analysis of the genome structures of phiPV83-pro, phiPVL, phi11, and other phages. Biosci. Biotechnol. Biochem. 64, 2631�2643.

docs.description:
Methylglyoxal is an electrophile, which at high concentrations can cause cell death. Methylglyoxal reacts rapidly with both proteins and nucleic acids and thus is both toxic and mutagenic. It is a natural metabolite that is related to intermediates in the glycolytic sequence, e.g. dihydroxyacetone phosphate, and its detoxification leads to the production of D-lactate.
 The main source of methylglyoxal is the nonenzymatic fragmentation of triose phosphates, but it also is formed during threonine catabolism and acetone oxidation. In some prokaryotes, dihydroxyacetone phosphate is enzymatically converted to methylglyoxal and inorganic phosphate by methylglyoxal synthase (EC 4.2.3.3) in response to phosphate starvation. 

 The production of methylglyoxal by cells is a paradox that can be resolved by assigning an important role in adaptation to conditions of nutrient imbalance. Analysis of a methylglyoxal synthase-deficient mutant provides evidence that methylglyoxal production is required to allow growth under certain environmental conditions. The production of methylglyoxal may represent a high-risk strategy that facilitates adaptation, but which on failure leads to cell death.
 Prevention of methylglyoxal accumulation can be controlled at the level of detoxification. Several methylglyoxal detoxification pathways have been identified.

 In enteric bacteria, three detoxification routes have been identified:
(1) the glutathione-dependent glyoxalase I-II system,
(2) glutathione-independent glyoxalase III, and 
(3) methylglyoxal reductases and dehydrogenases.

 The major detoxification system in Escherichia coli, the glutathione-dependent glyoxalase I-II system, is conserved from bacteria to man, and this implies universal exposure to this compound at some stage of all life cycles.

*******FUNCTIONAL VARIANTS:********

1.0 - Methylglyoxal formation(mgs) + Main (Glyoxalase I-II) detoxification pathway are present;
2.0 � Methylglyoxal formation(mgs) + Alternate detoxification routes;
3.0 - Methylglyoxal formation(mgs) + Main and alternate detoxification routes;
4.0 - Just Main (Glyoxalase I-II) detoxification pathway (No mgs gene -non-enzymatic formation of methylglyoxal);
5.0 - Just Alternate detoxification routes ( No mgs gene);
6.0 - No formation, but both - Main and alternate- detoxification routes are present;        
9.0 - Just Methylglyoxal formation(mgs gene), no detoxification routes found.
notes:
This Subsystem was originally encoded by Shanmugam, K.T , University of Florida ( see Clearinghouse: Subsystem: Methylglyoxal Pathway; Author: master:shan).

********SUBSYSTEM NOTES:*************

#1 - Methylglyoxal synthase (EC 4.2.3.3) � catalyzes the apparently irreversible conversion of  dihydroxyacetone phosphate to methylglyoxal and inorganic phosphate. In E. coli encoded by the mgs gene. The corresponding gene in eukaryotic cells has yet to be characterized.

#2 -Lactoylglutathione lyase (EC 4.4.1.5) - Glyoxalase I  - catalyzes the first of two sequential steps in the conversion of methylgloxal to D-lactate. The enzyme tightly binds one ion of nickel per enzyme dimer and is the first example of a Ni-containing isomerase.Glyoxalase I isomerises hemithiolacetal to S-lactoylglutathione, which is the substrate for glyoxalase II. Glutathione is released during the conversion of S-lactoylglutathione to D-lactate by glyoxalase II. The gene for glyoxalase I has been cloned from E. coli, S. typhimurium and Pseudomonas putida; and shows high levels of sequence conservation with the human colon enzyme

#3 -Hydroxyacylglutathione hydrolase (EC 3.1.2.6) -  Glyoxalase II  -catalyzes the second of two sequential reactions in the conversion of methylglyoxal to D-lactate. Bacterial glyoxalase II has been less well characterised, but the structural gene has recently been cloned from E. coli. The protein is approximately 29 kDa and shows considerable similarity with the human homologue (approximately 60% sequence similarity in each case). In contrast to glyoxalase I, the human and bacterial enzymes have similar masses and show only small discontinuities in the sequence match. Gene sequences that could encode homologues of glyoxalase II are widespread among prokaryotes, including the archaea and gram-positive bacteria. Several organisms, including E. coli, have two ORFs with similarity to the human glyoxalase II.

Glyoxalase III  - is a newly discovered enzyme in E. coli K-12 that converts methylglyoxal into D-lactate in one step without the use of GSH. Previously the only known route for this conversion was the two-step pathway catalyzed by glyoxalase I and II, utilizing GSH. Glyoxalase III has been partially characterized but its genetics are unknown. ( Ref.4)

#6 - Methylglyoxal reductase  - catalyzes the conversion of methylglyoxal into lactaldehyde. The lactaldehyde is then acted upon by lactaldehyde dehydrogenase yielding lactate. This provides an alternate route for methylglyoxal metabolism. Methylglyoxal reductase is an important enzyme in controlling methylglyoxal levels in eukaryotic cells, catalyzing the reduction of 2-oxoaldehydes to the corresponding 2-hydroxyaldehydes, and catalysing aldehydes to alcohols. However, the physiological significance of these enzymes in E. coli is debatable. An NADH- and an NADPH-dependent �methylglyoxal dehydrogenase�have been purified from E. coli.

=====AUX functional role:============

   Membrane-bound lytic murein transglycosylase D precursor (EC 3.2.1.-) - in cluster with Hydroxyacylglutathione hydrolase (EC 3.1.2.6) in more than 100 spicies; all E.coli, Salmonella, Shewanella, Yersinia, Bordetella, Azotobacter, Pseudomonas, Xanthomonas, Vibrio.  


========REFERENCES================
1a. Bacterial production of methylglyoxal: a survival strategy or death by misadventure?
Booth IR, Ferguson GP, Miller S, Li C, Gunasekera B, Kinghorn S.
Biochem Soc Trans. 2003 Dec;31(Pt 6):1406-8. Review.PMID: 14641075

1. Kalapos MP.  Methylglyoxal in living organisms: chemistry, biochemistry, toxicology and biological implications. Toxicol Lett. 1999 Nov 22;110(3):145-75. Review. PMID: 10597025
2. Ferguson GP, Totemeyer S, MacLean MJ, Booth IR.  Methylglyoxal production in bacteria: suicide or survival? Arch Microbiol. 1998 Oct;170(4):209-18. Review. PMID: 9732434
3. Vickers TJ, Greig N, Fairlamb AHA trypanothione-dependent glyoxalase I with a prokaryotic ancestry in Leishmania major. Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 2004 Sep 7;101(36):13186-91.
4. Misra K, Banerjee AB, Ray S, Ray M (1995). Glyoxalase III from Escherichia coli: a single novel enzyme for the conversion of methylglyoxal into D-lactate without reduced glutathione. Biochem J 1995;305 ( Pt 3);999-1003.

notes:
Notes copied from Energy_conserving_hydrogenase_b,_Methanococcales-Methanobacteriales-Methanopyrales:


Notes copied from Energy_conserving_hydrogenase,_Methanococcales-Methanobacteriales-Methanopyrales:
eha or energy-conserving hydrogenase A.  Present in the hydrogenotrophic methanogens Methanothermobacter, Methanopyrus, Methanococcus, Methanocaldococcus.  This class of enzymes reduces low potential electron acceptors (midpoint potential ~-500 mV) with hydrogen gas.  Since this reaction is unfavorable, it is driven by the proton motive force.  Some organisms possess two homologs of this system (eha and ehb).  These reactions are required to generate the reductant for the first step in methanogenesis (formylmethanofuran dehydrogenase reaction) and a number of anabolic reactions such those catalyzed by acetyl-CoA synthase, pyruvate oxidoreductase and other ferredoxin-dependent oxidoreductases. 

ehaI, ehaI2,ehaI3 were named according to position.  Similarity was not detected.
ehaK, ehaK2, ehaK3 were named according to position.  Similarity was not detected.
ehaP, ehaP2, ehaP3, and ehaP4 are paralogs to each other and ehaU.  ehaP2 is homologous to the C-terminal of ehaP.  ehaP4 is homologous with the N-terminal of ehaP3.  My interpretation is: the ancestral state was three paralogs represented by ehaP, ehaP3 and ehaU.  All modern lineages contain ehaU.  In Methanothermobacter, the ehaP3 paralog was lost and replaced by a duplication of ehaP.  In Methanopyrus, the ehaP was inherited unchanged.  In addition, the C-terminal of ehaP3 was lost and replaced by a new gene derived from the C-terminal of ehaP (which I called ehaP2).  For Methanococcus and Methanocaldococcus, the ehaP3 paralog was inherited intact.  However, the N-terminal portion of ehaP paralog was lost, forming a ehaP2 homolog.

docs.description:
Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) have important structural roles in cell membranes.  In higher eukaryotes they are also intermediates in the synthesis of biologically active molecules such as eicosanoids, which mediate fever, inflammation, blood pressure and neurotransmission.  Lower eukaryotes are particularly rich in C20-22 polyunsaturated fatty acids. Fungi and marine microalgae are currently used to produce dietary nutrients for neonatal babies, since arachidonic and docosahexaenoic acids are essential components of brain tissues required for the development of neural and retinal functions

Until the 1990s it was thought that, with the exception of cyanobacteria, bacteria had no polyunsaturated fatty acids.  It has since been found that omega-3 long-chain PUFAs such as eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) are preferentially distributed in psychrophilic bacteria that inhabit low-temperature deep-sea environments and the intestines of sea ﬁsh. After the discovery of the EPA biosynthetic pfa genes (Yazawa et al., 1996; Metz et al., 2001), their  homologues were detected in sequenced genomes of various marine bacteria.  The  pfa genes of Moritella marina MP-1 were the ﬁrst genes to be  cloned from DHA-producing bacteria (Tanaka et al., 1999).   Notably, PUFAs detected in bacteria are mostly EPA or DHA and not C18 PUFAs such as linoleic and linolenic acids, which are most common in animals, plants, fungi, and cyanobacteria.   

Polyunsaturated fatty acids can be synthesized by two different pathways: an anaerobic one, by using polyketide synthase related enzymes, and an aerobic one, which involves the action of elongases and oxygen dependent desaturases.  Only the former is encoded in this Subsystem. It is the only PUFA biosynthetic pathway known for prokaryotes (Metz et al., 2001), it is currently under intense investigation

notes:
This subsystem was originally encoded by master:MikeK. 
Ownership of the SS was changed 11/02/06 to OlgaZ for extending and further maintenance. 

================OVERVIEW:===================
   
   Rhamnose biosynthesis pathway genes have been found in several gram-negative bacteria, including Escherichia coli, Salmonella enterica, Xanthomonas campestris, and Shigella flexneri.

   In gram-positive bacteria rfb homologues, designated rml genes in Streptococcus mutans and cps genes in Streptococcus pneumoniae, have been characterized, and these homologues appear to play an essential role in the production of serotype-specific, rhamnose-containing CPS antigens.

  Various lactic acid bacteria, including lactobacilli, streptococci, and lactococci, characteristically contain rhamnose in their cell walls. Lactococcal cell wall polysaccharides decorate the peptidoglycan network, and rhamnose is one of the major components of these sugar polymers and has been suggested to be the primary binding site for certain bacteriophages.

The reaction steps and the genes required for dTDP-L-rhamnose biosynthesis are: 

1) dTTP + D-Glc-1-P -->  dTDP-D-Glc + PPi 
(glucose-1-phosphate thymidyltransferase, RmlA: EC 2.7.7.24);

2) dTDP-D-Glc -->dTDP-6-deoxy-D-xylo-4-hexulose
 (dTDP-D-glucose 4,6-dehydratase, RmlB: EC 4.2.1.46);
 
3) dTDP-6-deoxy-D-xylo-4-hexulose -->  dTDP-6-deoxy-L-lyxo-4-hexulose 
(dTDP-4-dehydrorhamnose 3,5-epimerase, RmlC: EC 5.1.3.13);

4) dTDP-6-deoxy-L-lyxo-4-hexulose + NAD(P)H -->dTDP-L-rhamnose + NAD(P)+
 (dTDP-4-dehydrorhamnose reductase, RmlD: EC 1.1.1.133).

==== Mycobacteria=========

    Four reactions are catalyzed by four enzyme activities of ��-d-glucose-1-phosphate thymidylyltransferase (RmlA), dTDP-d-glucose-4,6-dehydratase (RmlB), dTDP-4-keto-6-deoxyglucose-3, 5-epimerase (RmlC), and dTDP-6-deoxy-l-lyxo-4-hexulose reductase (RmlD), respectively. The rmlA-D genes for the RmlA-D enzymes are located together as rml gene cluster in many Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria, e.g., Escherichia coli, Salmonella enterica, Vibrio cholerae , Streptococcus mutans, etc. However, Mycobacterium tuberculosis rmlA-D genes are not located in a locus in the genome. The rmlA (Rv0334) gene is isolated from any other rhamnosyl formation enzymes, the rmlB (Rv3464) and rmlC (Rv3465) genes are together in an operon, and rmlD (Rv3266c) gene is found in an operon with wbbL (Rv3265c) and manB (Rv3264c).
  The rhamnosyl transferase encoded by wbbL gene transfers the rhamnosyl residue of dTDP-rhamnose into d-N-acetyl-glucosaminosyl-1-phosphate to form a disaccharide linker.

======================NOTES:========

In Corynebacterium and Bifidobacterium longum � fusion bifunctional protein RfbC/ RfbD:
dTDP-4-dehydrorhamnose 3,5-epimerase (EC 5.1.3.13) / dTDP-4-dehydrorhamnose reductase (EC 1.1.1.133).

==================REFERENCES:=====================


1. Boels IC, Beerthuyzen MM, Kosters MH, Van Kaauwen MP, Kleerebezem M, De Vos WM. Identification and functional characterization of the Lactococcus lactis rfb operon, required for dTDP-rhamnose Biosynthesis. J Bacteriol. 2004 Mar;186(5):1239-48.PMID: 14973085

2. Li W, Xin Y, McNeil MR, Ma Y. rmlB and rmlC genes are essential for growth of mycobacteria. Biochem Biophys Res Commun. 2006 Mar 31;342(1):170-8. Epub 2006 Feb 3. PMID: 16472764.

3. Graninger M, Nidetzky B, Heinrichs DE, Whitfield C, Messner P. Characterization of dTDP-4-dehydrorhamnose 3,5-epimerase and dTDP-4-dehydrorhamnose reductase, required for dTDP-L-rhamnose biosynthesis in Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium LT2. J Biol Chem. 1999 Aug 27;274(35):25069-77. PMID: 10455186


===========================================================
"An l-rhamnosyl residue plays an essential structural role in the cell wall of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Therefore, the four enzymes (RmlA to RmlD) that form dTDP-rhamnose from dTTP and glucose-1-phosphate are important targets for the development of new tuberculosis therapeutics."*


*http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=90481&rendertype=abstract

*Drug Targeting Mycobacterium tuberculosis Cell Wall Synthesis: Genetics of dTDP-Rhamnose Synthetic Enzymes and Development of a Microtiter Plate-Based Screen for Inhibitors of Conversion of dTDP-Glucose to dTDP-Rhamnose
Yufang Ma,1 Richard J. Stern,1 Michael S. Scherman,1 Varalakshmi D. Vissa,1 Wenxin Yan,1 Victoria Cox Jones,1 Fangqiu Zhang,2 Scott G. Franzblau,2 Walter H. Lewis,3 and Michael R. McNeil1*

Department of Microbiology, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, Colorado 805231; College of Pharmacy, University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, Illinois 606122; and Department of Biology, Washington University, St. Louis, Missouri 631303

docs.description:
Pyoverdines (PVDs) are complex siderophores produced by members of the fluorescent Pseudomonas. They comprise a dihydroxyquinoline fluorescent chromophore joined to a peptide of remarkably variable length and composition. Close to 40 structurally different pyoverdines have been identified to date,
from different species of Pseudomonas, with each strain making a single (and characteristic) form of pyoverdine; although they can utilize many different pyoverdines. As a fluorescent pigment, it represents a useful marker for bacterial differentiation. P. aeruginosa strains, for example, secrete one of three distinct pyoverdines (Types I�III). Pyoverdines are composed of three parts: (i) a fluorescent dihydroxyquinoline chromophore that is common to all pyoverdines; (ii) an acyl side chain (either dicarboxylic acid or amide) bound to the amino group of the chromophore; and (iii) a strain-specific peptide chain linked via an amide bound to the C1 (rarely C3) carboxyl group of the chromophore.

Pyoverdines are of considerable scientific interest because of their contribution to pathogenicity of P. aeruginosa (Meyer et al. 1996; Takase et al. 2000) and because of their role in the ecology of soil pseudomonads and their possible involvement in biological control of plant pathogens (Loper and Henkels 1999; Weller et al. 2002)

Genes responsible for the biosynthesis, excretion, uptake and regulation of these high-affinity siderophores are located either at a single locus or at up to three different loci in the genomes of the four pseudomonads analyzed. The peptide backbone of PVD is assembled by non-ribosomal peptide synthetases (NRPSs) and modified by accessory enzymes in the cytoplasm, and probably the periplasm. Regulation of PVD production and uptake depends on two extracytoplasmic sigma factors (ECF-sigmas), PvdS and FpvI, together with one anti-sigma, FpvR.

notes:
Comments, observations

1. Many species of Burkholderia contain several genes related to those of pyoverdine biosynthesis of Pseudomonas, grouped in a small cluster (Variant code 9). It is not clear, if these proteins are indeed involved in some type of pyoverdine biosynthesis.  There are two notable points, however:
- this cluster contains putative PvdA and PvdF homologs, which encode L-ornithine N5-monooxygenase and N5-hydroxyornithine formyltransferase respectively
- genes of an inducible arginine deiminase pathway (which produces ATP via fermentation of arginine into ortnithine) are located near-by in Burkholderia mallei
- Fe transporting systems are also near � some type of siderophore is being produced from ornithine?

2. The pvcABCD genes have been included in this Subsystem merely as auxiliary roles.  This operon has been associated with pyoverdine maturation by (Stintzi et al. 1996, 1999).  However, no expression of these genes could be detected during active pyoverdine biosynthesis by (Zaborin et al., 2008).  Involvement of this operon in PYO production was also doubted by (Visca, Imperi, Lamont, 2007)

3. The l-2,4-diaminobutyrate, which is required for pyoverdine synthesis, is produced by the aminotransferase PvdH. It has been predicted that during the synthesis of the pyoverdine chromophore, PvdL, a nonribosomal peptide synthetase, catalyzes the peptide linkage between l-2,4-diaminobutyrate and d-tyrosine (26). The enzyme required for cyclization of l-2,4-diaminobutyrate to form the pyrimidine ring of the pyoverdine chromophore remains to be discovered


References

Leoni L, Ciervo A, Orsi N, Visca P.  1996.  Iron-regulated transcription of the pvdA gene in Pseudomonas aeruginosa: effect of Fur and PvdS on promoter activity. J Bacteriol., 178(8):2299-313

Meyer JM.  Pyoverdines: pigments, siderophores and potential taxonomic markers of fluorescent Pseudomonas species. Arch Microbiol. 2000 Sep;174(3):135-42

Ravel J, Cornelis P. 2003. Genomics of pyoverdine-mediated iron uptake in pseudomonads. Trends Microbiol. 2003 May;11(5):195-200

Vandenende CS, Vlasschaert M, Seah SY.  2004. Functional characterization of an aminotransferase required for pyoverdine siderophore biosynthesis in Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1. J Bacteriol, 186(17):5596-602.

Visca P., Franceso Imperi and Iain L. Lamont. 2007.  Pyoverdine Synthesis and its Regulation in Fluorescent Pseudomonads (a book chapter)

notes:
This is the Type I topoisomerases from the previous DNA topoisomerases (which will not be maintained)

Variant codes:

1 = Topo-I
2 = Topo-I,Topo-III
3 = Topo-I,Topo-IB
4 = Topo-I,Topo-Ie
5 = Topo-I,Topo-III,Topo-IB
6 = Topo-III
7 = Topo-III,Topo-IB
9 = Topo-I,Topo-III,Top-III-B
or Topo-I,Topo-III,Topo-Ie
or Topo-I,Topo-V
or Topo-Ie

This is a work in progress.
Several of the paralog groups have not been sorted out, especially gyrase versus Topo-IV

Type I topoisomerases cleave one DNA strand and do not require ATP
   A very few degenerate genomes seem to lack all Type I topoisomerases

Type II topoisomerases cleave both DNA strands and are ATP-dependent (hydrolysis is required)
   Every organism needs at least one Type II topoisomerase to maintain the supercoiling of its DNA


Type I:

DNA topoisomerase I
   Relaxes negative supercoils in DNA
   TOP3 gene in yeast, hence topoisomerase III in eukaryotes
   yeast TOP3 mutant could be complemented with bacterial topoisomerase I
   "IncQ plasmid conjugative transfer protein TraB" is a special case of this, but is given separate role name

DNA topoisomerase III
   Bacterial gene with similarity to topoisomerase I

DNA topoisomerase IB:
   Found in a limited group of bacteria and poxvirus genomes
   Does not require magnesium or ATP

DNA topoisomerase I, eukaryotic-type (EC 5.99.1.2)
   First topoisomerase type found in eukaryotes
   Relaxes positive or negative supercoils

DNA topoisomerase V:
   Found in Methanopyrus kandleri
   Related to eukaryotic topo I
   Does not require magnesium or ATP


TypeII -- Now a separate subsystem

Type IIA

DNA topoisomerase II
   Eukaryotic gene with similarity to bacterial DNA gyrase

DNA topoisomerase IV = ParC + ParE
   Two subunit topoisomerase
   Bacterial genes with similarity to DNA gyrase
   Important for chromasome partitioning

DNA gyrase = GyrA + GyrB
   DNA gyrase subunit A
   DNA gyrase subunit B
   Actively adds negative supercoils to DNA

DNA reverse gyrase
   Found in all extreme thermophiles
   Actively adds positive supercoils to DNA
   Nanoarchaeum and Methanopyrus reverse gyrase proteins are fragmented,
      but there is no obvious sign of intein-based trans-splicing.


Type IIB

DNA topoisomerase VI - yeast REC12
   Two subunits, A and B in Archaea and Bdellovibrio

Spo11
   Meiosis-specific protein that initiates meiotic recombination by catalyzing the formation of double-strand
   breaks in DNA via a transesterifcation reaction; required for homologous chromosome pairing and
   synaptonemal complex formation

docs.description:
The "Respiratory Systems - Shewanella" subsystem is being created to summarize the suite of respiratory systems that are found in the sequenced members of this genus in one place.

We have used as a starting point, "Fe(III) respiration - Shewanella type" (svetag).

-------------
Notes from "Fe(III) respiration - Shewanella type" below this point:
-------------
This Subsystem has been encode by Margaret Romine, whose contributions to SEED we gratefully acknowledge.
This subsystem describes the Fe(III) respiratory system found in Shewanella species.  This system is believed to enable their hosts to utilize both insoluble (Fe, Mn) and soluble metals (V, U) as terminal electron acceptors.  Other bacteria such as Geobacter and Anaeromyxobacteria also possess all or some of these capabilities, but appear to utilize non-homolous proteins to mediate the electron transfer steps.  

Components of this electron transfer pathway are distributed across both the inner and outer membrane of this gram negative group of organisms. Electrons are first withdrawn from menaquinone via a specialized membrane-anchored tetraheme cytochrome c, named CymA, that belongs to the NapC family.  This menaquinone oxidase is also required for numerous other anaerobic respiratory pathways in Shewanella.  In S. oneidensis MR-1, CymA is also required for the use of various other electron acceptors including fumarate, nitrate, nitrite, and DSMO (PMID: 9023196, PMID: 12899636).  In Shewanella ANA-3 it also required for respiration of arsenate (PMID: 19760266).  A recent study demonstrated that CymA is sufficient to confer soluble Fe-NTA respiratory capability to E. coli (PMID:18394146).

The current hypothesis is that electrons are transferred from CymA to a periplasmic decaheme cytochrome c, named MtrA and then to surface localized multi-heme cytochromes.  There is still some speculation as to whether additional electron carriers mediate the transfer of electrons from CymA to MtrA.  In S. oneidensis MR-1, two surface localized decaheme cytochrome c's, MtrC and OmcA, contribute to Fe(III) reduction.  Both are lipoproteins and require the type II secretion system to mediate their translocation across the outer membrane.

A beta barrel protein, MtrB, is believed to provide passage for MtrA across the outer membrane whereby it can make contact with and transfer electrons to surface bound c-type cytochromes, MtrC and OmcA (PMID: 20002197).

Comparative analysis of 21 sequenced Shewanella reveals that CymA, MtrA, MtrB, and MtrC are conserved in all of the strains that reduce Fe(III) (all but S. denitrificans)(PMID: 18604222).  A second complex (MtrDEF) analogous to MtrCAB is found in some of the strains.  Varying numbers of additional c-type cytochromes, all lipoproteins predicted to localize to the cell surface and some predicted to bind 11 hemes (UndA, UndB), are encoded next to MtrCAB.  The substrate selectivity of these putative surface localized proteins is currently unknown.  Expression of MtrDEF has only been observed in aggregated cells (PMID: 18412550).

notes:
CymA is utilized by other respiratory pathways in Shewanella so please be sure to maintain the role for this genus.  There is redundancy in some of these respiratory pathways and not all of them are dependent on CymA.  For example, there are 2 nitrate reductases, one which uses CymA and one which uses NapC.

A comparative overview of the gene order can be found in PMID: 18604222.  Note there is a mistake on gene naming in the figure (one of Shal genes is MtrH and not OmcA).  There is also a figure of the MR1 iron respiration pathway here.  A prettier figure is in PMID: 17581116.

Some of the Shewanella genomes need to be updated in SEED.  PV4 is a partial assembly and needs to be replaced.  Missing are S. piezotolerans and S. baltica OS223. 

References:
Zargar K, Saltikov CW. Lysine-91 of the tetraheme c-type cytochrome CymA is essential for quinone interaction and arsenate respiration in Shewanella sp. strain ANA-3. Arch Microbiol. 2009 Nov;191(11):797-806. PMID: 19760266

Myers CR, Myers JM. Cloning and sequence of cymA, a gene encoding a tetraheme cytochrome c required for reduction of iron(III), fumarate, and nitrate by Shewanella putrefaciens MR-1. J Bacteriol. 1997 Feb;179(4):1143-52. PMID: 9023196

Schwalb C, Chapman SK, Reid GA. The tetraheme cytochrome CymA is required for
anaerobic respiration with dimethyl sulfoxide and nitrite in Shewanella
oneidensis. Biochemistry. 2003 Aug 12;42(31):9491-7. PMID: 12899636

Gescher JS, Cordova CD, Spormann AM. Dissimilatory iron reduction in Escherichia coli: identification of CymA of Shewanella oneidensis and NapC of E. coli as ferric reductases. Mol Microbiol. 2008 May;68(3):706-19. PMID:18394146

docs.description: The initiation factor 5A (IF-5A) of archaea and eukaryotes undergoes an unusual post-translational modification consisting of the transformation of a specific conserved lysine residue into the amino acid hypusine. This occurs in a two-step reaction catalysed by the enzymes deoxyhypusine synthase (DHS) and deoxyhypusine hydroxylase.

docs.description:
From Swiss-Prot
Produces a 42-residue extracellular sporulation delaying protein (SDP) that collapses the proton motive force (probably both the membrane potential and pH gradient) across the cell membrane, which leads to autolysis; may form a proton channel (PubMed:22469514). Induces the lysis of other B.subtilis cells that have not entered the sporulation pathway, inducing cannibalism to provide a source of nutrients to support sporulation, and at the same time delaying commitment to the energetically expensive and irreversible onset of sporulation (PubMed:12817086). Addition of SDP to liquid cultures halts growth, leads to increased cell permeability and eventually cell lysis in a significant subset of the population, although some cells survive and resume growth after a lag period (PubMed:20805502). Effects of SDP are irreversible within 10 minutes (PubMed:22469514). Addition of SDP to solid cultures induces killing, it is much more effective than SKF (AC O31422) (PubMed:20805502). Has antibiotic action against Gram-positive Firmicutes (L.acidophilus, M.megaterium, P.polymyxa, S.aureus, S.epidermidis) but not Actinobacteria M.luteus or Gram-negative P.aeruginosa or K.pneumoniae (PubMed:20805502, PubMed:22469514). SDP induces expression of the sdpR-sdpI operon (PubMed:12817086). Its maturation is dependent on SdpA and SdpB. Also functions as a ligand, binds to SdpI triggering a signal transduction cascade that protects the cell against the toxic effects of its own SDP.

From PMID:25788514 on "slow porins" in Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Acinetobacter species -

...Organisms such as P. aeruginosa or Acinetobacter species do not produce classical E. coli-type trimeric porins that provide a fast influx of small drugs. The major nonspecific porin in these organisms is a homolog of E. coli OmpA, and its major function is structural, that is, to connect the OM to the underlying peptidoglycan (178). The porin function is produced by the alternative folding of only a small fraction of the protein (perhaps 2% of the population) to produce 16 transmembrane beta-strands, and we proposed to call this class of porins �slow porins,� in order to distinguish them from the classical trimeric porins, in which every molecule produces an open channel (179, 180). Because the number of open channels is small, OM permeability is very low, and beta-lactams cross the OM of P. aeruginosa at a rate 100 times lower than that for the E. coli OM (181, 182). Because of this slow permeation through slow porins, the endogenous RND system MexAB-OprM can compete well with the influx of hydrophilic beta-lactams as well as other antibiotics (Fig. 1). 

P. aeruginosa strains with over-expression of OprD gene showed high sensitivity to carbapenems family antibiotics (PMID:25644798)

The outer membrane porin protein D (OprD), a specialized channel-forming protein, responsible for uptake of beta-lactam antibiotics, was identified as sialoglycoprotein.  OprD(-Sias) interacts with beta-lactam antibiotics more than OprD(+Sias) as demonstrated by surface plasmon resonance study. Lyposome-swelling assay further exhibited that antibiotics have more capability to penetrate through OprD(-Sias) purified from four clinical isolates of PA (PMID:24643970)

docs.description:
This subsystem encodes a gene cluster associated with resistance against fatty-acid synthase II (FAS-II) antibiotics in Mycobacterium tuberculosis H37Rv. 

M. tuberculosis possesses an extremely lipid-rich cell wall. The key components of this outer envelope are mycolic acids. Mycolic acids are the product of two fatty-acid synthase systems present in mycobacteria: mammalian-type fatty-acid synthase I (FAS-I) (Smith et al., 2003) and bacterial-type fatty-acid synthase II (FAS-II) (Takayama et al., 2005; White et al., 2005).

Quote from PMID:24100560 (paper on Rv0241c): "Rv0241c or HtdX was first identified in the mycobacterial membrane-associated fraction (Gu et al., 2003) and was eventually identified in the mRNA pool when cultured in the presence of several FAS-II drugs (Boshoff et al., 2004). Recent work on heterologous expression of HtdX has shown that it can participate in the yeast mitochondrial fatty-acid synthetic pathway (Gurvitz et al., 2009) but can only restore the dehydratase activity in Escherichia coli (Sacco et al., 2010). This R-specific beta-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydratase is hypothesized to be involved in an alternative or intermediate fatty-acid synthetic pathway required for antibiotic resistance (Kikuchi & Kusaka, 1983; Boshoff et al., 2004; Sacco et al., 2010). Based on the genomic arrangement in Mycobacteria and STRING functional protein association networks, a putative fatty-acid metabolizing operon was identified showing two genes Rv0241c (HtdX) and Rv0242c (FabG4) could be involved in the pathway (Gurvitz, 2009; Dutta et al., 2011). FabG4, which has been characterized recently, is an NADH-dependent�beta-ketoacyl CoA reductase (Dutta et al., 2011, 2013)�

docs.description: Succinate-ubiquinone oxidoreductase (SQR) as part of the trichloroacetic acid cycle and menaquinol-fumarate oxidoreductase (QFR) used for anaerobic respiration by Escherichia coli are structurally and functionally related membrane-bound enzyme complexes. Each enzyme complex is composed of four distinct subunits. Both enzyme complexes contain a catalytic domain composed of a subunit with a covalently bound flavin cofactor, the dicarboxylate binding site, and an iron-sulfur subunit which contains three distinct iron-sulfur clusters. The catalytic domain is bound to the cytoplasmic membrane by two hydrophobic membrane anchor subunits that also form the site(s) for interaction with quinones. The membrane domain of E. coli SQR is also the site where the heme b556 is located.

docs.description:
The glucuronides are then mostly excreted out of the body via the bile ducts into the intestine, through apocrine secretions, and through the bladder into the urinary tract. The conjugated compounds are typically much more water soluble than the respective aglycones and are often biochemically and biologically inactive. The glucuronidation and excretion of such compounds have thus often been described as detoxification.
  In the intestine and on the skin, large populations of commensal and symbiotic microorganisms have access to the diverse glucuronides, and some have evolved the ability to metabolize these compounds. The enterobacterium Escherichia coli colonizes all known vertebrates. Most E. coli strains living in natural environments possess β-d-glucuronidase (EC 3.2.1.31) and are able to acquire glucuronides as nutrients. β-d-Glucuronidase is an intracellular hydrolase that catalyzes the hydrolysis of β-d-glucuronides within the cytoplasm of E. coli. The glycone released can then be used as a carbon source. Almost any aglycone conjugated in a hemiacetal linkage to the C-1 hydroxyl of glucuronate in the β-configuration can be cleaved by β-d-glucuronidase, except for some thio-β-d-glucuronides.
    Some strains of B. subtilis can use glucuronate and galacturonate as primary carbon sources. Polymethylgalacturonate, or pectin, is a constituent of plant cell walls and thus is found in the soil. Extracellular pectate lyases, produced by Erwinia chrysanthemi and many other bacteria, including B. subtilis, convert pectin into oligogalacturonate. Oligogalacturonate can be metabolized into D-galacturonate by enzymes produced by Erwinia sp. In addition, free galacturonate and glucuronate enter Escherichia coli and Erwinia sp. via the exuT transport system. 
  The uxuA, uxuB, uxaA, uxaB, and uxaC genes of E. coli and E. chrysanthemi encode enzymes that degrade intracellular galacturonate and glucuronate into 2-keto 3-deoxygluconate (KDG), which is further metabolized to pyruvate and 3-phosphoglyceraldehyde. The expression of these genes, including exuT, is negatively regulated by the exuR gene product in these organisms.
