notes:
Biotin biosynthesis.

Biotin (vitamin H) is an essential cofactor for a class of important metabolic enzymes, biotin carboxylases and decarboxylases (Perkins and Pero 2001). Biotin biosynthetic pathway is widespread among microorganisms. The well-studied systems of biotin biosynthesis from Escherichia coli, Bacillus subtils, and Bacillus sphaericus differ in the first step of biosynthesis. B. subtils and B. sphaericus use pimeloyl-CoA synthase encoded by the bioW gene to synthesize pimeloyl-CoA from pimelic acid. In E. coli, pimeloyl-CoA is synthesized from L-alanine and/or acetate via acetyl-CoA, instead of pimelic acid (Ifuku et al. 1994), and products of the bioC and bioH genes are required for the pimeloyl-CoA synthesis in E. coli (EC numbers do not assigned). The pathway from pimeloyl-CoA to biotin is similar in E. coli and bacilli and uses products of the bioF, bioD, bioA, and bioB genes. Genes encoding biotin transporters have not been identified in bacteria until recently.
The biotin operon of E. coli is negatively regulated by biotin and the bifunctional protein BirA (DeMoll 1994). The biotin-protein ligase BirA mediates biotinylation of acetyl-CoA carboxylase via a two-step reaction. Firstly, the adenylate of biotin is synthesized from substrates biotin and ATP and, at the second step, transferred to a unique lysine residue on carboxylase. When biotin is unclaimed, two generated BirA-biotinyl-5`-AMP monomers bind cooperatively to the bioO operator between the divergent bioA and bioBCDF operons and repress transcription in both directions. The BirA protein is composed of the N-terminal DNA-binding (D-b) domain containing a helix-turn-helix (HTH) structure, the central domain, and the C-terminal domain. The central catalytic domain contains the binding site for biotinyl-5`-AMP and also is required for transcriptional regulation (Kwon et al. 2000).
Using comparative genomics and phylogenetic analysis, the biotin biosynthetic pathway and the BirA regulon has been described in most available bacterial genomes (Rodionov et al., 2002). Based on analysis of co-occurrence of the biotin biosynthetic genes and bioY in complete genomes, as well as on the distribution of the BirA bining sites, it has been predicted that the transmembrane protein BioY is involved in biotin transport. Different non-orthologous substitutes of the bioC-coupled gene bioH from E. coli (named bioG, bioZ and bioK), observed in several genomes, possibly represent existence of different pathways for the pimeloyl-CoA biosynthesis. 

#1,2	birA: Biotin-protein ligase (EC 6.3.4.15) and Biotin operon repressor are encoded by the bifunctional protein BirA in E. coli and many other bacteria. The biotin-protein ligase domain is ubiquitous to almost all prokaryodes. In contrast, the N-terminal DNA-binding domain containing a helix-turn-helix structure (Biotin operon repressor domain) is not so widely distributed, showing that BirA-mediated regulation of transcription for the biotin synthesis genes is more-or-less facultative. The predicted BirA-binding sites are well-conserved among various eubacterial and archaeal genomes. Existence of N-terminal DNA-binding domain in BirA strictly correlates with presence of putative BirA-binding sites upstream of biotin operons (Rodionov et al., 2000, Genome Res. 12:1507).

#3,4,5,6 are widely-distributed genes required for the de novo biotin synthesis from pimeloyl-CoA precursor and form the most conserved part of the pathway. Among the genomes encoding the biotin biosynthetic pathway these genes are missing only in minimal number of species:
#3 (bioF): in Clostridia species, Aquifex, and two Corynebacteria species;
#4 (bioA): several Clostridia species and cyanobacteria,  
#5 (bioD): no missing
#6 (bioB): no missing

#7,8,9,10,11,12 constitute variants of the pimeloyl-CoA precursor synthesis. 

#7 (bioW): is functionally characterized in several Bacillus species where it is involved in direct synthesize of pimeloyl-CoA from pimelic acid.

#8,9 (bioC, bioH): In E. coli, pimeloyl-CoA is synthesized from L-alanine and/or acetate via acetyl-CoA, instead of  pimelic acid (Ifuku et al. 1994), and products of the bioC and bioH genes are required for the pimeloyl-CoA synthesis in E. coli. Exact biochemical functions of these two genes were not clear until recently. However, a recent analysis of BioH with a panel of hydrolase assays revealed a carboxylesterase activity with a preference for short acyl chain substrates (Sanishvili et al., 2003, J.Biol.Chem. 278:26039). For BioC, it is possesses S-adenosylmethionine binding motif and belongs to the methyltransferase superfamily.

The bioC-bioH gene pair is required for the synthesis of pimeloyl-CoA in E. coli. The bioC gene is widely distributed in bacteria, whereas bioH was not found in many bioC-containing bacterial genomes. Instead, we predict several non-orthologous gene displacements of bioH in some of these genomes. 

#8,10 (bioC, bioG): A possible non-orthologous displacement of bioH by another gene, named bioG, was detected by bioinformatic analysis in some proteobacteria, the CFB group of bacteria, and Fusobacterium (Rodionov et al., 2000, Genome Res. 12:1507). The bioG gene always forms an operon with bioC and other biotin synthesis genes in these genomes; furthermore, in Bacteroides fragilis there is a single gene encoding a fused protein BioC-BioG. Most gamma-proteobacteria except Pasteurellaeceae possess the bioC-bioH gene pair, whereas all Pasteurellaeceae have bioC-bioG. Notably, Neisseria meningitidis has both bioC-bioH and bioC-bioG gene pairs, and the latter likely has been acquired from Haemophilus influenzae or a closely related bacterium, as the respective genes are highly similar. The phylogenetic tree of the BioC family has a separate branch for the proteins associated with BioG.

#8,11 (bioC, bioK): Another bioC-linked gene, named bioK, was found in some cyanobacteria. The genomes of Synechococcus sp. and Prochlorococcus marinus contain the bioFKCDA operon and the bioB gene. Two other cyanobacteria, Synechocystis sp. and Nostoc sp., have all biotin biosynthetic genes except bioC and bioK. Therefore, they possibly use a different pathway for the pimeloyl-CoA synthesis.

#8,12 (bioC, bioZ): Another bioC-linked gene, named bioZ, was found in rhizobia (alpha-proteobacteria), where it is the last gene in the biotin biosynthesis operon. It was recently shown that the bioZ gene from the bioABFDZ operon of Mesorhizobium loti can complement bioH of E. coli (Sullivan et al. 2001). 

The observed diversity of enzymes for the first step of the biotin biosynthesis (pimeloyl-CoA synthesis) can reflect either frequent non-orthologous gene displacements, or possible use of different substrates for the biotin biosynthesis.

#13 (bioY): Based on analysis of co-occurrence of the biotin biosynthetic genes and bioY in complete genomes, the hypothetical transmembrane protein BioY was predicted to be involved in biotin transport  (Rodionov et al., 2000, Genome Res. 12:1507). bioY is widely distributed in bacteria and often clusters with genes of biotin metabolism. The homologs of BioY form a unique protein family  (InterPro entry IPR003784), and have no significant similarity with any gene of known function. Analysis of the BirA regulatory sites showed that bioY is always under regulation of the biotin repressor in the genomes containing a regulatory domain of BirA.

See "The Tricarballylate Utilization (tcuRABC) Genes of Salmonella enterica Serovar Typhimurium LT2",

by Lewis, Horswill Schwem, and Escalante-Semerena, J. Bact, Mar 2004, p 1629-1637


Here is the abstract:

The Tricarballylate utilization (tcuRABC) genes of Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium LT2.

Lewis JA, Horswill AR, Schwem BE, Escalante-Semerena JC.

Department of Bacteriology, University of Wisconsin--Madison, 53726-4087, USA.

The genes of Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium LT2 encoding functions needed for the utilization of tricarballylate as a carbon and energy source were identified and their locations in the chromosome were established. Three of the tricarballylate utilization (tcu) genes, tcuABC, are organized as an operon; a fourth gene, tcuR, is located immediately 5' to the tcuABC operon. The tcuABC operon and tcuR gene share the same direction of transcription but are independently transcribed. The tcuRABC genes are missing in the Escherichia coli K-12 chromosome. The tcuR gene is proposed to encode a regulatory protein needed for the expression of tcuABC. The tcuC gene is proposed to encode an integral membrane protein whose role is to transport tricarballylate across the cell membrane. tcuC function was sufficient to allow E. coli K-12 to grow on citrate (a tricarballylate analog) but not to allow growth of this bacterium on tricarballylate. E. coli K-12 carrying a plasmid with wild-type alleles of tcuABC grew on tricarballylate, suggesting that the functions of the TcuABC proteins were the only ones unique to S. enterica needed to catabolize tricarballylate. Analyses of the predicted amino acid sequences of the TcuAB proteins suggest that TcuA is a flavoprotein, and TcuB is likely anchored to the cell membrane and probably contains one or more Fe-S centers. The TcuB protein is proposed to work in concert with TcuA to oxidize tricarballylate to cis-aconitate, which is further catabolized via the Krebs cycle. The glyoxylate shunt is not required for growth of S. enterica on tricarballylate. A model for tricarballylate catabolism in S. enterica is proposed.

======  <<< Next Paper >>>   ====

Journal of Bacteriology, August 2006, p. 5479-5486, Vol. 188, No. 15

The FAD-Dependent Tricarballylate Dehydrogenase (TcuA) Enzyme of Salmonella enterica Converts Tricarballylate into cis-Aconitate{dagger}
Jeffrey A. Lewis and Jorge C. Escalante-Semerena

Tricarballylate is the causative agent of grass tetany, a ruminant disease characterized by acute magnesium deficiency. Tricarballylate toxicity has been attributed to its ability to chelate magnesium and to inhibit aconitase, a Krebs cycle enzyme. Neither the ruminant nor the normal rumen flora can catabolize tricarballylate to ameliorate its toxic effects. However, the gram-negative enterobacterium Salmonella enterica can use tricarballylate as a carbon and energy source, providing an opportunity to study the genes and enzymes required for tricarballylate catabolism. The tricarballylate utilization (tcu) genes are organized into two transcriptional units, i.e., tcuR and tcuABC. Here, we report the initial biochemical analysis of TcuA. TcuA catalyzed the oxidation of tricarballylate to cis-aconitate. The apparent Km of TcuA for tricarballylate was 3.8 � 0.4 mM, with a Vmax of 7.9 � 0.3 mM min�1, turnover number (kcat) of 6.7 x 10�2 s�1, and a catalytic efficiency (kcat/Km) of 17.8 M�1 s�1. Optimal activity was measured at pH 7.5 and 30�C. The enzyme was inactivated at 45�C. One mole of FAD was present per mole of TcuA. We propose a role for TcuB as an electron shuttle protein responsible for oxidizing FADH2 back to FAD in TcuA.


------------------------


TcuB exists in Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis SC-B67; the gene was just not called.
Hence, I have given it a variant of 0.  It actually has a variant of 1, once the gene is added.

docs.description:
The Acetyl-CoA Pathway is the major mechanism of CO2 and CO fixation under anaerobic conditions.It is characterized by the use of hydrogen as an electron donor and carbon dioxide as an electron acceptor to produce acetyl-CoA as the final product. This two step process begins with the reduction of a carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide.
The carbon dioxide that is reduced to a carbonyl group, via the carbon monoxide dehydrogenase, is combined with the methyl group to form acetyl-CoA. The acetyl-CoA synthase complex is responsible for this reaction. 
It couples the folate-mediated one-carbon (C1) metabolism to either CO2 reduction or acetate oxidation via acetyl-CoA.
is used in both the oxidative and reductive directions. Besides being used for energy production and autotrophic carbon assimilation in acetogens (Ljungdahl, 1994; Ragsdale, 1997; Drake et al., 2002), the Wood-Ljungdahl pathway is used for acetate catabolism by sulfate reducing bacteria (Schauder et al., 1988; Spormann and Thauer, 1988) and aceticlastic methanogens (Ferry, 1999) and for CO2 fixation by hydrogenotrophic methanogens (Stupperich et al., 1983; Ladapo and Whitman, 1990).
two molecules of CO2 are reduced to a methyl and a carbonyl group, and are joined with coenzyme A (CoA) to make acetyl-CoA. Acetyl-CoA is then incorporated into cell carbon or converted to acetyl phosphate, whose phosphoryl group is transferred to ADP to generate ATP and acetate, the main growth product of acetogenic bacteria

Dehalococcoides mccartyi was shown to have an incomplete Wood�Ljungdahl pathway. Lacking key enzymes for both C1 metabolism and CO2 reduction this organism cleaves acetyl-CoA to donate a methyl group for the production of methyl-tetrahydrofolate (CH3-THF) for methionine biosynthesis, representing an unconventional strategy for generating CH3-THF in organisms without methylene-tetrahydrofolate reductase. Carbon monoxide (CO) was found to accumulate as an obligate by-product from the acetyl-CoA cleavage because of the lack of a CO dehydrogenase. CO accumulation inhibits the sustainable growth and dechlorination of strain 195 maintained in pure cultures, but can be prevented by CO-metabolizing anaerobes that coexist with D. mccartyi, resulting in an unusual syntrophic association. We also found that this pathway incorporates exogenous formate to support serine biosynthesis.
PMID 24733917

corrinoid iron-sulfur protein (CFeSP) from Moorella thermoaceticum functions as a methyl carrier, The small subunit (33 kDa) contains cobalt in a corrinoid cofactor, and the large subunit (55 kDa) contains a [4Fe-4S] cluster. The cobalt center is methylated by methyltetrahydrofolate (CH3-H4folate) to form a methylcobalt intermediate and, subsequently, is demethylated by carbon monoxide dehydrogenase/acetyl-CoA synthase (CODH/ACS).

Archaeoglobus fulgidus: CO2 + 2 Fdred(Fe2+) + 2 H+ + CH3 - H4SPt + CoA <==> acetyl-CoA + H4SPt + 2 Fdox(Fe3+) + H2O where Fd is ferredoxin, and CH3-H4SPt and H4SPt denote N5-methyl-tetrahydrosarcinapterin and tetrahydrosarcinapterin, respectively.

Comparison http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20202935

docs.description: The TCS locus called prlS/R is a proline sensor-regulator. It encodes a hybrid histidine kinase (PrlS) with an unusual Na(+)/solute symporter N-terminal domain and a transcriptional regulator (belonging to the LuxR family) (PrlR). In vitro, Brucella spp. with a functional PrlR/S system form bacterial aggregates, which seems to be an adaptive response to a hypersaline environment, while a prlS/R mutant does not. We identified ionic strength as a possible signal sensed by this TCS. The absence of a functional PrlR/S system correlates with the lack of hypersaline-induced aggregation in particular marine Brucella spp.
docs.subsystem_name: PrlS-PrlR Two-Component Regulatory System of Brucella

docs.description:
Poly-gamma-glutamate (PGA), a natural polymer, is synthesized by several bacteria, one archaea and one eukaryote.  It is currently viewed as a potential new biodegradable material in the fields of foods, cosmetics, and medicine.  For example, Natto, traditional Japanese fermented food made from soybeans by Bacillus subtilis (formerly Bacillus natto), contains abundant DL -PGA, which consists of 50 � 80%  D- and 20 � 50% L-glutamate as a main component. 

Poly-gamma-glutamate is an unusual anionic polypeptide, in which glutamate is polymerized via the gamma-amide linkages, and thus needs be synthesized in a ribosome-independent manner. 

PGA has diverse functions that vary according to the species synthesizing it and their environment.  Soil bacteria (mostly from the genus Bacillus, but excluding B. anthracis) use released PGA for the sequestration of toxic metal ions, increasing their resistance to adverse environments (McLean et al., 1990).  PGA may also be a source of glutamate for bacteria in a starvation state during late stationary phase (Kimura et al., 2004a).  Planococcus halophilus, Sporosarcina halophila and Natrialba asiatica, the only archaea known to produce PGA, use it to decrease high local salt  concentrations, enabling them to survive in a hostile environment (Kandler et al., 1983; Hezayen et al., 2001).  Finally,   Cnidaria , animals armed with stringing cells called nematocysts, are the only eukaryotic organism known to produce PGA.  Cnidaria use these explosive organelles to capture prey, for locomotion and for defence (Weber, 1990), and large amounts of PGA trigger this explosion.  Thus, anchored PGA is a bacterial virulence factor, protecting the pathogen from the immune system, whereas released PGA may be a persistence factor � protecting the bacterium from its environment � or a storage element for carbon and nitrogen precursors or for energy (Schreier, 1993).  

References:

Candela T, Fouet A.  2006.  Poly-gamma-glutamate in bacteria. Mol Microbiol, 60(5):1091-8

Ashiuchi M, Nawa C, Kamei T, Song JJ, Hong SP, Sung MH, Soda K, Misono H.  2001. Physiological and biochemical characteristics of poly gamma-glutamate synthetase complex of Bacillus subtilis. Eur J Biochem. 2001 Oct;268(20):5321-8

Ashiuchi M, Soda K, Misono H.  1999. A poly-gamma-glutamate synthetic system of Bacillus subtilis IFO 3336: gene cloning and biochemical analysis of poly-gamma-glutamate produced by Escherichia coli clone cells. Biochem Biophys Res Commun, 263(1):6-12

Makino, S., Uchida, I., Terakado, N., Sasakawa, C. & Yoshikawa, M. (1989) Molecular characterization and protein analysis of the cap region which is essential for encapsulation in Bacillus anthracis. J. Bacteriol. 171, 722 � 730.

docs.description: Bacterial magnetosomes are membrane-enveloped, nanometer-sized crystals of magnetite (Fe3O4), which serve for magnetotactic navigation. Four major operons could be associated with magnetite biomineralization, The deletion of the mamAB operon results in the complete loss of magnetic particles, deletion of the conserved mms6, mamGFDC, and mamXY operons leads to severe defects in morphology, size and organization of magnetite crystals. The later seem to be responsible for the formation and content of vesicles formed of the magnetosome membrane (MM). The small hydrophobic MamGFDC proteins account for nearly 35% of all proteins associated with the MM.

ARCHIVE NOTES. MANY OF THEM ARE ALREADY OBSOLETE OR SIMPLY CAPTURES THE PROCESS OF SUBSYSTEM ENCODING ETC. THEY MAY BE AS WELL DELETED OR AT LEAST IGNORED FOR PRACTICAL PURPOSES.

INTRODUCTION IN THE CONTEXT OF NMPDR ORGANISMS
Fatty acid biosynthesis is one of the most conserved components of bacterial biosynthetic machinery, (for recent reviews see  eg(Campbell and Cronan 2001; Heath et al. 2002)). With a few exceptions (such as in Mycoplasmas) Fatty Acid Synthase (FAS) multienzyme complex is present in all bacteria and eukaryotes, but it is absent in archaea. Saturated and unsaturated fatty acids participate in a number of cellular processes, most importantly in building the cell envelope. Most of the FAS-related genes are indispensable for cell growth and survival, as demonstrated in a number of gene essentiality studies in model (E.coli, B.subtilis) and  pathogenic (H.influenzae, S.aureus, S.pneumoniase) bacteria.

Eukaryotic and bacterial FAS drive fundamentally the same sequence of biochemical transformations, although structurally they are highly divergent. In eukarytotic (non-dissociable) FAS I, most of the catalytic domains are encoded in one gigantic modular polypeptide chain, In a typical bacterial (dissociable) FAS II, individual components (enzymes and carrier proteins) are encoded by separate genes.  Most (but not all) of these components are clearly homologous to functional domains of eukaryotic FAS I.  

One of the unique bacterial enzymes, encoded by the gene fabI in many bacterial species is a proven target for popular antibiotics, such as triclosan.  Recently it was shown that enoyl-ACP-reductase in S. pneumoniae (�missing� a classic fabI), is encoded by a nonhomologous gene fabK. This discovery was made based on the analysis of the conserved chromosomal cluster, which contains most of the FAS genes in Streptococci. An experimental verification of this prediction was published in the independent study (Heath and Rock 2000).

FabK is very distantly related to FMN-dependent domain of eukaryotic FASI and is completely insensitive to the inhibitors of bacterial FabI, providing a rational for the known triclosan-resistance of S. pneumoniae and other bacteria with the same gene pattern. 

The FAS subsystem analysis for a set of NMPDR organisms allows us to predict/rationalize the triclosan sensistivity/resistance based on the presense of FabI/FabK forms, in most cases except for Vibrio ssp.

Vibrio ssp represent a case of an open problem. None of them have strong candidates for FabI, although they contain several paralogs with relatively low scores having other functional assignments. Most of them (except Vibrio parahaemolyticus) also do not have string FabK candidates. Additional analysis (a combination of bioinformatics and experiments) will be required to elucidate this aspect of FAS in Vibrio ssp.

Another conclusion about the phenotype can be made by considering the presence of one of the two described branching pathways; Unsaturated Fatty Acids (. Vibrio ssp are likely is capable of producing Unsaturated Fatty Acids (UFA) using the same two-step fabB/fabA branching pathway as E.coli. 

An alternative UFA branching pathway involving a universally conserved fabF gene and a relatively rare fabM gene was described in S.pneumoniae (Marrakchi et al. 2002), which does not have fabA/fabB homologs.  Remarkably, the discovery of fabM was also based on the evidence brought by genome context analysis (gene clustering, as discussed in (Osterman and Overbeek 2003)). This alternative UFA pathway is relatively rare, and it is apparently not present Staphylococci, Listeria and Campylobcater ssp. Genetics and enzymology of UFA synthesis these organisms remain to be explored.

REFERENCES:


Campbell, J. W. and J. E. Cronan, Jr. (2001). "Bacterial fatty acid biosynthesis: targets for antibacterial drug discovery." Annu Rev Microbiol 55: 305-32.
Heath, R. J. and C. O. Rock (2000). "A triclosan-resistant bacterial enzyme." Nature 406(6792): 145-6.
Heath, R. J., S. W. White and C. O. Rock (2002). "Inhibitors of fatty acid synthesis as antimicrobial chemotherapeutics." Appl Microbiol Biotechnol 58(6): 695-703.
Marrakchi, H., K. H. Choi and C. O. Rock (2002). "A New Mechanism for Anaerobic Unsaturated Fatty Acid Formation in Streptococcus pneumoniae." J Biol Chem 277(47): 44809-16.
Osterman, A. and R. Overbeek (2003). "Missing genes in metabolic pathways: a comparative genomics approach." Curr Opin Chem Biol 7(2): 238-51.

====================================================================
Variant codes:
Basic variants:
#1 as in E.coli, including FabI and UFAI (FabA/FabB)
#2 as in S.pneumoniae, including FabK and FabM-driven UFAII

Subvariants and hybrid (examples):
10: Variant #1 with 1 missing gene (as in Vibrio cholerae) (equivalent of 1.0)
11: Var.# 1 w/o UFA (as in campylobacter)
12: Hybrid of 1 and 2 (as in V.parahaem.): FabI with UFAI
112: Hybrid of 11 and 2: with both FabI and FabK
21; version of var2 etc

#201 - missing BC (as in Thermotoga and three moe genomes). See below for comments
Current classification does not reflect upon AcpS/PPT profiling

===============MISCELANEOUS NOTES========================
1. FabI-FabK-FabL:
- A variety of form in Enoyl-ACP-reductase. We all remember the story of "missing fabI" in S.pneumoniae, that we managed to predict a few months before the publication of C.Rock group in Nature,2000. This gene is now termed fabK. 
PROBLEM: homologs of fabK are present in many genomes, and not all of them are probably functional (for example yrpB in B.subtilis is claimed to be inactive by Heath et al, JBC 2000). IT SEEMS IMPORTANT TO ANALYZE THE WHOLE FAMILY and attempt to sort out paralogs. Clustering of fabK in several genomes shoudl be very helpful for this analysis. FabL (in B.subtilis) is another tough issue due to its confusing homology with FabG. 

2.Paralogs of FabG is another issue to address. More generally, the real task is to sort out genuine FAS from some polyketide synthases and other "variations of the theme". Requires case-by-case analysis.

3. Missing AcpS. Most notably in H.influenzae. Here we have a solid prediction, made more than a year ago, that a nonhomologous PPT (HI0152) functionally replaces acpS. This prediction likely holds in several other genomes with that pattern (see table). Evidence:
- homology with characterized PPTs involved in secondary metabolism (sfp in B.subtilis, yhhU in E.coli);
- experimental results in E.coli, where overexpression of yhhU compensated for acpS defficiency;
- essentiality of HI0152 in Mikelanos paper.
Somebody should make an experiemnt. although, in fact, it seems obvious.

4. Missing BC in four genomes (out of all bacteria I looked up so far). This is a bridging problem in this subsystem and in Biotin-dependent transcarboxylation in general. Genomes are: Thermotoga maritima. Fusobacetrium, Porphyromonas, adn Thermoanaerobacter (ALL ANAEROBES!). My working hypothesis for now is that BC is functionally replaced by pyruvate carboxyltransferase component (such as TM0128). That means that conversion of biotin to carboxy-biotin in the hypothesized tri-partite complex (PycB-BCCP-AccD/A: TM0128-TM0717-TM0716) occurs not from CO2 but from oxaloacatetate. This is a pretty radical conjecture and it must be experimentally verified (in progress).
Alternatives are possible:
- nonorthologous BC;
- spontaneous charging by saturating CO2 concentrations.


Miscellaneous problems:
acpS in PA - open problem
too many copies of fabG
fabL story seems strange: too close to fabG?
Controversy with fabK homologs in bacilli:
yrpB was shown to be inactive by Heath et al, JBC 2000,
although its close homolog ois the only plausible candidate for enoylACP-reductase in B.anthracis
FabZ is missing in a number of species (Mycobacteria, Chloroflex, etc). Use code 110


Miscellaneous notes:
Apparently Corynebacteria don's have FASII (only FASI). Mycobacteria have both (FabZ missing?).

docs.description: Photosynthetic (PS) organisms synthesize a variety of Mg-tetrapyrrols for light harvesting and energy-generating charge separation in PS reaction centers. Cyanobacteria, algae, and plants, which evolve oxygen as byproduct of photosynthesis, typically synthesize chlorophyll a, b, or c. Anoxygenic photosynthetic bacteria synthesize a variety of related tetrapyrrols: bacteriochlorophylls (Bchls) a and b, the most common types of bacteriochlorophyll, are main antenna and reaction center pigments in most purple bacteria. Green sulfur bacteria synthesize Bchls c, d, or e. In contrast to other Chls these can occur as more than one defined compound within a given organism (so called homologous mixtures). Components of such mixtures differ by the nature of side groups at C8 and C12 and the type of the esterified alcohol at C17 (farnesol, octadec-9-en-1-ol, hexadecanol, octadecanol maybe found in addition to more common phytol and geranylgeraniol). Bchl g, the sole pigment in Heliobacteriaceae is related to Bchl b. Chlorophylls c1, c2, c3 are used as accessory light-harvesting pigments in many algae. Only biosynthesis of Chl a and b, and Bchl a were included in this SS, since very little is known to date about biosynthetic pathways of all other (bacterio)chlorophylls. ============================== This subsystem incorporates the following AraCyc pathways: chlorophyllide a biosynthesis I: CHLOROPHYLL-SYN chlorophyll a biosynthesis I: PWY-5086 chlorophyll a biosynthesis II: PWY-5064 chlorophyll cycle: PWY-5068

Variant codes

 1 = organism is capable of biosynthesis of at least one type of of chlorophyll or bacteriochlorophyll
-1 = no (bacterio)chlorophyll biosynthesis can be asserted in an organism based on genomic data

Additional encoding of functional variants (after the dot) are as follows:

First digit � type of Mg-protoporphyrin IX monomethyl ester oxidative cyclase (ChlE) catalyzing the formation of the 5th, isocyclic ring:
1 = aerobic enzyme utilizing O2 as substrate
2 = anaerobic enzyme, utilizing H2O  (utilized by anoxygenic PS bacteria)
8 = notably, orthologs of both enzymes are present (e.g. in Synechocystis 6803)

Second digit after the dot � type of protochlorophyllide reductase present.  There are two mechanisms for reducing the double bond in the 4th ring of a protochlorophyllide: 
1 = light dependent enzyme (POR)
2 = light independent 3-subunit enzyme complex (ChlLNB)
8 = both mechanisms can be asserted in given organism (majority of photoautoptrophs: cyanos, gymnosperms, some anoxygenic photosynthetic bacteia)

Third digit (optional) � type of chlorophyll synthesized.  Only biosynthesis of Bchl a, Chl a, and Chl b have been analyzed, since very limited data are currently available on biosynthetic pathways of all other (bacterio)chlorophylls.
1 = Bacteriochlorophyll a present
2 = Chlorophyll a present
3 = Chlorophylls a and b present
4 = any other type of (B)Chls present (solely or in addition to mentioned above)

This is a cluster-based subsystem encoding proteins families (most of them hypothetical), which tend to co-localize with lipopolysaccharide biosynthesis genes lpxK (encoding tetraacyldisaccharide 4'-kinase) and kdtA (encoding 3-deoxy-D-manno-octulosonic-acid transferase) in Alphaproteobacteria.  In prokaryotes conserved clustering of genes on the chromosome often points to their functional association.  Hence, collection of hypothetical proteins in this Subsystem might help identify yet unknown enzymes involved in lipopolysaccharide biosynthesis in Alphaproteobacteria.

The inositol monophosphatase family protein is probably 3.1.3.45 (or some such)

docs.description:
Betaines, like carnitine are amino acid derivatives in which the nitrogen atom is fully methylated, i.e. they are quaternary ammonium compounds. 
Carnitine is an essential metabolite that enables intracellular transport of fatty acids and acetyl units.

Bacteria are able to metabolize this trimethylammonium compound in three different ways:

- Enterobacteriaceae are able to convert carnitine, via crotonobetaine, to gamma-butyrobetaine in the presence of C and N sources and under anaerobic conditions. This two-step pathway, including a L-(-)-carnitine dehydratase and the crotonobetaine reductase, is encoded by the cai genes. 
- Pseudomonas species, assimilate L-(-)-carnitine as sole source of carbon and nitrogen. The first catabolic step is catalysed by the L-(-)-carnitine dehydrogenase. 
- Acinetobacter species, degrade only the carbon backbone, with formation of trimethylamine. 
- Some bacteria are also able to metabolize the non-physiological D-(+)-carnitine, which results as a waste product in some chemical procedures for L-(-)-carnitine production based on the resolution of racemic carnitine.

notes:
Variant codes:

Only a handful of roles included in this SS are currently reflected in variant codes.
E.g. the presence of Ornithine decarboxylase (EC 4.1.1.17) has not been taken into account, since in many genomes it turned out to be all but impossible to disambiguate Ornithine/Arginine/Lysine decarboxylases based on sequence alone (clustering with a transporter doesn�t help either � these are very close in sequence as well) 

 1 = putrescine is produced via ArgDC + Agmatinase (AUH) 
 1? = same as above, but the source of agmatine is not clear (no ArgDC)
 2 = putrescine is produced via ArgDC + Agmatine deiminase (AIH) + N-carbamoylputrescine amidase (CPA)
 2? = same as above, but the source of agmatine is not clear (no ArgDC)
 3 = putrescine can be produced via both routes (ArgDC + AUH and ArgDC  + AIH + CPA) 
 3? = same as above, but the source of agmatine is not clear (no ArgDC)
 4 = ArgDC and Agmatine deiminase are present, but CPA is absent.  Instead, AIH is clustered with Putrescine carbamoyltransferase, PTC (and often with Carbamate kinase, CK), indicating it�s involvement in arginine catabolism for ATP generation (and not putrescine biosynthesis)
 5 = two routes can be asserted in a genome: ArgDC + AUH (for putrescine biosynthesis) and ArgDC + AIH + PTC + CK (for energy generation)
 7 = no ArgDC branch, de novo putrescine biosynthesis might potentially occur via Ornithine decarboxylase
 6 = no ArgDC branch, but putrescine/ornithine symporter is co-localized with Ornithine decarboxylase (like in some Shewanella) � uptake is the main source of putrescine?
 8.1 = no de novo putrescine biosynthesis, an organism depends on extracellular polyamines (polyamine transporter(s) can be asserted). No spermidine synthase.
 8.2 = no de novo putrescine biosynthesis, an organism depends on extracellular polyamines (polyamine transporter(s) can be asserted).  Spermidine synthase is present, apparently, only putrescine is being transported.
 9 = Spermidine synthase is present, but the source of putrescine is not clear: neither de novo biosynthesis, nor transport can be asserted (overannotation?). This hypothesis is partially supported by the publication from 1963, which demonstrated putrescine uptake by Mycobacteria (https://circle.ubc.ca/handle/2429/38628)
* a start  with any variant code indicates, that gene complement is incomplete, for example CPA or AIH appear missing in the AIH+CPA route (or the other member of the branch is overannotated??)

Open questions:

  1. S-adenosylmethionine decarboxylase is likely a missing gene in Corynebacteria and Mycobacteria, since Spermine synthase and 5'-methylthioadenosine nucleosidase can be asserted in these genomes
  2. In some Shewanellas both ArgDC-dependent routes (ArgDC + AUH and ArgDC  + AIH + CPA) are missing.  In spite the fact that they contain OrnDC, variant code #7 was not assigned.  The fact that putrescine/ornithine symporter is co-localized with Ornithine decarboxylase might indicate that  uptake (and not biosynthesis) is the main source of putrescine
  3. In some Burkholderias CPA is present, while AIH cannot be found.  Missing gene? A gap in genome sequence is apparent near CPA, but AIH could not be found via �edit empty cells� tool
docs.description:
Polyamines are essential and ancient small polycation metabolites required for cell growth and proliferation and are found in most if not all bacterial, fungal, animal and plant cells (Illingworth et al., 2003; Yoshida et al., 2004; Tabor & Tabor, 1985).  The most common polyamines are putrescine (1,4-diaminobutane) and spermidine; spermine is present largely in eukaryotes. In some microbial species (Vibrio, a number of archaea and thermophilic bacteria) the major polyamine is norspermidine.  The genes for norspermidine synthesis are present in the genomes of many members of the proteobacteria and of a few members of the deinococci, bacteroidetes, cyanobacteria, and gram-positive bacteria (Karatan et al., 2005)

Putrescine is synthesized from ornithine by ornithine decarboxylase (OrnDC) or from arginine by the sequential actions of (i) arginine decarboxylase and agmatinase (ArgDC+AUH)  or (ii) arginine decarboxylase, Agmatine deiminase and N-carbamoylputrescine amidase (ArgDC+AIH+CPA).  
In well studied organisms, such as E. coli, two types of ornithine decarboxylase and arginine decarboxylase can be distinguished: biodegradative (induced) and biosynthetic (constitutive) (Tabor and Tabor, 1985).  Extrapolation of these data has not been attempted for the majority of organisms in this SS.

Spermidine synthase (SPDS) synthesizes spermidine from putrescine by the addition of an aminopropyl group acquired from  decarboxylated S-adenosylmethionine formed by S-adenosyl-methionine decarboxylase (Woolridge, 1999). Similarly, spermine is formed from spermidine by spermine synthase  or spermidine synthase through addition of another aminopropyl group.  Spermidine and spermine can be further metabolized by acetylation (Casero et al., 1993).  In addition, uptake systems for putrescine, spermidine and spermine has been described for various microorganisms. In contrast to putrescine and spermidine, spermine is normally not present in media or under natural conditions.

Several widely distributed Polyamine transport systems have been characterized (Igarashi et al., 1999; Woolridge et al., 1997).  In the absence of polyamine biosynthetic pathways one or more polyamine transport systems is likely to be present � but in many cases potential gene candidates were not annotated as such: impossible to predict a transporter�s substrate based on sequence alone. 

Polyamine metabolism has been targeted for therapeutic or preventative intervention in the treatment of certain diseases, based on the observation of increased polyamine concentration in a variety of diseases and parasitic infections (reviewed in Wallace, et al., 2004).

See also related subsystems:  Arginine Putrescine and 4-aminobutyrate degradation;  Putrescine utilization cluster; Biofilm formation in Vibrio.

This Subsystem has been originally encoded by Ines Thiele (UCSD), whose excellent contribution we gratefully acknowledge.

References

Casero, R. A., Jr., and A. E. Pegg. 1993. Spermidine/spermine N1-acetyltransferase--the turning point in polyamine metabolism. Faseb J 7:653-61.

Igarashi K and Kashiwagi K. Polyamine Modulon in Escherichia coli: Genes Involved in the Stimulation of Cell Growth by Polyamines. J Biochem (Tokyo). 2006 Jan;139(1):11-6.

Igarashi, K., and K. Kashiwagi. 1999. Polyamine transport in bacteria and yeast. Biochem J 344 Pt 3:633-42.

Igarashi K., K. Itob , K.Kashiwagia.  Polyamine uptake systems in Escherichia coli. Res. Microbiol. 152 (2001) 271�278

Illingworth, C., M.J. Mayer, K. Elliott, C. Hanfrey, N.J. Walton, A.J. Michael. The diverse bacterial origins of the Arabidopsis polyamine biosynthetic pathway. FEBS Letters 549 (2003) 26-30

Ishii, I., H. Takada, K. Terao, T. Kakegawa, K. Igarashi, and S. Hirose. 1994. Decrease in spermidine content during logarithmic phase of cell growth delays spore formation of Bacillus subtilis. Cell Mol Biol (Noisy-le-grand) 40:925-31.

Karatan E, Duncan TR,  Watnick PI. 2005.  NspS, a predicted polyamine sensor, mediates activation of Vibrio cholerae biofilm formation by norspermidine. J Bacteriol, 187(21):7434-43.

Woolridge, D. P., N. Vazquez-Laslop, P. N. Markham, M. S. Chevalier, E. W. Gerner, and A. A. Neyfakh. 1997. Efflux of the natural polyamine spermidine facilitated by the Bacillus subtilis multidrug transporter Blt. J Biol Chem 272:8864-6.

5-Nitroimidazole-based antibiotics like Metronidazole (MTZ) are compounds extensively used for treating infections in humans and animals. They are administered as prodrugs, and their activation depends upon an anaerobic 1-electron reduction of the nitro group by a reduction pathway in the cells. Bacterial resistance toward these drugs is thought to be caused by decreased drug uptake and/or an altered reduction efficiency. One class of resistant strains, identified in Bacteroides, has been shown to carry Nim genes (NimA, -B, -C, -D, and -E), which encode for reductases that convert the nitro group on the antibiotic into a non-bactericidal amine.

PMID: 24448511
metronidazole resistance does occur in Bacteroides and has been mainly attributed to Nim proteins, a class of proteins with a suggested nitroreductase function.the data herein do not provide evidence for Nim proteins acting as nitroreductases using metronidazole as a substrate, because no correlation between Nim levels and levels of metronidazole resistance could be observed. Furthermore, no evidence was found that Nim proteins protect B. fragilis from metronidazole by sequestering the activated antibiotic
docs.subclass: Resistance to antibiotics and toxic compounds

docs.description: C-di-GMP, which is produced by diguanylate cyclases (DGC) and degraded by specific phosphodiesterases (PDEs)-is a ubiquitous second messenger in bacterial biofilm formation. notes:
Nishino, T & Ishida, Y Production of Dihydroxamate Siderophore Alcaligin by Alcaligenes xylosoxidans subsp. xylosoxidans. Agricultural and Biological Chemistry Vol.54 , No.7(1990)pp.1837-1839


Bordetella pertussis and Bordetella bronchiseptica utilize other siderophores, such as enterobactin (bfeR encodes an enterobactin-dependent positive regulator of bfeA transcription in these Bordetella species, fepA homologue required for utilization of exogenous ferric enterobactin), ferrichrome (6), desferrioxamine B (BfrA, homologous to Cir of Escherichia coli, IrgA of Vibrio cholerae, BfeA), and certain pyoverdins (bfrZ upstream region revealed the presence of two tightly linked genes, bupI and bupR. Both of these genes are located downstream from a Fur-binding sequence. BupI is homologous to Escherichia coli FecI and Pseudomonas putida PupI and belongs to the family of extracytoplasmic-function sigma factors involved in transcription of genes with extracytoplasmic functions. BupR is homologous to the FecR and PupR antisigma factors and is predicted to be localized in the inner membrane), to satisfy their iron requirement. Apart from these iron sources of microbial origin, eukaryotic host-derived iron sources, such as hemin and hemoglobin, are also readily assimilated by B. pertussis and B. bronchiseptica cells by way of a specific heme-iron transport system (bhuRSTUV genes restored heme utilization)

docs.description: DNA phosphorothioation(DNA sulfur modification) in the DNA backbone is a multi-enzymatic and highly coordinated process controlled by five dnd genes(dndB-E). This is a modification, where one of the non-bridging oxygen atoms in the phosphodiester bond linking DNA nucleotides is exchanged by sulphur in a sequence selective and stereo-specific manner.
notes: DNA degradation (Dnd) phenomenon during electrophoresis led eventually to the discovery of an unprecedented DNA sulfur modification.

docs.description:
Conserved cluster of Bacterial checkpoint controller protein DisA with di-adenylate cyclase activity, a hypothetical protein and Phosphoglucosamine mutase (EC 5.4.2.10). 

The octameric DisA protein complex has structurally linked nucleotide-binding and DNA-binding HhH domains and the nucleotide-binding domains are bound to a cyclic di-adenosine phosphate such that DisA is a specific di-adenylate cyclase. The di-adenylate cyclase activity is strongly suppressed by binding to branched DNA, but not to duplex or single-stranded DNA, suggesting a role for DisA as a monitor of the presence of stalled replication forks or recombination intermediates via DNA structure-modulated c-di-AMP synthesis. The resulting cyclic diadenosine phosphate, c-di-AMP, is reminiscent but distinct from c-di-GMP, a prokaryotic regulator of complex cellular processes. 

The the size of the "Uncharacterized secreted protein associated with spyDAC" is very variable.

The "Phosphoglucosamine mutase (EC 5.4.2.10)" catalyzes the interconversion of glucosamine-6-phosphate into glucosamine-1-phosphate, an essential step in the biosynthetic pathway leading to the formation of peptidoglycan precursor uridine 5'-diphospho-N-acetylglucosamine. Insertional glmM mutant of S. gordonii did not produce GlmM, and had a growth rate that was approximately half that of the wild type. Morphological analyses clearly indicated that the glmM mutation causes marked elongation of the streptococcal chains, enlargement of bacterial cells, and increased roughness of the bacterial cell surface. Furthermore, the glmM mutation reduces biofilm formation and increases sensitivity to penicillins.  Compared with the wild type glmM mutation resulted in increased sensitivity to PMN-dependent killing. GlmM may be required for synthesis of firm peptidoglycans for resistance to bacterial cell lysis.

docs.description:
Plastoquinone is an electron carrier of the photosynthetic electron transport chain. It is also a cofactor involved in the desaturation of phytoene in the synthesis of carotenoid, a photosynthetic pigment.
In cyanobacteria plastoquinone is synthesized by the pathway propsed by Sandre et al.,2012 (PMID: 22166075), as posted under the Illustration tab. It differs significantly from the plastoquinone biosynthetic pathway in plants, which is encoded in SS: "Plastoquinone biosynthesis in plants".  Only the first and the last steps of the cyanobacterial pathway are currently known, the rest are still unresolved 

From PMID:22166075:
"During evolution, cyanobacterial ancestors have apparently lost the ability to synthesize ubiquinone and replaced it with PQ-9. Phylogenetically, Slr0926 (PlqA) probably originated from bacterial 4-hydroxybenzoate prenyltransferases involved in ubiquinone biosynthesis, whereas plant HSTs may have evolved from a cyanobacterial homogentisate phytyltransferase for tocopherol biosynthesis. As shown in Figure 10, the use of 4-hydroxybenzoate as the prenyl acceptor necessitates further modifications at the aromatic ring such as decarboxylation, hydroxylation and two methylations to finally yield PQ-9. The Synechocystis sp. genome encodes homologues of the E. coli proteins UbiX/UbiD (decarboxylation), UbiH (hydroxylation) and UbiE (C-methylation) involved in the downstream reactions of UQ-8 biosynthesis. It is therefore very conceivable that the order of the reactions in cyanobacterial PQ-9 biosynthesis is similar to that in the course of UQ-8 biosynthesis in E. coli, with decarboxylation of 3-solanesyl-4-hydroxybenzoate and then hydroxylation preceding methylations of the aromatic ring at positions 2 and 3"
notes:
MSBM - 2-methyl-6-phytyl-1,4-benzoquinone/2-methyl-6-solanyl-1,4-benzoquinone methyltransferase (MPBM/MSBM), which catalyzes a key methylation step in both tocopherol and plastoquinone (PQ) synthesis. 
 VTE3 (vitamin E defective) locus, which encodes MPBM/MSBM in Arabidopsis, was isolated and characterized.
  In vitro enzyme assays confirmed that VTE3 is the plant functional equivalent of the previously characterized MPBM/MSBM (Sll0418) from Synechocystis sp PCC6803, although the two proteins are highly divergent in primary sequence. 
   Sll0418 orthologs are present in all fully sequenced cyanobacterial genomes, Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, and the diatom Thalassiosira pseudonana but absent from vascular and nonvascular plant databases.
Sll0418 orthologs are present in all fully sequenced cyanobacterial genomes, Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, and the diatom Thalassiosira pseudonana but absent from vascular and nonvascular plant databases. 
  VTE3 orthologs are present in all vascular and nonvascular plant databases and in C. reinhardtii but absent from cyanobacterial genomes. A comparison of protein amino acid sequences confirmed that Arabidopsis VTE3 is not an ortholog of the Synechocystis sp PCC 6803 MPBM/MSBM, because the two proteins share only 18% identity in their primary amino acid sequences. However, biochemical and genetic analyses showed that Arabidopsis VTE3 represents the functional equivalent of Synechocystis sp PCC 6803 MPBQ/MSBQ MT. This finding is quite interesting from an evolutionary perspective, because all other enzymes of the tocopherol pathway are highly conserved between higher plants and cyanobacteria.
    The finding indicates that, unlike Arabidopsis, functional redundancy exists for MPBM/MSBM  in Synechocystis sp PCC6803 and that this step in tocopherol and PQ synthesis has diverged significantly in cyanobacteria and plants( ref.#1). An Arabidopsis MPBM/MSBM was isolated and it was shown that it is the nonorthologous functional equivalent of its cyanobacterial counterpart. The Arabidopsis VTE3 gene encodes a protein and activity in tocopherol and PQ biosynthesis that are highly conserved in photosynthetic eukaryotes.

================References:=============================

1. Sadre R, Pfaff C, Buchkremer S. Plastoquinone-9 biosynthesis in cyanobacteria differs from that in plants and involves a novel 4-hydroxybenzoate solanesyltransferase. Biochem J. 2012 Mar 15;442(3):621-9. PMID: 22166075

2. DellaPenna D. Progress in the dissection and manipulation of vitamin E synthesis. Trends Plant Sci. 2005 Dec;10(12):574-9.PMID: 16290217;

3.Cheng, Z., Sattler, S., Maeda, H., Sakuragi, Y., Bryant, D.A., and DellaPenna, D. (2003). Highly divergent methyltransferases catalyze a conserved reaction in tocopherol and plastoquinone synthesis in cyanobacteria and photosynthetic eukaryotes. Plant Cell 15, 2343�2356; PMID: 14508009

4. N. A. Eckardt. Vitamin E-Defective Mutants of Arabidopsis Tell Tales of Convergent Evolution, PLANT CELL, October 1, 2003; 15(10): 2233 � 2235

docs.description:
Tetracyclines (TET) were discovered in the 1940s and exhibited activity against a wide range of microorganisms including gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, chlamydiae, mycoplasmas, rickettsiae, and protozoan parasites. The first tetracycline-resistant bacterium, Shigella dysenteriae, was isolated in 1953. It was in fact the inquiry into molecular mechanisms of TET resistance that opened up the entire field of antimicrobial resitance (ISBN 1-55581-329-1) 

Tetracycline resistance is most often due to the acquisition of new genes, which encode either (i) energy-dependent efflux of tetracyclines or (ii) a protein that protects bacterial ribosomes from the action of tetracyclines (Chopra and Roberts, 2001). Ribosomal protection proteins and TET efflux pumps are the two main mechanisms of TET resistance. In addition, a limited number of bacteria acquire resistance by mutations, which alter the permeability of the outer membrane porins and/or lipopolysaccharides in the outer membrane, change the regulation of innate efflux systems, or alter the 16S rRNA.  Reviewed in (Chopra and Roberts, 2001)

Over 50 types of TET resistant determinants have been described so far, and new ones are being reported. 
Dr. Stuart Levy (Tufts University) has initiated the clearinghouse for naming new TET genes. A new gene must have <79% amino acid identity with all previous characterized TET genes to be recorded.  A detailed up-to-date database is currently maintained by prof. Marilyn Roberts:  
http://faculty.washington.edu/marilynr/
http://faculty.washington.edu/marilynr/tetnomenclature.pdf

This Subsystems encodes all TET resistant mechanisms, published by May2016. See also related Subsystems:
-- Tetracycline resistance, ribosome protection type"
-- Tetracycline resistance, efflux systems type

notes:
Tetracycline resistance ABC-type efflux pump TetA(46)/TetB(46) [PMID:22941900] is in fact identical to the BmrCD transporter and is annotated in this database as such.  See Subsystem "Tetracycline resistance, all mechanisms" for details:

-- Heterodimeric efflux ABC transporter, multidrug resistance => BmrC subunit of BmrCD
-- Heterodimeric efflux ABC transporter, multidrug resistance => BmrD subunit of BmrCD
 ____________________________________________

Tetracycline resistance mechanisms were originally encoded in SEED by prof. Gary Olsen, whose contribution we gratefully acknowledge.  SS Notes from earlier SS version: 

TetM = Tn916, tetracycline resistance protein in Enterococcus

TetO was identified in Campylobacter coli

TetP was identified in Clostridium perfringens

TetQ was identified in Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron

TetW was identified in Butyrivibrio fibrisolvens.

OtrA was identified in Streptomyces rimosus
  It is a subset of "Ribosome protection-type tetracycline resistance related proteins"

Ribosome protection-type tetracycline resistance related proteins
  Unknown function
  Includes OtrA
  Paralogous to TetM etc.

Ribosome protection-type tetracycline resistance related proteins, group 2
  Unknown function, but clearly related to the OtrA and Tet genes

Translation elongation factor G is the molecule from which all of these members are derived.

Translation elongation factor G paralog is more similar to EF-G than are the other genes.  It is concentrated in a few phylogenetic groups

docs.description:
MprB/MprA is a two-component response regulator whose expression is required for entrance into and maintenance of persistent infection. Inactivation of this response regulator, Rv0981 (termed here mprA for mycobacterial persistence regulator), affected M. tuberculosis H37Rv growth in vivo in an organ- and infection stage-specific fashion. These results indicate that two-component systems are important for adaptation of the tubercle bacillus during stages of persistent infection (PMID: 11675502).  
MprAB is stress responsive and regulates the expression of numerous stress-responsive genes in M. tuberculosis, including sigma factors sigB and sigE in M. tuberculosis (PMID: 16513743)

References

Zahrt TC, Deretic V. 2006 Mycobacterium tuberculosis signal transduction system required for persistent infections. J Bacteriol. 2006 Mar;188(6):2134-43. PMID: 11675502

He H, Hovey R, Kane J, Singh V, Zahrt TC. 2006 MprAB is a stress-responsive two-component system that directly regulates expression of sigma factors SigB and SigE in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. J Bacteriol. 2006 Mar;188(6):2134-43. PMID: 16513743

docs.description:
This subsystem encodes a head-to-head fatty acid condensation biosynthetic pathway dependent on genes denoted as ole (for olefin biosynthesis). It was deciphered in a series of publications by Sukovich and colleagues (ref.2-3) and independently by Keasling group (ref.1).  The same cluster was independently predicted to be involved in biosynthesis of polyunsaturated fatty acids or related compounds by this database (see "Notes" section below)

Sukovich et al. (ref.3) tested experimentally selected microorganisms from the phyla Verucomicrobia, Planctomyces, Chloroflexi, Proteobacteria, and Actinobacteria and showed that they produce long-chain olefinic hydrocarbons. However, different species from the same genera sometimes lack the ole genes and fail to produce olefinic hydrocarbons. The type of olefins produced by different bacteria differed greatly with respect to the number of carbon-carbon double bonds. The greatest number of organisms surveyed biosynthesized a single long-chain olefin, 3,6,9,12,15,19,22,25,28-hentriacontanonaene, that contains nine double bonds (ref.3).

It was further proposed (ref.2) that these long-chain polyunsaturated compounds aid in adapting cells to a rapid drop in temperature, based on three observations. In S. oneidensis wild-type cells, the cellular concentration of polyunsaturated compounds increased significantly with decreasing growth temperature. Second, the oleABCD deletion strain showed a significantly longer lag phase than the wild-type strain when shifted to a lower temperature. Lastly, compound I has been identified in a significant number of bacteria isolated from cold environments (ref.2).  

    This observation is fully supported in this SS by the fact that the OLE operon often co-occurs and co-localizes with the pfaABCD(E) operon, controlling biosynthesis of eicosapentaenoic (EPA) and/or docosahexaenoic (DHA) omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids, important in bacterial cold adaptation

References

1.Beller HR, Goh EB, Keasling JD. 2010.  Genes involved in long-chain alkene biosynthesis in Micrococcus luteus.   Appl Environ Microbiol. 2010 Feb;76(4):1212-23. Epub 2009 Dec 28

2. Sukovich DJ, Seffernick JL, Richman JE, Hunt KA, Gralnick JA, Wackett LP.  Structure, function, and insights into the biosynthesis of a head-to-head hydrocarbon in Shewanella oneidensis strain MR-1. Appl Environ Microbiol. 2010 Jun;76(12):3842-9. Epub 2010 Apr 23

3. Sukovich DJ, Seffernick JL, Richman JE, Gralnick JA, Wackett LP. Widespread head-to-head hydrocarbon biosynthesis in bacteria and role of OleA.  Appl Environ Microbiol. 2010 Jun;76(12):3850-62. Epub 2010 Apr 23

notes:
Hypothesis for At1g52510 and AT4G12830: These Arabidopsis proteins are associated with some aspect of polyunsaturated fatty acids  metabolism in chloroplasts

OBSERVATIONS
Due to the fact that At1g52510 and AT4G12830 belong to a diverse family �Hydrolase, alpha/beta fold� family, annotation of their bacterial homologs was performed so as to keep groupings isofunctional. For that purpose different branches of the tree were assigned with different Functional Roles. The following two Prokaryotic subgroups appear to be the closest to At1g52510 and AT4G12830:

1. �Hydrolase, alpha/beta fold family protein, At1g52510/AT4G12830 homolog�
2. "Haloalkane dehalogenase-like protein" (OleB)

The OleB proteins (subgroup #2) were recently shown to be involved in olefin biosynthesis (ref. 1-3). 

It is likely, that function of the "Hydrolase, alpha/beta fold family protein, At1g52510/AT4G12830 homolog" (subgroup #1) is also associated with some aspect of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) metabolism, because:

(i) out of all bacterial homologs this small subgroup seems to have the highest homology with At1g52510 and AT4G12830.  It�s members occurs only in SOME cyanobacterial species. 

(ii) cyanobacteria are known to produce PUFAs - catalyzed by �classic� desaturases (not by Pfa enzymes), just like plants or other eukaryotes

(iii) members of the "Hydrolase, alpha/beta fold family protein, At1g52510/AT4G12830 homolog" family are absent from the genome of Thermosynechocus, which is known to lack highly unsaturated fatty acids in lipids and contains only one ∆9 desaturase in contrast with mesophilic cyano strains, (likely due to its thermic habitat, where membrane ﬂuidity is increased, and hence, FA desaturation is unnecessary).

It might be interesting to compare the pattern of the absence/presence of At1g52510/AT4G12830 homologs in different cyano genomes with the complement of various desaturases in each, which differs significantly among cyanos (see recent review by Chi et al.,2008: Comparative Analysis of Fatty Acid Desaturases in Cyanobacterial Genomes).  This comparison might help generate specific functional prediction for this subgroup of the At1g52510//AT4G12830 homologs. For example, �pathway of acyl-lipid desaturation for unicellular marine cyanobacteria Synechococcus and Prochlorococcus diﬀers from that of other cyanos� (according to Chi et al., 2008), and these are the strains that lack members of this protein subfamily. 

Gene clustering: Members if this subgroup are NOT involved in any conserved clustering, but this is common in cyanobacteria (even genes known to cluster in other taxa hardly ever cluster in these organisms)


===============  EARLIER PREDICTION (as of Feb 2010)m verified by others =======

This Subsystem encodes a hypothetical gene cluster, which includes a hydrolase of alpha/beta fold family, putative 3-oxoacyl-ACP synthase;  AMP-acid ligase/peptide synthase; and a hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase/isomerase family protein

We hypothesize that this putative operon might be involved in microbial biosynthesis of polyunsaturated fatty acids via anaerobic pathway (resembling polyketide synthesis).  This hypothesis is based on the observation, that this cluster often co-occurs (and in several cases is co-localized with) the pfaABCD(E) operon, controlling biosynthesis of eicosapentaenoic (EPA) and/or docosahexaenoic (DHA) omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (Yazawa, 1996; Tanaka et al., 1999; Metz et al., 2001) 

For additional info on the pfa operon see SS: "Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids synthesis"

References

Yazawa, K. 1996. Production of eicosapentaenoic acid from marine bacteria.  Lipids 31:S297�S300. 

Tanaka, M., A. Ueno, K. Kawasaki, I. Yumoto, S. Ohgiya, T. Hoshino, K. Ishizaki, H. Okuyama, and N. Morita. 1999. Isolation of clustered genes that are notably homologous to the eicosapentaenoic acid biosynthesis gene cluster from the docosahexaenoic acid-producing bacterium Vibrio marinus strain MP-1.  Biotechnol. Lett. 21:939�945.

Metz JG, Roessler P, Facciotti D, Levering C, Dittrich F, Lassner M, Valentine R, Lardizabal K, Domergue F, Yamada A, Yazawa K, Knauf V, Browse J.  2001.  Production of polyunsaturated fatty acids by polyketide synthases in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Science, 293(5528):290-3.

docs.description: Subunit composition of photosystem II (PSII) complex can be used as "quality control" of sorts for ORF calling algorithms used by different sequencing centers: from 34 - 36 transmembrane a-helices revealed in PSII via electron and X-ray crystallography (in plants and cyanobacteria respectively), at least 12�14 are attributed to low molecular mass proteins -- merely 25 to 60 amino acids in size, each containing a single trans-membrane span. These ORFs are often overlooked, even the ones stably clustered into operons in the majority of cyanobacterial genomes. The situation is especially bad in the genomes of Synechococcus elongatus PCC 7942, Crocosphaera watsonii WH 8501, Trichodesmium erythraeum IMS101, Anabaena variabilis ATCC 29413. Interestingly, two subunits (PsbU and PsbV) are missing �for real� from some cyanobacterial genomes indicating that some degree of plasticity may exist in the composition of PSII. Collectively, there are at least 18 and possibly more than 25 distinct subunits in PSII from cyanobacteria and plants, as compared to only three or four in the non-oxygenic bacterial photosynthetic reaction centers. The evolutionary source of most of these "additional" proteins is enigmatic, as they have no apparent homology to any other proteins in existing databases. However, some of the proteins in PSII have apparent homologies to each other, suggesting ancient gene duplications have played an important role in the development of the complex. This suggests that a period of remarkable evolutionary innovation took place when the ability to make oxygen was invented, leading to explosion in complexity of photosynthetic machinery. Cyanobacterial and eukaryotic PSII complexes are very close, differing in only a few subunits. This implies that nearly entire spectrum of PSII proteins had originated by the time the first plastid endosymbiosis occurred and has hardly changed since. Proteins annotated here as �Chlorophyll a(b) binding protein, photosystem II CP43 protein (PsbC) homolog� are not PSII subunits per ser. In the genera of prochlorophytes (including Prochloron, Prochlorothrix, and Prochlorococcus) lacking phycobilisomes, these proteins form light-harvesting antenna (binding both, chlorophyll a and chlorophyll b), while their homologs in cyanobacteria encode chlorophyll a binding protein IsiA, expressed exclusively under conditions of iron starvation. In addition, Nostoc PCC 7120 and Trichodesmium erythraeum contain multiple PsbC homologs of yet unknown function, while a few other species contain none. This protein family is closely related to the PSII chlorophyll-binding protein PsbC and � more distantly -- PsbB. Use "show clusters" to view this Subsystem - many PSII-related genes are beautifully clustered in various combinations. ============================== This subsystem covers protein complexes involved in a single AraCyc reaction: photosystem II: PSII-RXN ============================== References: 1. Jason Raymond, Robert E. Blankenship. 2004 The evolutionary development of the protein complement of Photosystem 2. Biochimica et Biophysica Acta 1655 (2004) 133� 139. 2. Shi LX, Schroder WP. 2004. The low molecular mass subunits of the photosynthetic supracomplex, photosystem II. Biochim Biophys Acta. 1608(2-3):75-96. 3. J. La Roche, G.W.M. Van Der Staay, F.Partensky, A.Ducret, R.Aebersold, R.Li , S.S.Golden , R. G. Hiller, P. M. Wrench, A. W. D. Larkum, And B. R. Green. 1996. Independent evolution of the prochlorophyte and green plant chlorophyll a/b light-harvesting proteins. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA Vol. 93, pp. 15244�15248.

notes:
Variants:   I have elected to just use 

acive: has the pathway, with the possible exception of PurK
likely: has most of the steps in the pathway
-1: does not have the pathway

PurK or equivalent is missing in nearly half of the genomes with the rest of the pathway.
PurS is otional.

===========================


I have been unable to find an IMP cyclohydrolase (EC 3.5.4.10) in the Sulfolobus or Pyrococcus genomes.

Two key papers relating to the last two steps in Archcaea are 

    "New class of IMP cyclohydrolases in Methanococcus jannaschii" by Graupner, Xu and White
    J. bact, March 2002, p 1471-1473 

and

    "A Methanocaldococcus jannaschii Archaeal signature gene encodes for a 
    5'-Formaminoimidazole-4-carboxamide-1-B-D-ribofuranosyl 5'-monophosphate synthetase"
        by Ownby, Xu and White, J. of Biological Chemistry, March, 2005, p. 10881-10887


PurK is missing in many genomes.

=================================================

I have added the 3 steps preceding the normal view of the pathway, and I see no evidence
of 6.3.4.7.    KEGG cites

       Reem, G.H. Enzymatic synthesis of 5'-phosphoribosylamine from
       ribose 5-phosphate and ammonia, an alternate first step in purine
       biosynthesis. J. Biol. Chem. 243 (1968) 5695-5701.

It is time for someone to reread that article and
try to figure out a sequence, or at least an organism for it.

==================================================================

purB is very strongly coupled via chromosomal clustering to a gene that is called
NP_415650.1,b1132,gi|16129095,ycfC  in E.coli K12.  This gene is annotated as an 
"Uncharacterized protein involved in purine metabolism" in a number of organisms,
although I have not yet located the reference standing behind the annotation.
===============================================================

I have found numerous duplicates of 

    Ribose-phosphate pyrophosphokinase (EC 2.7.6.1)

Some may not actually be this.  I started separating them out using trees, which
is not too difficult.  However, the alternative is that we have multiple forms
using different regulation.  Since the enzyme is directly related to several pathways
(at least the pentose phsphate shunt, as well as this pathway, and PRPP plays
a role in several others), I decided that I was probably looking at multiple
copies that had different regulation.
-------

 J Bacteriol. 2003 Sep;185(17):5200-9.Click here to read Click here to read Links

    Definition of a second Bacillus subtilis pur regulon comprising
    the pur and xpt-pbuX operons plus pbuG, nupG (yxjA), and pbuE
    (ydhL).

    Johansen LE, Nygaard P, Lassen C, Agers� Y, Saxild HH.


    In Bacillus subtilis expression of genes or operons encoding
    enzymes and other proteins involved in purine synthesis is
    affected by purine bases and nucleosides in the growth medium. The
    genes belonging to the PurR regulon (purR, purA, glyA, guaC, pbuO,
    pbuG, and the pur, yqhZ-folD, and xpt-pbuX operons) are controlled
    by the PurR repressor, which inhibits transcription
    initiation. Other genes are regulated by a less-well-described
    transcription termination mechanism that responds to the presence
    of hypoxanthine and guanine. The pur operon and the xpt-pbuX
    operon, which were studied here, are regulated by both
    mechanisms. We isolated two mutants resistant to 2-fluoroadenine
    in which the pur operon and the xpt-pbuX operon are expressed at
    increased levels in a PurR-independent manner. The mutations were
    caused by deletions that disrupted a potential transcription
    terminator structure located immediately upstream of the ydhL
    gene. The 5' part of the ydhL leader region contained a
    63-nucleotide (nt) sequence very similar to the 5' ends of the
    leaders of the pur and xpt-pbuX operons. Transcripts of these
    regions may form a common tandem stem-loop secondary
    structure. Two additional genes with potential leader regions
    containing the 63-nt sequence are pbuG, encoding a
    hypoxanthine-guanine transporter, and yxjA, which was shown to
    encode a purine nucleoside transporter and is renamed
    nupG. Transcriptional lacZ fusions and mutations in the 63-nt
    sequence encoding the possible secondary structures provided
    evidence that expression of the pur and xpt-pbuX operons and
    expression of the ydhL, nupG, and pbuG genes are regulated by a
    common mechanism. The new pur regulon is designated the XptR
    regulon. Except for ydhL, the operons and genes were negatively
    regulated by hypoxanthine and guanine. ydhL was positively
    regulated. The derived amino acid sequence encoded by ydhL (now
    called pbuE) is similar to the amino acid sequences of metabolite
    efflux pumps. When overexpressed, PbuE lowers the sensitivity to
    purine analogs. Indirect evidence indicated that PbuE decreases
    the size of the internal pool of hypoxanthine. This explains why
    the hypoxanthine- and guanine-regulated genes are expressed at
    elevated levels in a mutant that overexpresses pbuE.

    PMID: 12923093

===========  REGULATION VIA PurR =======================

glyA                  fig|224308.1.peg.3697  Serine hydroxymethyltransferase (EC 2.1.2.1)

===========

 J Bacteriol. 1999 Jun;181(12):3810-5.

    A role for a highly conserved protein of unknown function in regulation of Bacillus subtilis purA by the purine repressor.

    Rappu P, Shin BS, Zalkin H, M�nts�l� P.

 
    Regulation of the purine biosynthetic gene purA was examined by using a transcriptional fusion to a luciferase reporter gene. Transcription was repressed about 10-fold by the addition of adenine and increased approximately 4.5-fold by the addition of guanosine. This regulation is mediated by a purine repressor (PurR). In a purR mutant, basal expression was increased 10-fold, and there was no further stimulation by guanosine or repression by adenine. An open reading frame, yabJ, immediately downstream from purR was found to have a role in the repression of purA by adenine. Repression by adenine was perturbed in a purR+ yabJ mutant, although guanosine regulation was retained. Mutations in the PurR PRPP binding motif abolished guanosine regulation in the yabJ mutant. Thus, PRPP appears to be required for upregulation by guanosine. The amino acid sequence of YabJ is homologous to the YER057c/YjgF protein family of unknown function.

    PMID: 10368157

=============

Note in the following paper an assertion that PurR functions in Streptococcus:

J Bacteriol. 2003 Jan;185(1):359-70.

    Transcriptional regulation and signature patterns revealed by microarray analyses of Streptococcus pneumoniae R6 challenged with sublethal concentrations of translation inhibitors.
    Ng WL, Kazmierczak KM, Robertson GT, Gilmour R, Winkler ME.

    The effects of sublethal concentrations of four different classes of translation inhibitors (puromycin, tetracycline, chloramphenicol, and erythromycin) on global transcription patterns of Streptococcus pneumoniae R6 were determined by microarray analyses. Consistent with the general mode of action of these inhibitors, relative transcript levels of genes that encode ribosomal proteins and translation factors or that mediate tRNA charging and amino acid biosynthesis increased or decreased, respectively. Transcription of the heat shock regulon was induced only by puromycin or streptomycin treatment, which lead to truncation or mistranslation, respectively, but not by other antibiotics that block translation, transcription, or amino acid charging of tRNA. In contrast, relative transcript amounts of certain genes involved in transport, cellular processes, energy metabolism, and purine nucleotide (pur) biosynthesis were changed by different translation inhibitors. In particular, transcript amounts from a pur gene cluster and from purine uptake and salvage genes were significantly elevated by several translation inhibitors, but not by antibiotics that target other cellular processes. Northern blotting confirmed increased transcript amounts from part of the pur gene cluster in cells challenged by translation inhibitors and revealed the presence of a 10-kb transcript. Purine metabolism genes were negatively regulated by a homologue of the PurR regulatory protein, and full derepression in a DeltapurR mutant depended on optimal translation. Unexpectedly, hierarchical clustering of the microarray data distinguished among the global transcription patterns caused by antibiotics that inhibit different steps in the translation cycle. Together, these results show that there is extensive control of transcript amounts by translation in S. pneumoniae, especially for de novo purine nucleotide biosynthesis. In addition, these global transcription patterns form a signature that can be used to classify the mode of action and potential mechanism of new translation inhibitors.

    PMID: 12486074 

=====================

Note that in Lactococcus PurR activates expression.  Hence, I am changing my general annotation to just mention regulation: activation or repression will need to be studied carefully over a set of organisms.

J Bacteriol. 1998 Aug;180(15):3907-16.

    A transcriptional activator, homologous to the Bacillus subtilis PurR repressor, is required for expression of purine biosynthetic genes in Lactococcus lactis.

    Kilstrup M, Martinussen J.

    A purR::pGh9:ISS1 mutant of Lactococcus lactis was obtained following transposon mutagenesis of strain MG1363 and selection for purine auxotrophs. After determination of the nucleotide sequence and deduction of the purR reading frame, the PurR product was found to be highly similar to the purR-encoded repressor from Bacillus subtilis. The wild-type purR gene complemented the purine auxotrophy of a purR::ISS1 mutant, and it was shown that the purR::ISS1 mutation lowered the level of transcription from the purine-regulated L. lactis purD promoter. In a parallel study on the regulation of purC and purD expression in L. lactis (M. Kilstrup, S. G. Jessing, S. B. Wichmand-Jorgensen, M. Madsen, and D. Nilsson, J. Bacteriol. 180:3900-3906, 1998), we identified regions (PurBox sequences: AWWWCCGAACWWT) upstream of the promoters with a central G residue at exactly position -76 relative to the transcriptional start site. The PurBox sequences were found to be required for high-level promoter activity and purine regulation. We identified a PurBox sequence overlapping the -35 region of the L. lactis purR promoter and found, by studies of a purR-lacLM fusion plasmid, that purR is autoregulated. Because of the high degree of similarity of the PurR proteins from B. subtilis and L. lactis, we looked for PurBox sequences in the promoter regions of the PurR-regulated genes in B. subtilis and identified a perfectly matching PurBox sequence in the purA promoter region and slightly degenerate PurBox-like sequences in the promoter regions for the pur operon and the purR gene. Interestingly, the PurBox in the pur operon of B. subtilis is located almost identically, with respect to the promoter, to the PurBox sequences located in front of purC and purD in L. lactis. We present a hypothesis to explain how an ancestral PurR protein in B. subtilis could have evolved from an activator of the pur operon into a repressor which regulates transcription initiation from the same pur promoter by using the same PurR binding site and a similar response toward its effectors.

    PMID: 9683488

docs.description:
Acyl-CoA thioesterase II is an Acyl-CoA thioesterase that is very different from Acyl-CoA thioesterase in both sequence and structure. Its precise role is not fully known, but it seems specific for short to medium length 3-hyroxy acyl chains (perhaps 3-hydroxybutyric acid to 3-hydroxydecanoic acid). It has been proposed that it is present to purify the pool of acyl-CoA.

Mycobacteria and relatives seem to have a large number quite similar paralogs.

It has a few distant paralogs, which might be associated with the synthesis of particular compounds.

docs.description: Bis-(3'-5')-cyclic-di-guanosine monophosphate (c-di-GMP) is a bacterial signalling molecule produced by diguanylate cyclases (DGC, carrying GGDEF domains) and degraded by specific phosphodiesterases (PDE, carrying EAL domains). c-di-GMP has been shown to be involved in the regulation of metabolic processes, cell differentiation, and modulation of the cell surface properties of microorganisms. More specifically, intracellular levels of c-di-GMP have been shown to regulate the formation of rugose colony morphology, intracellular aggregation, exopolysaccharide synthesis, biofilm formation, and motility in several species.

docs.description: The bacterial catabolism of steroids has importants as a potential means of producing bioactive steroids from natural, low-cost sterols such as β-sitosterol and cholesterol. A pathway responsible for the aerobic degradation of the latter via 4-androstene-3,17-dione (AD) and 3-hydroxy-9,10-seconandrost-1,3,5(10)-triene-9,17-dione (3-HSA) may be pieced together from biochemical and genetic studies in diverse bacteria. In some Mycobacterium and Rhodococcus species, the aliphatic side chain at C17 is removed via a process similar to β-oxidation involving progressively shorter carboxylic acids. In these strains, 3-ketosteroid Δ1-dehydrogenase (KSTD) and 3-ketosteroid 9α-hydroxylase catalyze the opening of ring B and aromatization of ring A to yield 3-HSA. The subsequent degradation of 3-HSA to 9,17-dioxo-1,2,3,4,10,19-hexanorandrostan-5-oic acid (DOHNAA) via oxygenolytic cleavage of ring A is specified by the tes genes in the testosterone-degrading strain Comamonas testosteroni TA441. In Rhodococcus equi, the propionate moiety of DOHNAA is removed via β-oxidation. Many of the genes involved in steroid catabolism have yet to be identified, and many of the pathway enzymes are poorly characterized, particularly those involved in degrading the bicycloalkanone originating from rings C and D.
notes:
Cholesterol is an important nutrient during chronic Mycobacterium infection. 

Deletion of the igr locus resulted in a profound growth defect in the presence of cholesterol. However, growth inhibition did not have an effect on the cells� ability to make ATP. The mutant cannot fully metabolize cholesterol, resulting in the build-up of a toxic metabolite, while cells are able to fully oxidize glycerol and glucose through unrelated metabolic pathways.

docs.description:
MarC is an inner membrane protein with six predicted transmembrane domains. MarC is not involved in multiple antibiotic resistance (PMID:17954692), as it was previously believed

MarC, YchE and YhgN are paralogs in E. coli. Neither a marC single deletion mutant nor a triple marC ychE yhgN deletion mutant shows a difference in susceptibility to various antibiotics compared to wild type. Overexpression of MarC also has no effect on antibiotic susceptibility (PMID:17954692).

References

McDermott PF, McMurry LM, Podglajen I, Dzink-Fox JL, Schneiders T, Draper MP, Levy SB. 2008. The marC gene of Escherichia coli is not involved in multiple antibiotic resistance. Antimicrob Agents Chemother. 2008 Jan;52(1):382-3. PMID:17954692
