notes:
Alanine racemase (EC 5.1.1.1)

Alanine racemase is required by most bacteria to make D-alanine for the cell wall.  This activity is called biosynthetic alanine racemase, and is often constitutive.
Alanine racemase can also be used to convert L-alanine to D-alanine, which is the substrate for the alanine dehydrogenase pathway of alanine utilization for nitrogen and/or carbon.  This activity is sometimes called catabolic alanine racemase, and expression may be regulated.
The two types are enzymatically identical, differing only in regulation.  Therefore I have converted them to a single "function", and included a comment regarding the direction.  There is a huge legacy of incorrect attributions of the role.


Cryptic alanine racemase
This enzyme was described in Bacillus subtilis.  A single amino acid replacement in the sequence is sufficient for it to provide sufficient alanine racemase activity for cell growth.  The natural substrate is unknown.


Serine racemase
Related to alanine racemase.  The only example that I know an experimental identification is for vancomycin resistance.


Methionine racemase (EC 5.1.1.2)
The activity has been described in a number of organisms including Chromobacterium violaceum and Bacillus subtilis (Ochi K, Kandala JC, Freese E.  1981.  Initiation of Bacillus subtilis sporulation by the stringent response to partial amino acid deprivation. J. Biol. Chem. 256: 6866-6875. PMID: 6113248).  I cannot find any known sequence.  I wonder if this might be the same enzyme that is annotated as Alanine racemase, and which is adjacent to "D-amino acid dehydrogenase small subunit (EC 1.4.99.1)".


Glutamate racemase (EC 5.1.1.3)
No cofactor requirement.


Aspartate racemase (EC 5.1.1.13)
Related to glutamate racemase.  No cofactor requirement.  Very few experimentally verified organisms.  Almost certainly overextended.


Amino acid racemase RacX
Related to glutamate/aspartate family, but these genes are almost certainly not for aspartate.  The gene is implicated in promoting the dispersal of biofilms in Bacillus subtilis.

docs.description: Stxs (also known as Vero toxins, and previously as Shiga-like toxins) are a group of bacterial AB5 protein toxins of about 70 kDa that inhibit protein synthesis in sensitive eukaryotic cells. Protein synthesis is blocked by the Stxs through the removal of an adenine residue from the 28S rRNA of the 60S ribosome. This N-glycosidase activity of the toxin resides in the A subunit. The pentamer of identical B subunits mediates toxin binding to the cellular receptor globotriaosylceramide (Gb3). Additional commonalities between the Stx groups are that the subunit genes are encoded in an operon with the A subunit gene 5� to that of the B subunit, that the stx operon is usually found within the sequence for an inducible, lysogenic, lambda-like bacteriophage, and that the toxins utilize a retrograde pathway to reach the cytoplasm. Differences between the two toxin groups include the fact that the genes for stx/stx1a are repressed by Fur when high levels of iron are present, and that E. coli strains that encode stx2 are epidemiologically linked to more severe disease than those that carry stx1.
notes:
Shiga toxin (Stx) is one of the most potent bacterial toxins known. Stx is found in Shigella dysenteriae 1 and in some serogroups of Escherichia coli (called Stx1 in E. coli). In addition to or instead of Stx1, some E. coli strains produce a second type of Stx, Stx2, that has the same mode of action as Stx/Stx1 but that is antigenically distinct. Because subtypes of each toxin have been identified, the prototype toxin for each group is now designated Stx1a or Stx2a.
The Stxs traffic in a retrograde manner within the cell, such that the A subunit of the toxin reaches the cytosol only after the toxin moves from the endosome to the Golgi and then to the endoplasmic reticulum. In humans infected with Stx-producing E. coli (STEC), the most serious manifestation of the disease, the hemolytic uremic syndrome or HUS, is more often associated with strains that produce Stx2a rather than Stx1a, and that relative toxicity is replicated in mice and baboons. Stx1a and Stx2a also exhibit differences in cytotoxicity to various cell types, bind dissimilarly to receptor analogs or mimics, induce differential chemokine responses, and have several distinctive structural characteristics.
shiga toxins induce apoptosis and cleavage of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase via in vitro activation of caspases.

docs.description: Cytolethal distending toxin (CDT) is a bacterial toxin that initiates a eukaryotic cell cycle block at the G2 stage prior to mitosis. CDT is a secreted protein toxin produced by a number of Gram-negative disease-causing bacteria (Campylobacter species, Escherichia coli, Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi, Shigella dystenteriae, enterohepatic Helicobacter species, Actinobacillus actinomycetemcomitans - the cause of aggressive periodontitis, and Haemophilus ducreyi - the cause of chancroid). The functional toxin is composed of three proteins; CdtB potentiates a cascade leading to cell cycle block, and CdtA and CdtC function as dimeric subunits, which bind CdtB. The toxin is internalized via dynamin-dependent endocytosis into early and late endosomes. The CdtB subunit further transits to the Golgi complex, and is then retrogradely transported to the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). Translocation from the ER does not require the ER-associated degradation (ERAD) pathway, and protein unfolding. Here CdtB enters the nucleus and exhibits a DNase I-like activity that results in DNA double-strand breaks leading to cell cycle arrest, cellular distension, and cell death.
role_id: Cytolethal distending toxin subunit B, DNase I-like
role_name: Cytolethal distending toxin subunit B, DNase I-like
notes: Mutations in CdtABC that cause any of the three subunits to lose function prevent the bacterial cell from inducing cytotoxicity. The result of CDT activity can differ somewhat depending on the eukaryotic cell types affected. Epithelial cells, endothelial cells, and keratinocytes undergo G2 cell cycle arrest, cellular distension, and death; fibroblasts undergo G1 and G2 arrest, cellular distension, and death; and immune cells undergo G2 arrest followed by apoptosis. CDT contributes to pathogenesis by inhibiting both cellular and humoral immunity via apoptosis of immune response cells, and by generating necrosis of epithelial-type cells and fibroblasts involved in the repair of lesions produced by pathogens resulting in slow healing and production of disease symptoms. Thus, CDT may function as a virulence factor in pathogens that produce the toxin. H. hepaticus CDT has been shown to play a crucial role in promoting the progression of infectious hepatitis to pre-malignant, dysplastic lesions via activation of a pro-inflammatory NF-kappaB pathway and increased proliferation of hepatocytes, providing the first evidence that CDT has carcinogenic potential in vivo.

docs.description:
This Subsystem encodes a group of 36 FadD paralogous long-chain fatty-acid-CoA ligases that are present in every Mycobacterial genome. In general, it is next to impossible to distinguish these closely related proteins. This family is different, however, as it was addressed in 2 Nature publications and an ID number was assigned to each of the 36 members (FadD1 through FadD36).  They are interesting for several reason, but mostly because some of the 36 paralogs are not using CoA to activate fatty acids, but AMP instead! A solid publication in Nature claims this new biochemistry and lists specific paralogs (out of the 36) that are likely doing this (below).

Nature. 2004 Mar 25;428(6981):441-5.
Enzymic activation and transfer of fatty acids as acyl-adenylates in mycobacteria.
Trivedi OA, Arora P, Sridharan V, Tickoo R, Mohanty D, Gokhale RS.
Abstract
The metabolic repertoire in nature is augmented by generating hybrid metabolites from a limited set of gene products. In mycobacteria, several unique complex lipids are produced by the combined action of fatty acid synthases and polyketide synthases (PKSs), although it is not clear how the covalently sequestered biosynthetic intermediates are transferred from one enzymatic complex to another. Here we show that some of the 36 annotated fadD genes, located adjacent to the PKS genes in the Mycobacterium tuberculosis genome, constitute a new class of long-chain fatty acyl-AMP ligases (FAALs). These proteins activate long-chain fatty acids as acyl-adenylates, which are then transferred to the multifunctional PKSs for further chain extension. This mode of activation and transfer of fatty acids is contrary to the previously described universal mechanism involving the formation of acyl-coenzyme A thioesters. Similar mechanisms may operate in the biosynthesis of other lipid-containing metabolites and could have implications in engineering novel hybrid products.
PMID: 15042094

docs.description: Integrons are a cassette-based system that promotes the collection of antibiotics into genomic regions that are frequently associated with plasmids or transposable elements.  New elements are added, or elements are removed by site-specific recombination at coupling sequences by an associated integrase.  Generally the cassettes are "upstream" of the integrase gene.
notes:
The SEED does not currently have a Type 3 integron with the exception of a very bad version of Klebsiella pneumoniae MGH78578 (573.2).

docs.description:
The toxic solvents tetrachloroethene (PCE) and trichloroethene (TCE) have been widely used as degreasers and chemical feedstocks and present now the most common groundwater contaminants. A variety of microbe-mediated processes can catalyze conversion of these chlorinated solvents to harmless products. 
In aerobic environments, TCE, dichloroethenes (DCEs), and vinyl chloride (VC) are cometabolized by bacteria containing oxygenases, such as methane monooxygenase, toluene monooxygenase, and toluene dioxygenase, but PCE is not transformed. 
Anaerobic bacterial degradation of PCE proceeds readily via reductive dehalogenation to TCE, cis-1,2-DCE, VC, and ethene. In contaminated anaerobic environments, dechlorination often terminates at DCE or VC, but only rarely a complete dechlorination to ethene happens. Complete reductive dechlorination of PCE and TCE to ethene or ethane has also been observed in anaerobic enrichment cultures. Dehalococcoides ethenogenes, is able to completely dechlorinate PCE to ethene.
The dehalogenation reactions unique to dehalorespiring bacteria are catalyzed by reductive dehalogenases (RDases), many of which have been purified and characterized. The identified substrates of these enzymes are either chlorinated ethenes or substituted chloroaromatics. Chloroethene RDases are membrane bound, or anchored to the membrane through an accessory protein. All contain cobalamin and iron-sulfur clusters.
role_id: Tetrachloroethene reductive dehalogenase PceA membrane-bound subunit
Tetrachloroethene reductive dehalogenase TceA membrane-bound subunit
role_name: Tetrachloroethene reductive dehalogenase PceA membrane-bound subunit
Tetrachloroethene reductive dehalogenase TceA membrane-bound subunit
notes:
variant code  0 - work in progress,
variant code -1 - no functional variant,
variant code 1.xx - one type (pce or tce present),
variant code 2.xx - both types (pce and tce) present,
variant code 3.xx - both types present, but tce/mpd type,
variant code x.1x - number of pce pairs (A/B),
variant code x.x1 - number of tce pairs (A/B or A/mpd)
 
D. ethenogenes is more phylogenetically distant from the other dehalorespiring bacteria, it is a bacterium possessing a unique archaeon-like cell wall.

Three of the four known PCE-RDases dechlorinate PCE or TCE to cis-DCE, as would be expected from the metabolism of their parent organisms, but the PCE-RDase from D. ethenogenes accepts only PCE as a substrate, converting it to TCE. D. ethenogenes also contains a second enzyme, TCE-RDase, which is able to effect the complete dechorination of TCE, DCEs, and VC to ethene.
PCE-RDase of D. multivorans (AF022812) and the oCP-RDase of Desulfitobacterium dehalogenans (AF115542) share limited homology with the TCE-RDase of D. ethenogenes (AF228507).
--------------------------------------------------------

vinyl chloride reductive dehalogenase bvcA [Dehalococcoides sp. BAV1]is just one of the many Tetrachloroethene reductive dehalogenases
oCP-RDase of Desulfitobacterium dehalogenans (AF115542) is most similar to Tetrachloroethene reductive dehalogenase PceA in Desulfitobacterium sp. Y51, the only reductive dehalogenase in that organism
----------------------------------------------------------
N-terminal sequence of the mature protein determined by Edman degradation (KDVDD�) indicated the presence of a 42-amino-acid leader sequence.

fig|243164.3.peg.330 Dehalococcoides ethenogenes 195 DET0318 was reported to be a PCE-RDases?

docs.description:
The biosynthesis of pyrroloquinoline quinone (PQQ), a vitamin and redox cofactor of quinoprotein dehydrogenases, is facilitated by an unknown pathway that requires the expression of six genes, pqqA to -F.
  Pyrroloquinoline quinone [4,5-dihydro-4,5-dioxo-1H-pyrrolo-[2,3-f]quinoline-2,7,9-tricarboxylic acid (PQQ) is an aromatic, tricyclic ortho-quinone that serves as the redox cofactor for several bacterial dehydrogenases. Among the best known examples are methanol dehydrogenase and glucose dehydrogenase. PQQ belongs to the family of quinone cofactors that has been recognized as the third class of redox cofactors following pyridine nucleotide- and flavin-dependent cofactors.
 PQQ is derived from the two amino acids glutamate and tyrosine encoded in the precursor peptide PqqA. Five reactions are necessary to form this quinone cofactor:
 The first step of the whole pathway is the expression of PqqA as a precursor for PQQ. PqqA is recognised by PqqE, which links the C atoms from the glutamate and tyrosine to become C9 and C9a of the final product PQQ and, therefore, enables recognition and acceptance of the modified PqqA by PqqF. In step two PqqF afterwards cuts out the linked amino acids. The following Schiff base reaction is spontaneous, the following dioxygenation is catalysed by an unknown enzyme. To finally finish the product PqqC facilitates the last cyclization and oxidation steps.

Klebsiella pneumoniae needs six genes, seven genes are required in Methylobacterium extorquens (AM1), whereas Acinetobacter calcoaceticus requires only four genes for PQQ synthesis. Interestingly, the homologous enzymes of PqqF and PqqG of Methylobacterium extorquens strain AM1 are missing. Although, much is known about the enzymes that use PQQ as a cofactor relatively little is known about its biosynthesis.
 Basic reference:
Puehringer S, Metlitzky M, Schwarzenbacher R. The pyrroloquinoline quinone biosynthesis pathway revisited: a structural approach.  BMC Biochem. 2008 Mar 27;9:8. PMID: 18371220.

=======Variant codes:================

Variant code 1 - has all pathway functional roles, including dipeptidases similar to microsomal dipeptidases.
Variant code 2 - has PqqA-F (no MDP)
Variant code 3 - may use MDP instead of PqqF.
Variant code 4 - may use other peptidases that are not very similar to PqqF or MDP.
Variant code 5 - has PqqC/D protein fusion (see notes)
notes:
==========Enzymes of the pathway:==============

Klebsiella pneumoniae was initial model, switched to Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 b/c PqqA ORF wasn't called in K. pneumoniae.

    PqqA is 24-29 aa peptide, see refs. 4 and 7.  Not widely conserved, except for glu-X-X-X-tyr motif.  Some PqqA must be present for PQQ biosynthesis by this pathway.  Alternate pathway without using PqqA may exist in Methylobacterium extorquens (see ref. 11)  Orf is missing from Klebsiella pneumoniae and others.  Variant codes assume presence of PqqA in all instances of the subsystem (even if missing from column b/c orf not yet named).
 
    PqqB may be indirectly involved in transport across cytoplasmic membrane?  It may modify existing transport system for PQQ intermediate transport (ref. 13). It has been reported that a knock out of PqqB produces small amounts of PQQ in the cytosol [24] and that no PQQ is secreted into the periplasm. The amount of PQQ in the cytosol was in an equimolar relationship to PqqC. This finding indicates that PqqB is not directly required for PQQ biosynthesis but a carrier for PQQ and responsible for its transport across the plasma-membrane into the periplasm, where the bacterial dehydrogenases reside. Therefore, it is likely that PqqC needs an acceptor for PQQ because it can react with oxygen to generate free radicals [25]. PqqB could be required for the release of PQQ from PqqC and could act as PQQ-acceptor.

 PqqC catalyzes final step in PQQ biosynthesis. It is a cofactor-free oxygenase and is the signature  protein for this subsystem.  It oxidizes (8e-) intermediate (3a-(2-amino-2-carboxyethyl)-4,5-dioxo-4,5,6,7,8,9-hexahydroquinoline-7,9-dicarboxylic acid) to PQQ. See ref. 1b and 6.

 PqqC/D is a protein fusion that has been found to occur in Methylobacterium extorquens (see ref. 12).  Methylobacterium extorquens is not here (not in SEED), but Magnetospirillum magnetotacticum is an example of this subsystem variant. 

 PqqE has metal-binding motif, pqqE genes show some regions of identity to moa genes and nifB.  Provides cofactor for other component of subsystem.  See ref. 8.

 PqqF is endopeptidase, low specificity (many different peptidases may play necessary role), MDP can substitute (some similarity to eukaryotic microsomal/membrane peptidases)?  E. coli has ORF that may  play similar functional role when PqqABCD are heterologously expressed (GenBank X71917) (see ref. 8.) Hence, PqqF is most likely a metalloendopeptidase involved in processing of the tyrosine and glutamate of PqqA at R1�R3 with a Zinc centre in its active site. Its sequence has homologies (sequence identities of 15�20%) to insulin-degrading enzymes and protease III of Bacteria. 

PqqD seems like it should be in Ralstonia eutropha JMP134 and Pseudomonas fluorescens PfO-1, haven't found it yet.

docs.description: Free and protein-bound methionine residues are easily oxidized to methionine sulfoxides by various reactive oxygen species.  However, the oxidized methionines can be reduced back to methionine by repair enzymes, the methionine sulfoxide reductases (Msrs). Two distinct families of these enzymes, MsrA and MsrB, have evolved for stereospecific reduction of methionine sulfoxide residues in proteins (Kim, et al., 2008).  MsrA is specific for the reduction of the S-form of methionine sulfoxide, whereas MsrB is specific for the R-form. Msrs are present in most organisms in all three domains of life, but are absent in some hyperthermophiles, parasites, and organisms with minimal genomes.  They have been even found in anaerobic bacteria, where their presence may be due to the role in protein repair and antioxidant defense when transiently exposed to oxygen (Kim et al., 2008).  Msrs play a pivotal role in the repair of oxidatively damaged proteins and defend cells from oxidative stress. Therefore, these proteins are viewed as protein repair and antioxidant enzymes.  These enzymes have been implicated in regulation of physiological and pathological processes such as aging and neurodegenerative diseases.

notes:
Some members of the MsrA and MsrB protein families contain selenocysteine (Sec) residue in catalytic site in place of Cys.  Selenoprotein MsrBs are found in invertebrates and vertebrates, but not in bacteria or plants.  For example, among three mammalian methionine-R-sulfoxide reductases, MsrB1 is a Sec-containing protein, whereas MsrB2 and MsrB3 contain Cys in the active site.  In contrast, selenoprotein forms of MsrA are also found in bacteria (albeit very few) and in lower eukaryotes, including Syntrophobacter fumaroxidans MPOB, Alkaliphilus oremlandi OhILAs, Natranaerobius thermophilus JW/NM-WN-LF, and a unicellular green alga  Chlamydomonas reinhardtii. The reason why some enzymes evolve into selenoproteins if the Cys versions may be sufficient is not understood, and MsrA and MsrB might serve as an excellent system for addressing the question of why Sec is used in biological systems (Kim et al., 2008; Lee et al., 2008; Kim et al., 2005).  See also SS: Selenocysteine metabolism.

References

Kim HY, Zhang Y, Lee BC, Kim JR, Gladyshev VN.  2008. The selenoproteome of Clostridium sp. (also known as Alkaliphilus oremlandii) OhILAs: Characterization of anaerobic bacterial selenoprotein methionine sulfoxide reductase A. Proteins. 2008 Sep 2. [Epub ahead of print]

Lee TH, Kim HY.  2008.  An anaerobic bacterial MsrB model reveals catalytic mechanisms, advantages, and disadvantages provided by selenocysteine and cysteine in reduction of methionine-R-sulfoxide. Arch Biochem Biophys, 478(2):175-80. 

Kim HY, Gladyshev VN.  2005. Different catalytic mechanisms in mammalian selenocysteine- and cysteine-containing methionine-R-sulfoxide reductases. PLoS Biol, 3(12):e375.

docs.description:
Phenylacetic acid (PhAc) or phenylacetyl-CoA (PhAc-CoA) can be catabolized into general metabolites aerobically by a variety of gram-positive and gram-negative organisms. This central pathway is referred to as the PhAc-CoA catabolon core. The routes involved in the specific degradation of aromatic compounds into the PhAc or PhAc-CoA intermediates are called upper pathways of the PhAc-CoA catabolon (covered by other subsystems). This catabolon may be the first example of a hybrid pathway because, although it is aerobic, its catabolic intermediates (aryl-CoA derivatives) were, until recently, considered to be specific to the anaerobic catabolic pathways. The PhAc-CoA catabolon (core) was shown to contain (i) a transport system (PaaL and PaaM); (ii) a PhAc-activating enzyme, i.e. the PhAc-CoA ligase (PaaF); (iii) a ring-hydroxylating complex (PaaG, PaaH, PaaI, PaaJ and PaaK); (iv) a ring-opening protein (PaaN); (v) a β-oxidation-like system (PaaA, PaaB, PaaC and PaaE); and (vi) two regulatory proteins (PaaX and PaaY). Note, that the gene denomination is according to 
Luengo JM, Garc�a JL, Olivera ER. Mol Microbiol. 2001 Mar;39(6):1434-42.[PMID: 11260461]!

docs.description:
The characteristic shape of bacterial cells is mainly determined by the cell wall, the synthesis of which is orchestrated by penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs).  Rod-shaped bacteria have two distinct modes of cell wall synthesis, involved in cell elongation and cell division, which are believed to employ different sets of PBPs.  A long-held question has been how these different modes of growth are co-ordinated in space and time.  Recently key players in the elongation-division cycle of Bacillus subtilis have been identified (Claessen et al., 2008): the cell division protein EzrA, and a newly discovered protein GpsB  (for guiding PBP1 shuttling).  Mutations in these genes have a synthetic phenotype with defects in both cell division and cell elongation.  Furthermore, these phenotypes are tightly associated with disturbed localization of the major transglycosylase/transpeptidase of the cell, PBP1, which is involved in both  elongation and division, dynamically relocates from the  septum to the lateral wall during the cell cycle.  EzrA and GpsB have partially differentiated roles in the localization cycle of PBP1, with EzrA mainly promoting the recruitment of PBP1 to division sites, and GpsB facilitating its removal from the cell pole, after the completion of pole maturation (Claessen et al., 2008)

References

Claessen D, Emmins R, Hamoen LW, Daniel RA, Errington J, Edwards DH. 2008.  Control of the cell elongation-division cycle by shuttling of PBP1 protein in Bacillus subtilis.  Mol Microbiol, 68(4):1029-46

Tavares JR, de Souza RF, Meira GL, Gueiros-Filho FJ.  2008.  Cytological characterization of YpsB, a novel component of the Bacillus subtilis divisome. J Bacteriol, 190(21):7096-107

Ca�as C, Carrasco B, Ayora S, Alonso JC. 2008.  The RecU Holliday junction resolvase acts at early stages of homologous recombination. Nucleic Acids Res, 36(16):5242-9

McGregor N, Ayora S, Sedelnikova S, Carrasco B, Alonso JC, Thaw P, Rafferty J.  2005. The structure of Bacillus subtilis RecU Holliday junction resolvase and its role in substrate selection and sequence-specific cleavage. Structure, 13(9):1341-51.

Hypothetical protein in cluster with penicillin-binding protein PBP1, Listerial type
Hypothetical protein in cluster with penicillin-binding protein PBP1, Staphylococcal type
notes:
Notably, GpsB is tightly clustered with PBP1 in the majority of microorganisms where it occurs (in class Bacilli only), while EzrA is located in a separate locus.   This clustering of a group of proteins with the Penicillin-binding protein 1 (PBP1) � was what trigger the encoding of this Subsystem (SS), originally created by Ross Overbeek as a clustering-based SS: �CBSS-1307.2.peg.138�.

Remarkably, the PBP1//GpsB gene cluster also includes a number of proteins involved in chromosomal replication � Recombination protein RecU (required for proper segregation), Endonuclease III, Chromosome replication initiation protein DnaD (believed to be associated with primosome).  This functional association might point to a mechanism of coordination between chromosomal replication and the newly elucidated mechanism (PBP1/GspB/ErzA) of switching between the two modes of growth - cell elongation and cell division in Bacilli.   

A number of hypothetical proteins are associated with this cluster as well.   An interesting group of several related protein families (Hyp1, Hyp2, Hyp3), located immediately downstream of PBP1, all share homology within their C-termini, but differ wildly in the N-termini.

docs.description:
Pathogenic mycobacteria require type VII secretion (T7S) systems to transport virulence factors across their complex cell envelope. These bacteria have up to five of these systems, termed ESX-1 to ESX-5. This Subsystem encodes locus ESX-4 in all Mycobacterial genomes currently available in the SEED database.

ESAT-6, the 6 kDa early secreted protein from Mycobacterium tuberculosis, a potent T-cell antigen, is the prototype of a novel family of small proteins (ESX) of unknown function produced by several Gram(+) microorganisms.  The genome of Mycobacterium tuberculosis H37Rv has 23 ESX proteins, encoded by genes esxA through esxW, arranged in tandem pairs in 11 genomic loci, known as the ESX or ESAT-6 loci 

Export of ESAT-6 and related proteins requires a dedicated secretory apparatus, variously named ESAT-6- , SNM-, ESX-, or type VII secretion system (Bitter et al., 2009). Components of these secretion machinery are commonly encoded by clusters of genes co-localized with the ESAT-6 (ESX) family proteins. Out of the 11 ESX loci in the genome of M. tuberculosis, five (ESX-1 through ESX-5) include secretion system components.  Among them region 4 (Rv3444c-3450c) is believed to be ancestral.  Only the ESX-1 region (corresponding to RD1) is encoded in this SS, please see the following subsystems for loci ESX-2 through ESX-5:

ESAT-6 proteins secretion system in Firmicutes
ESAT-6 proteins secretion system in Mycobacteria (locus ESX-2)
    ...........
ESAT-6 proteins secretion system in Mycobacteria (locus ESX-5)

Conservative gene clusters containing proteins of the ESAT-6/Esx family and the components of the putative secretion system (SNM) have been identified in other Gram-positive pathogens as well, including Bacillus anthracis, Corynebacterium diptheriae and Listeria monocytogenes (Pallen, 2002).  In Staphylococcus aureus SNM  homologues are required for secretion of ESAT-6-like proteins (Burts et al ., 2005).  As with mycobacteria, loss of ESAT-6 secretion in S. aureus  correlates with reduced virulence.  While the role of these homologues in other Gram(+) species is not yet determined, mounting evidence suggests that this alternative secretion system will be important for virulence in many acid-fast and Gram-positive pathogens. 

Given its role in pathogenesis, it is curious that the ESAT-6/Esx/SNM secretion system also functions in non-pathogenic mycobacteria. M. smegmatis  has a genetic locus homologous to RD1 and is able to secrete ESAT-6 and CFP-10 homologues (Gey Van Pittius et al .,2001; Converse and Cox, 2005). Interestingly, mutations in M. smegmatis SNM homologues not only disrupt secretion of ESAT-6 and CFP-10 (Converse and Cox, 2005), but also result in increased conjugal DNA transfer (Flint et al ., 2004).  While the SNM pathway may have different functions in various bacteria, similarity of snm  genes suggests that the core mechanism of SNM secretion is conserved.

docs.description: Tricarboxylates are transported into Salmonella typhimurium by a binding protein-dependent transport system known as TctI. Genetically, it comprises three structural genes, tctCBA (where TctC is a periplasmic tricarboxylate-binding protein, TctA and TctB are inner membrane protein components), as well as a transcriptional regulator TctD and a sensor protein TctE. The transport system tctCBA is present in many other organisms. In some of them additional genes (i.g. in Pseudomonads coding for porins) have become parts of the operon and suggest a specialization for some particular substartes that have yet to be determined.

notes: Fractionation studies have demonstrated that the TctC periplasmic binding protein of Salmonella serovar Typhimurium interacts with both the outer and inner membranes and may funnel substrates from one membrane to the other. In Pseudomonas aerogenosa it was shown that the porin OpdH is tricarboxylate specific (cis-aconitate, isocitrate, citrate), even though no specific binding site were found within the channel.

docs.description:
Daptomycin (DAP), a fermentation product produced by Streptomyces roseosporus, is a cyclic lipopeptide antibiotic with potent bactericidal activity against most Gram-positive organisms including multiple antibiotic-resistant and -susceptible strains. It exerts its effect through cell membrane disruption (PMID: 17402833).  DAP appears to have a multifaceted effect on cell wall homeostasis that includes leakage of small ions, such as intracellular potassium, leading to loss of membrane potential, and by changes to the cell envelope ultrastructure leading to rapid cell death (PMID: 12878516).  Recent evidence strongly suggests that DAP inserts into the plasma membrane in a calcium-dependent manner and subsequently disrupts the functional integrity of the cell membrane, altering cell division. Fluorescence studies have shown that DAP forms membrane-associated oligomers on liposomes and bacterial cells, suggesting that it is phosphatidylglycerol (PG)-dependent oligomerization of DAP that contributes to its effectiveness in altering membrane homeostasis (PMID: 23114777)

Resistance mechanisms: 
The change in the bacterial cell envelope and biophysical properties of the cell membrane appear to play an important role in the interaction of daptomycin with the cell membrane, and it has been postulated that a more positively charged cell envelope �repels� the cationic daptomycin from the cell membrane, contributing to the development of resistance (PMID:17954690; PMID:21899450). A major factor in the cell-envelope charge is the phospholipid composition of the inner and outer cell-membrane leaflets, such as the negatively charged phospholipid cardiolipin and the positively charged amino derivatives of phosphatidylglycerol. 

In S. aureus, all daptomycin-nonsusceptible strains had a mutation in a phospholipid biosynthesis gene. This included mutations in the previously described mprF gene, L-O-lysylphosphatidylglycerol synthase (PMID:16723576, PMID:12878516), but also in other phospholipid biosynthesis genes, including cardiolipin synthase (cls2) and CDP-diacylglycerol-glycerol-3-phosphate 3-phosphatidyltransferase (pgsA). EM and lipid membrane composition analyses on two clinical pairs showed that the daptomycin-nonsusceptible strains had a thicker cell wall and an increase in membrane lysyl-phosphatidylglycerol (PMID:22238576, PMID:17954690; PMID:19289517)

In Enterococci the development of resistance to daptomycin, like the development of resistance in S. aureus, is associated with alterations in the cell envelope and biophysical properties of the cell membrane. However, the genes linked to these changes in enterococci appear to be different (PMID: 21899450; PMID:23114777) from those reported in S. aureus, with the exception of cardiolipin synthase, which has been implicated in DAP resistance in both taxa, albeit indirectly (PMID:21502617, PMID:23114777) 

Specifically in Enterococci DAP resistance has been linked to mutations in genes that alter the cell envelope stress response [liaFSR, where "lia" denotes lipid II cycle-interfering antibiotics protein](PMID:21899450) and changes in enzymes that directly affect phospholipid homeostasis, and these changes may alter membrane composition, such as glycerophosphoryl diester phosphodiesterase [GdpD] (PMID:21899450), as well as cardiolipin synthase (above)

docs.description:
The antituberculosis drugs Ethionamide (ETH) and Isoniazid = isonicotinylhydrazide (INH) (structural analogs) target InhA, an enzyme involved in mycolic acid biosynthesis. A notable distinction between the two drugs is the lack of cross-resistance in clinical isolates. This is due in part to the fact that INH requires catalase-peroxidase (KatG) activation, while and ETH has been shown to be activated by the gene products of ethA (which is regulated by ethR)

Isoniazid is a first-line medication in prevention and treatment of tuberculosis since 1950 (INH) and Ethionamide (1956) is a second-line antimycobacterial drug when resistance to or toxicity from first-line drugs has developed.

1. Target organisms:  Mycobacteria
2. Mechanism of action: disruption of mycolic acid synthesis (cell wall synthesis)
3. Molecular target: InhA 
4. Mechanism leading to resistance: inhibition of prodrug activation
5. Required for resistance: suppression or inhibition of expression of katG (INH), or
                            suppression or inhibition of expression of ethA (ETH), or
                            overexpession of ethR, or
                            suppression or inhibition of expression of ndh (INH), or
                            pathogen not growing, persistence
role_id: Monooxygenase EthA, implicated in activation of thiocarbamide-containing pro-drugs
role_name: Monooxygenase EthA, implicated in activation of thiocarbamide-containing pro-drugs
docs.subclass: Resistance to antibiotics and toxic compounds
notes:
Rv3855  = ethR = etaR   Transcriptional repressor EthR, TetR family
Rv3854c = ethA = etaA   Monooxygenase EthA, implicated in activation of thiocarbamide-containing pro-drugs
Rv1908c = katG          Catalase-peroxidase KatG (EC 1.11.1.21)
Rv1484  = inhA          Enoyl-[acyl-carrier-protein] reductase [NADH] (EC 1.3.1.9)

INH is classified as a prodrug, meaning that it must undergo in vivo transformation to an active form. katG-encoded catalase-peroxidase (KatG) performs this function in M. tuberculosis, and mutations in katG, particularly at codon 315, confer INH, but not ETH, resistance. The primary target of activated INH is an NADH-dependent enoyl-acyl carrier protein reductase, designated InhA. Mutations within the inhA structural gene or within the inhA promoter have been identified and are associated with both INH and ETH resistance. Missense mutations within the inhA structural gene cause INH resistance by reducing the NADH binding affinity of InhA and thus protecting the enzyme from INH inactivation. The inhA promoter mutations upregulate target expression, producing INH and ETH resistance via a drug titration mechanism. The structural similarity and shared molecular target of INH and ETH led to the hypothesis that ETH must, like INH, undergo cellular activation.

KatG couples the isonicotinic acyl (INH) with NADH to form isonicotinic acyl-NADH complex. This complex binds tightly to the enoyl-acyl carrier protein reductase known as InhA, thereby blocking the natural enoyl-AcpM substrate and the action of fatty acid synthase. This process inhibits the synthesis of mycolic acid.

EthA, a mono-oxygenase in Mycobacterium tuberculosis, binds NADH to form an adduct which inhibits InhA in the same way as isoniazid. Expression of the ethA gene is controlled by EthR, a transcriptional repressor. It is understood that improving ethA expression will increase the efficacy of ethionamide and so EthR inhibitors are of great interest to co-drug developers. The action may be through disruption of mycolic acid synthesis.

Ndh:  a small percentage (10%) of INH-resistant strains of M. tuberculosis are associated with gene Rv1854c, which encodes NADH dehydrogenase (EC 1.6.99.3) (PMID: 17294000).  Mutations in this gene reduce NADH oxidation causing an increase in NADH concentration and depletion of NAD(+). This prevents the peroxidation reactions required for the activation of INH, as well as the displacement of the NADH-isonicotinic acyl complex from InhA enzyme binding site (PMID: 17294000).

notes:
Mol Plant Microbe Interact. 2005 Jun;18(6):546-54.
    Characterization of the hrpF pathogenicity peninsula of Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae.
    Sugio A, Yang B, White FF.

    Department of Plant Pathology, Throckmorton Hall, Kansas State University, Manhattan 66506-5502, USA.

    The hrp gene cluster of Xanthomonas spp. contains genes for the assembly and function of a type III secretion system (TTSS). The hrpF genes reside in a region between hpaB and the right end of the hrp cluster. The region of the hrpF gene of Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae is bounded by two IS elements and also contains a homolog of hpaF of X. campestris pv. vesicatoria and two newly identified genes, hpa3 and hpa4. A comparison of the hrp gene clusters of different species of Xanthomonas revealed that the hrpF region is a constant yet more variable peninsula of the hrp pathogenicity island. Mutations in hpaF, hpa3, and hpa4 had no effect on virulence, whereas hrpF mutants were severely reduced in virulence on susceptible rice cultivars. The hrpF genes from X. campestris pv. vesicatoria, X. campestris pv. campestris, and X. axonopodis pv. citri each were capable of restoring virulence to the hrpF mutant of X. oryzae pv. oryzae. Correspondingly, none of the Xanthomonas pathovars with hrpF from X. oryzae pv. oryzae elicited a hypersensitive reaction in their respective hosts. Therefore, no evidence was found for hrpF as a host-specialization factor. In contrast to the loss of Bs3-dependent reactions by hrpF mutants of X. campestris pv. vesicatoria, hrpF mutants of X. oryzae pv. oryzae with either avrXa10 or avrXa7 elicited hypersensitive reactions in rice cultivars with the corresponding R genes. A double hrpFxoo-hpa1 mutant also elicited an Xa10-dependent resistance reaction. Thus, loss of hrpF, hpal, or both may reduce delivery or effectiveness of type III effectors. However, the mutations did not completely prevent the delivery of effectors from X. oryzae pv. oryzae into the host cells.

The enigma of carotenogenesis in the absence of light (e.g. in endosperm, a target for improving nutritional content) argued for Z-ISO as a pathway requirement.

docs.description:
Isoprenoids make up for more than 25000 biomolecules that include compounds like cholesterol, chlorophyll, vitamin A, ubiquinone, and natural rubber. The two essential building blocks of all isoprenoids, isopentenyl pyrophosphate (IPP) and dimethylallyl pyrophosphate (DMAPP), are ubiquitous in the three domains of life. In most eukaryotes and archaea, IPP and DMAPP are generated through the mevalonate pathway.
two novel variants have been found: 
1. deploying mevalonate-3-kinase and mevalonate-3-phosphate-5-kinase from Thermoplasma acidophilum
2. deploying mevalonate phosphate decarboxylase (MPD) and isopentenyl phosphate kinase (IPK) from Roseiflexus castenholzii and Haloferax volcanii

docs.description:
Tetracyclines (TET) were discovered in the 1940s and exhibited activity against a wide range of microorganisms including gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, chlamydiae, mycoplasmas, rickettsiae, and protozoan parasites. The first tetracycline-resistant bacterium, Shigella dysenteriae, was isolated in 1953. It was in fact the inquiry into molecular mechanisms of TET resistance that opened up the entire field of antimicrobial resitance (ISBN 1-55581-329-1) 

Tetracycline resistance is most often due to the acquisition of new genes, which encode either (i) energy-dependent efflux of tetracyclines or (ii) a protein that protects bacterial ribosomes from the action of tetracyclines (Chopra and Roberts, 2001). The latter have high sequence similarity with translation elongation factor EF-G and EG-Tu and have G+C% ranging from 32 and 40%, which is consistent with a gram-positive origin (Roberts, 2005).  Ribosomal protection proteins and TET efflux pumps are the two main mechanisms of TET resistance. In addition, a limited number of bacteria acquire resistance by mutations, which alter the permeability of the outer membrane porins and/or lipopolysaccharides in the outer membrane, change the regulation of innate efflux systems, or alter the 16S rRNA.  Reviewed in (Chopra and Roberts, 2001)

Nearly 50 types of TET resistant determinants have been described so far, and new ones are being reported. Dr. Stuart Levy from Tufts is the clearinghouse for naming new TET genes. A new gene must have <79% amino acid identity with all previous characterized TET genes to be recorded.  A detailed up-to-date database is maintained by prof. Marilyn Roberts:  http://faculty.washington.edu/marilynr/
http://faculty.washington.edu/marilynr/tetnomenclature.pdf

This Subsystem encodes only TET resistant determinants of the Ribosomal protection type. 
For tetracycline resistant determinants of other types (efflux pumps, drug modifying enzymes, others) see Subsystem "Tetracycline resistance, efflux and enzymatic types"

References:

Frontiers in Antibacterial Resistance: A Tribute to Stuart B. Levy Edited by David G. White, Michael N. Alekshun, and Patrick F. McDermot Washington, DC: ASM Press, 2005. ISBN 1-55581-329-1

Roberts MC. 2005. Update on acquired tetracycline resistance genes. FEMS Microbiol Lett, 245(2):195-203. PMID:15837373 

Chopra I, Roberts M. 2001. Tetracycline antibiotics: mode of action, applications, molecular biology, and epidemiology of bacterial resistance. Microbiol Mol Biol Rev, 65(2):232-60. PMID:11381101

docs.description:
This SS encodes a genetic locus (sbn) involved in biosynthesis of the siderophore staphylobactin in S. aureus.  Although this compound has not been structurally characterized yet, it�s involvement in virulence of S. aureus in a murine kidney abscess model has been clearly demonstrated (Dale et al., 2004).  It was also shown, that the sbnABCDEFGHI genes comprise an operon, and that iron (via Fur) regulates its transcription (Dale et al., 2004).  The functions of each gene product have not been determined yet. The involvement of the SirABC proteins in the staphylobactin import in S. aureus was shown experimentally (Dale, Sebulsky, and Heinrichs,  2004)

It was later suggested by (Challis GL. 2005), based on sequence similarity of the SbnE, SbnC, and SbnF genes with iucA, iucB, iucC respectively (controlling aerobactin biosynthesis in some virulent E. coli strain), that staphylobactin is related to a group of non-peptide siderophores, produced by nonribosomal peptide synthetases (NRPS)-independent mechanism.  Siderophores in this group include aerobactin, rhizobactin 1021, achromobactin, vibrioferrin, alcaligin, and desferrioxamine E (reviewed by Challis, 2005).  Such siderophores are assembled from alternating dicarboxylic acid and diamine or amino alcohol building blocks (which are nevertheless derived from amino acids) linked by amide or ester bonds (Challis GL. 2005)

notes:
Methanophenazine hydrogenase is a three subunit, membrane-bound [NiFe]-hydrogenase
that reduces methanophenazine with molecular hydrogen.  Historically this was the
"Methylviologen-reducing hydrogenase", or "non-F420 dehydrogenase".  This version is
found in Methanosarcinales and Archaeoglobales.  The other methanogens have a different
"Methylviologen-reducing hydrogenase" that has a polyferredoxin-containing subunit, not
a cytochrome b.

The small subunit is proteolytically cleaved after insertion of the metal center.

The reduced methanophenazine is used by heterodisulfide reductase to recycle the
CoM-S-S-CoB produced by Methyl-CoM reductase in the terminal step of methanogenesis.

Methanophenazine is membrane-bound due to its pentaprenyl side chain.

docs.description:
This SS captures various transport systems for malate and citrate (and also protein families that are functionally coupled with them - to improve annotation accuracy)

This SS was started originally to capture a gene cluster in B.subtilis (around fig|224308.1.peg.2360), which I thought could be generating precursors for poly-gamma-glutamate biosynthesis in Bacilli (see the corresponding SS for details), because it appeared to be able to generate lots of NH4 and carbon skeleton for glutamate.  However, looking deeper, it appears that this cluster is probably induced under low pH to combat acidic conditions and can lead to alkalization of the medium.

notes:
VARIANT CODES

For simplicity, Variant Codes reflect only the presence/absence the two routes of acetate dissimilation and/or assimilation: (i) the PAT+ACK pathway and (ii) Acetyl-coenzyme A synthetase (AMP-forming) as follows.  No other branches of this rich and variable node are currently reflected 

REFERENCES

J Bacteriol., 181(18):5885-8

7. Schreiner M.E., Eikmanns B.J. 2005. Pyruvate:quinone oxidoreductase from Corynebacterium glutamicum: purification and biochemical characterization. J Bact., 187(3):862-71
8. Starai V. J., Celic I., Cole R. N., Boeke J. D. and Escalante-Semerena J. C. (2002) Sir2-dependent activation of acetyl-CoA synthetase by deacetylation of active lysine. Science 298:2390�2392
9. Starai VJ, Escalante-Semerena JC.  2004. Identification of the protein acetyltransferase (Pat) enzyme that acetylates acetyl-CoA synthetase in Salmonella enterica.  J Mol Biol, 340(5):1005-12.

11. J. Ruff, K. Denger and A.M. Cook.  2003 Sulphoacetaldehyde acetyltransferase yields acetyl phosphate : purification from Alcaligenes defragrans and gene clusters in taurine degradation.  Biochem. J. (2003) 369, 275�285

13.  Hiroaki Taniai, Ken-ichiro Iida, et al. 2008. Concerted Action of Lactate Oxidase and Pyruvate Oxidase in Aerobic Growth of Streptococcus pneumoniae: Role of Lactate as an Energy Source. Journal of Bacteriology, 190(10): 3572-3579
docs.description:
Due to its complexity, the [Pyruvate / Acetyl-CoP / Acetyl-P / Acetate] node of central metabolism is encoded in 3 Subsystems (SS):  (i) Pyruvate:ferredoxin oxidoreductase, (ii) Fermentations: Mixed acid, and (iii) this SS: Pyruvate metabolism II: acetyl-CoA, acetogenesis from pyruvate.  The combination of VARIANT CODES of all three SSs provides a draft model of this node in each organism. Variant codes for this SSs (only) are explained below.

Decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA can occur oxidatively under aerobic conditions and nonoxidatively under anaerobic conditions. Oxidative decarboxylation, a reaction catalyzed by the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDH), functions primarily during respiratory metabolism, although some function may be retained during anaerobiosis (e.g. see Wagner et al., 2005).  During anaerobiosis various microorganisms  perform nonoxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA by means of pyruvate formate-lyase (PFL) or Pyruvate:ferredoxin (flavodoxin) oxidoreductase.  Pyruvate decarboxylase (EC 4.1.1.1) catalyzes  non-oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetaldehyde.  In addition, Pyruvate oxidases catalyze the following reactions:
Pyruvate -> Acetate + CO2 (EC 1.2.2.2) or 
Pyruvate -> Acetyl-P + CO2 + H2O2 (EC 1.2.2.3).  The roles of these enzymes in metabolism are not completely clear, and are currently under intense investigation (Abdel-Hamid et al., 2005; Schreiner et al., 2005; Schreiner et al., 2006).

ACETATE DISSIMILATION
In the majority of eubacteria acetate dissimilation is catalyzed by PTA-ACK pathway (Phosphate acetyltransferase + Acetate kinase). This reversible pathway can also assimilate acetate, but only when it is present in relatively large concentrations and predominantly functions in the catabolic direction in vivo. 
In all acetate-forming Archaea studied so far, the conversion of acetyl-CoA to acetate and the formation of ATP from ADP and phosphate are catalyzed by a single enzyme, an Acetyl-CoA synthetase (ADP-forming) (Brasen et al., 2001).  This enzyme represents a novel mechanism of ATP synthesis by the mechanism of substrate-level phosphorylation. ADP-forming acetyl-CoA synthetase is also present in the eukaryotic protists Entamoeba histolytica and Giardia lamblia, and homologous proteins have been found in the genomes of several bacteria (see in Musfeldt et al. 1999; Sanchez et al. 2000).  The metabolic function of these putative synthetases in bacteria remains to be demonstrated.  Similarity of these proteins with Protein acetyltransferase, regulating AMP-forming Acetyl-CoA synthetase (Starai et al., 2004) is intriguing. 

ACETATE ASSIMILATION
The catabolism of acetic acid in microorganisms involves condensation of this compound with CoA to form acetyl-CoA (Ac-CoA) in the presence of ATP and  Mg (Wolfe, 2005).  Acetyl-coenzyme A synthetase (AMP-forming, EC 6.2.1.1) catalyzes this process in eubacteria and archaea alike.  Although reversible in vitro, this reaction is irreversible in vivo due to the presence of intracellular pyrophosphatases (Wolfe, 2005) and serves as the main route of acetate assimilation.  The reversible PTA-ACK pathway can assimilate acetate as well, but only in relatively large concentrations.
Note that acetate ActP transporter (Gimenez et al., 2003) is often clustered with Acetyl-CoA synthetase (AMP-forming).  
Putative components of the Sir2-like protein acetylation/deacetylation regulatory system for Acetyl-CoA synthetase (Starai et al., 2002 & 2004) are also included in this SS:  (i) NAD-dependent protein deacetylase of SIR2 family, (ii) Protein acetyltransferase.  A different, NAD-independent acetylation/deacetylation regulatory system that uses AcsA as a substrate has been recently described in B. subtilis (Gardner et al., 2006).  It�s orthologs present in many Firmicutes are annotated here as: (iii) Acetyltransferase AcuA, acetyl-CoA synthetase inhibitor and (iv) NAD-independent protein deacetylase AcuC.  The role of AcuB located in the same cluster remains unclear (Gardner et al., 2006) 


OTHER Acetyl-P-FORMING ENZYMES
Acetyl-P is a central metabolite of vital importance for ATP generation via substrate phosphorylation, as well as several proposed energy-related and signaling roles (Wolfe, 2005).  In addition to PAT and ACK, other enzymes evolving acetyl~P are included in this SS as auxiliary functional roles (SSs encoding them in detail are given below): 

(i) Pyruvate oxidase (EC 1.2.3.3):  Pyr + O2 = Acetyl~P + CO2 + H2O2 (this SS) 
(ii) Xylulose-5-phosphate phosphoketolase (EC 4.1.2.9): Xylulose-5P + Pi <=> Acetyl~P + Glyceraldehyde-3P+ H2O. See SS: Fermentation: Lactate for details.
(iii) Fructose-6-phosphate phosphoketolase (EC 4.1.2.22): Fructose-6P + Pi <=> Acetyl~P Erythrose-4P + H2O. See SS: Fermentation: Lactate for details.
(iv) Sulfoacetaldehyde acetyltransferase (XSC, EC 2.3.3.15): Sulfoacetaldehyde + HPO4 = HSO3 + Acetyl~P (dissimilation of sulfonated compounds).  Enzyme is widespread in Proteobact and at least a couple Gram(+)s. In most organisms tested PAT is located in immediate vicinity of XSC 
(v)  Glycine reductase (EC 1.21.4.2)  -- present in some strict anaerobes (Arkowitz, Abeles, 1991).  It catalyzes acetyl~P production during reductive deamination of glycine, sarcosine, or betaine : 
Glycine + Pi + Thioredoxin = Acetyl~P+ NH3 + Thioredoxin disulfide. See SS: Glycine reductase, sarcosine reductase and betaine reductase.

In many organisms these enzymes are located in immediate vicinity of PAT or ACT, suggesting that Acetyl~P formed could be converted by PAT to Acetyl-CoA for anabolism or utilized as P-donor by ACK for ATP generation (Ruff et al., 2003; Wolfe, 2005).

LACTATE 2-MONOOXYDENASE (EC 1.13.12.4)
in S. pneumoniae, lactate oxidase converts lactate, usually regarded as a dead-end product of glucose metabolism in this organism, back to pyruvate, which is then subject to oxidation by pyruvate oxidase to form acetyl phosphate. Based on this finding, it was proposed that the two H2O2-producing oxidases (pyruvate and lactate) act in a concerted manner in the presence of oxygen to obtain a greater amount of energy from glucose than under anaerobiosis, with acetate rather than lactate being the final product of the system (Taniai, Iida, et al.2008)

This subsystem has been initially encoded by master:LienC_UCSD as Acetogenesis_from_Pyruvate.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The attached subsystem diagramm was provided by Jensen, R. and Bonner, C. and is covering the entire Aromatic Amino Acid Biosynthesis. It is NOT interactive.

Elements of the subsystem (details are below):

1. Aspartyl-tRNA(Asn) synthetase (an activity of the non-discriminating Aspartyl-tRNA synthetase) is the first step in the indirect charging of tRNA(Asn).
2-4.  Aspartyl-tRNA(Asn) amidotransferase subunit A, B and C are the "bacterial" second step of the indirect charging of tRNA(Asn).  See note above about "bacterial" Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase.  (The fact that no archaeon seems to have lost the heterodimeric Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase, even when the have Aspartyl-tRNA(Asn) amidotransferase, suggests that this latter enzyme is not fully funcitonal as a Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase in Archaea.)
5. Aspartyl-tRNA synthetase is in the subsystem because the non-discriminating form of the enzyme is essential to the pathway.
6. Asparaginyl-tRNA synthetase is in the subsystem because it makes the indirect pathway optional.
7. Glutaminyl-tRNA synthetase is in the subsystem because its absence makes the amidotransferase essential.


Details:

Among Bacteria, the GatCAB heterotrimeric enzyme seems to have both Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase and Aspartyl-tRNA(Asn) amidotransferase activities, even if there is no non-discriminating aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase.  This can be used for amino acid biosynthesis, not just tRNA charging.  (The original paper describing indirect charging in Bacillis subtilis called it a biosynthetic pathway. [Wilcox, M, and Nirenberg, M.  1968.  Transfer RNA as a cofactor coupling amino acid synthesis with that of protein.  Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 61: 229-326; also note Griffiths, E, and Bayley, S. T.  1969.  Properties of transfer ribonucleic acid and aminoacyl transfer ribonucleic acid synthetases from an extremely halophilic bacterium.  Biochemistry 8: 541-551].)

The assignments to eukaryotic Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase subunit C is a guess based on extensive PSI-BLAST searches.


Distinguishing the "discriminating" and "non-discriminating" Glu-tRNA(Glu) and Asp-tRNA(Asp) synthetases is imprecise (to put it mildly).  In principle, having a non-discriminating synthetase, without the amidotransferase is lethal, as it makes "mischarged" tRNA, but does not convert it to the correct amino acid.  Because a non-discriminating synthetase really has two activities, that is how I am annotating them:

   Discriminating Aspartyl-tRNA synthetase = Aspartyl-tRNA synthetase (EC 6.1.1.12)
   Non-discriminating Aspartyl-tRNA synthetase = Aspartyl-tRNA synthetase (EC 6.1.1.12); Aspartyl-tRNA(Asn) synthetase
   Discriminating Glutamyl-tRNA synthetase = Glutamyl-tRNA synthetase (EC 6.1.1.17)
   Non-discriminating Glutamyl-tRNA synthetase = Glutamyl-tRNA synthetase (EC 6.1.1.17); Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) synthetase

For the time being, assignment to non-discriminating type has been very conservative, in most cases, only when no direct charging enzyme is present, and there is strong evidence for the appropriate amidotransferase.  The problem is that there are a remarkable number of genomes in which there are two Glutamyl-tRNA synthetase genes, at least one of which must be non-discriminating, but there is no obvious criterion for choosing which.


Organellar enzymes have not been distinguished.  Mitochondtria and chloroplasts mostly use the indirect charging of tRNA(Gln), and direct charging of tRNA(Asn).


Organism-specific notes:

AsnRS
Arabidopsis AsnRS is not evident

###############################
LITERATURE

docs.description:
Quoted from PubMed:22046172 (van Hoek et al., 2011) -
"The first macrolide, erythromycin A, was discovered in the early 1950s (McGuire et al., 1952). The main structural component of this molecule is a large lactone ring to which amino and/or neutral sugars are attached by glycosidic bonds.
    Macrolides have a similar mode of antibacterial action and comparable antibacterial spectra as two other antibiotic classes, i.e., lincosamides and streptogramins B. Consequently, these antibiotics, although chemically distinct, have been grouped together as Macrolide�Lincosamide�Streptogramin B (MLS) antibiotics (Roberts, 2002). Recently this class of antibiotics was extended due to the development to include synthetic drugs: the ketolides (Zhanel et al., 2002; Ackermann and Rodloff, 2003) and oxazolidinones (Diekema and Jones, 2000), which resulted in the MLSKO family of antibiotics (Roberts, 2008).
    Macrolides, lincosamides, and streptogramins B inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit of bacteria (Weisblum, 1995; Roberts, 2002)�
    Bacterial resistance mechanisms to these antibiotics include rRNA methylases, ABC-F type ribosomal protection proteins, efflux pumps, and drug inactivating enzymes (Roberts et al., 1999; Roberts, 2008). The latter group can be further subdivided in esterases, lyases, phosphorylases, and transferases. The most common mechanism of MLS resistance is due to the presence of rRNA methylases, encoded by the erm genes. These enzymes methylate the adenine residue(s) resulting in MLS resistance. The methylated adenine prevents the binding of the drugs from binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit. 
  This Subsystem encodes only the latter type of resistance. Three additional Subsystems encode other (MLSKO) resistance mechanisms
docs.subsystem_name: Macrolides, lincosamides, streptogramins, ketolides, oxazolidinones (MLSKO) resistance: rRNA methylases
docs.subclass: Resistance to antibiotics and toxic compounds
notes:
References:

van Hoek AH1, Mevius D, Guerra B, Mullany P, Roberts AP, Aarts HJ. 2011.  Acquired antibiotic resistance genes: an overview. Front Microbiol. 2011 Sep 28;2:203. PMID: 22046172

Roberts MC. 2008. Update on macrolide-lincosamide-streptogramin, ketolide, and oxazolidinone resistance genes. FEMS Microbiol Lett. 2008 May;282(2):147-59.  PMID: 18399991

Hydrogenase nickel incorporation protein HypA -- Zn finger protein that inserts nickel into some [NiFe] hydrogenases

Synthesis of the cyanide:

HypE and HypF proteins use cabamoylphosphate to add cyanide to the Fe in the formation of the [NiFe] center.
[Blokesch, M., Paschos, A., Bauer, A., Reissmann, S., Drapal, N., and Bock, A.  2004.  Analysis of the
transcarbamoylation-dehydration reaction catalyzed by the hydrogenase maturation proteins HypF and HypE. 
Eur. J. Biochem. 271: 3428-36].  Note that there are two moles of cyanide per Fe.


  Carbamoylphosphate (= PO4-CONH2)
                |

                |/
                |  ATP
                |/
                |  (autocatalysis by HypF)
                |\
                | Pi + PPi
                |
  HypF-AMP-CONH2
                |
                |  HypE-SH
                |/
                |  (autocatalysis by HypE)
                |\
                |  HypF + AMP
                |
    HypE-S-CONH2
                |
                |  ATP
                |/
                |  (autocatalysis by HypE)
                |\
                |  H2O + ADP + Pi
                |
       HypE-S-CN


Formation of Fe-HypCD complex (HypCD complex does not form without iron):

               |\

Metal insertion into the large subunit apoprotein:

The order appears to be iron then nickel.  HypA is the Ni-binding protein.  HypB is the GTPase.
HypC might remain bound until the nickel is added.

Paralogs of HypA (n.b., HybF ) and HypC (n.b., HybG) can be specific for different hydrogenases.

role_name: Indolepyruvate ferredoxin oxidoreductase, alpha and beta subunits
Indolepyruvate ferredoxin oxidoreductase, alpha and beta subunits like
notes:
This SS was started by W.B. Whitman and will be extended by VeronikaV.

Common in anaerobes, this system interconverts aromatic amino acids (try, tyr, and phe) to the aryl acids (indoleacete, hydroxyphenylacetate, and phenylacetate).  Used biosynthetically in many methanogens and other organisms, involved in amino acid catabolism in Pyrococcus and others.

See for instance:  Porat I, Waters BW, Teng Q, Whitman WB.(2004) Two biosynthetic pathways for aromatic amino acids in the archaeon Methanococcus maripaludis J. Bacteriol. 186:4940-4950.

The entire pathway is:

     aryl acid
         |  + HS-CoA + ATP
         |
     aryl acid-S-CoA
         |  + CO2 + Ferredoxin(red)
         |  IOR
   ketoacid
         |  + glutamate (or some N-donor)
         |
   amino acid

docs.description:
Cysteinyl-tRNA(Cys) is most commonly made by directly charging tRNA(Cys) with Cys. 

Cysteinyl-tRNA(Cys) is made by an indirect pathway in methanogens and some of their relatives.
Unlike Selenocysteine-tRNA(Sec), where the tRNA is charged first with serine, in this case the
tRNA is charged with phosphoserine.  The sulfur is then transfered to the actived hydroxyl group.

docs.description:
From (Osterman A1, Overbeek R. 2003) -
Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is an ultimate precursor in the biosynthesis of the universal and indispensable flavonoid red-ox cofactors: flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD). Biosynthesis of riboflavin in the archaea follows an alternate pathway from that found in bacteria and eukarya (see DIAGRAM under Illustrations Tab above). First, an alternative two-step transformation (via a GTP cyclohydrolase III and formamide hydrolase) occurs instead of the established one-step reaction of GTP-cyclohydrolase II characteristic of bacteria, fungi and plants.  Another remarkable variation is the flipped order of the pyrimidine deaminase and reductase steps in eukaryotes and archaea, compared to the standard bacterial biosynthetic route.  Both, fungi and archaea contain a monofunctional reductase, homologous to a corresponding domain of the bi-functional protein (encoded by ribD gene) characteristic of most bacteria.  A monofunctional and non-orthologous eukaryotic deaminase (Pyr_Da) was identified and characterized, while its archaeal counterpart remains a missing gene.  Analysis of chromosomal gene clustering in archaea reveals a strong candidate gene for this functional role.  Orthologs of this gene (e.g., MJ0699 in M. jannaschii) are both distantly related to guanosine deaminase and largely conserved in archaea.  Initial experiments did not provide verification of the expected enzymatic activity of this and several other candidates [81].  In view of the overwhelming genomic evidence available today, the effort to confirm this conjecture is likely to be continued.  

From (Grochowski et al., 2009) -
Biosynthesis of riboflavin in the archaea follows an alternate pathway from that found in bacteria and eukarya (1). See scheme under Illustrations Tab (within thin green banner above). The proposed archaeal pathway begins with the opening of the imidazole ring of GTP by the action of an archaeal GTP cyclohydrolase III (MJ0145, ArfA). The product of this reaction is 2-amino-5-formylamino-6-ribosylamino-4 (3H)-pyrimidinone 5-monophosphate (FAPy). FAPy is be converted to 2,5-diamino-6-ribosylamino-4(3H)-pyrimidinone 50-phosphate (APy) by formamide hydrolase (MJ0116, ArfB) (4). APy is then reduced to 5-amino-6-ribitylamino- 2,4(1H,3H)-pyrimidinedione phosphate by the MJ0671/ArfC gene product (1). A deamination  followed by dephosphorylation (both steps catalyzed by yet unidentified enzymes) then produce the 5-amino-6-ribitylamino-2,4(1H,3H)-pyrimidinedione (ARP), the precursor of riboflavin (and also of coenzyme F420 in methanogenic Archaea)


REFERENCES:

1. Graupner M, Xu H, White RH: The pyrimidine nucleotide reductase step in riboflavin 
and F(420) biosynthesis in archaea proceeds by the eukaryotic route to riboflavin. 
J Bacteriol 2002, 184:1952-1957. 

2. Fischer M, Romisch W, Schiffmann S, Kelly M, Oschkinat H, Steinbacher S, Huber 
R, Eisenreich W, Richter G, Bacher A: Biosynthesis of riboflavin in archaea studies 
on the mechanism of 3,4-dihydroxy-2-butanone-4-phosphate synthase of Methanococcus 
jannaschii. J Biol Chem 2002, 277:41410-41416.

3. Haase I1, M�rtl S, K�hler P, Bacher A, Fischer M. 2003. Biosynthesis of riboflavin in archaea. 6,7-dimethyl-8-ribityllumazine synthase of Methanococcus jannaschii. Eur J Biochem. 2003 Mar;270(5):1025-32.

4. Grochowski LL1, Xu H, White RH. 2009. An iron(II) dependent formamide hydrolase catalyzes the second step in the archaeal biosynthetic pathway to riboflavin and 7,8-didemethyl-8-hydroxy-5-deazariboflavin. Biochemistry. 2009 May 19;48(19):4181-8. 

5. Mashhadi Z1, Xu H, Grochowski LL, White RH. 2010. Archaeal RibL: a new FAD synthetase that is air sensitive. Biochemistry. 2010 Oct 12;49(40):8748-55. 

6. Osterman A1, Overbeek R. 2003. Missing genes in metabolic pathways: a comparative genomics approach. Curr Opin Chem Biol. 2003 Apr;7(2):238-51.

Elements of the subsystem (details are below):

Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) synthetase (an activity of the non-discriminating Glutamyl-tRNA synthetase) is the first step in the indirect charging of tRNA(Gln).

Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase L-asparaginase subunit (EC 6.3.5.-) and Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase transferase subunit (EC 6.3.5.-) are the two subunits of the archaeal second step of the indirect charging of tRNA(Gln).

Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase subunit A, B and C are the "bacterial" second step of the indirect charging of tRNA(Gln).  In many (or all) cases, the same proteins constitute Aspartyl-tRNA(Asn) amidotransferase, the second step in the indirect charging of tRNA(Asn).

Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase subunit F (EC 6.3.5.7) is a distant homolog of GatC and performs the same role in fungal mitochondria.

Glutaminyl-tRNA synthetase is in the subsystem because it makes the indirect pathway optional.

Glutamyl-tRNA synthetase is in the subsystem because the non-discriminating form of the enzyme is essential to the pathway.

Asparaginyl-tRNA synthetase is in the subsystem because its absence makes the transamidase essential.


Details:

Among Bacteria, the GatCAB heterotrimeric enzyme seems to have both Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase and Aspartyl-tRNA(Asn) amidotransferase activities, even if there is no non-discriminating aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase.  This can be used for amino acid biosynthesis, not just tRNA charging.  (The original paper describing indirect charging in Bacillis subtilis called it a biosynthetic pathway. [Wilcox, M, and Nirenberg, M.  1968.  Transfer RNA as a cofactor coupling amino acid synthesis with that of protein.  Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 61: 229-326; also note Griffiths, E, and Bayley, S. T.  1969.  Properties of transfer ribonucleic acid and aminoacyl transfer ribonucleic acid synthetases from an extremely halophilic bacterium.  Biochemistry 8: 541-551].)

The assignments to eukaryotic Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase subunit C is a guess based on extensive PSI-BLAST searches.


The UniProt roles Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase subunit D (EC 6.3.5.-) and Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase subunit E (EC 6.3.5.-) are misnomers taken from the gene names (gatD and gatE).  These two proteins make a heterodimeric, glutamine-specific amidotransferase.  [Feng, L., Sheppard, K., Tumbula-Hansen, D., and Soll, D.  2004.  Gln-tRNAGln formation from Glu-tRNAGln requires cooperation of an asparaginase and a Glu-tRNAGln kinase.  J. Biol. Chem. Dec 16; [Epub ahead of print] ]

So, the nomenclature used here is:

Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase L-asparaginase subunit (EC 6.3.5.-)
= UniProt Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase subunit D (EC 6.3.5.-)

Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase transferase subunit (EC 6.3.5.-)
= UniProt Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) amidotransferase subunit E (EC 6.3.5.-)


Distinguishing the "discriminating" and "non-discriminating" Glu-tRNA(Glu) and Asp-tRNA(Asp) synthetases is imprecise (to put it mildly).  In principle, having a non-discriminating synthetase, without the amidotransferase is lethal, as it makes "mischarged" tRNA, but does not convert it to the correct amino acid.  Because a non-discriminating synthetase really has two activities, that is how I am annotating them:

   Discriminating Aspartyl-tRNA synthetase = Aspartyl-tRNA synthetase (EC 6.1.1.12)
   Non-discriminating Aspartyl-tRNA synthetase = Aspartyl-tRNA synthetase (EC 6.1.1.12); Aspartyl-tRNA(Asn) synthetase
   Discriminating Glutamyl-tRNA synthetase = Glutamyl-tRNA synthetase (EC 6.1.1.17)
   Non-discriminating Glutamyl-tRNA synthetase = Glutamyl-tRNA synthetase (EC 6.1.1.17); Glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) synthetase

For the time being, assignment to non-discriminating type has been very conservative, in most cases, only when no direct charging enzyme is present, and there is strong evidence for the appropriate amidotransferase.  The problem is that there are a remarkable number of genomes in which there are two Glutamyl-tRNA synthetase genes, at least one of which must be non-discriminating, but there is no obvious criterion for choosing which.

Some light is shed by cases in which the "non-discriminating" enzyme has lost the ability to charge tRNA(Glu):

   Skouloubris S, Ribas de Pouplana L, De Reuse H, Hendrickson TL.  2003.  A noncognate aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase
   that may resolve a missing link in protein evolution.  Proc. Nat.l Acad. Sci. U S A. 100: 11297-302.


Organellar enzymes have not been distinguished.  Mitochondtria and chloroplasts mostly use the indirect charging of tRNA(Gln), and direct charging of tRNA(Asn).

###############################
LITERATURE

docs.description:
0. Antibiotic class: Capreomycin and Viomycin are cyclic peptide antibiotics
1. Organisms antibiotic is used against:  Mycobacteria

2. Mechanism of action: Inhibition of protein synthesis
3. Molecular target: Interface between two ribosome subunits

4. Mechanism of drug resistance: Target modification
5. Required for resistance: Loss or inactivation of 16S/23S rRNA 2'-O-methyltransferase, encoded by tlyA. Loss of these specific rRNA methylations confers resistance to capreomycin and viomycin.

6. Detailed description of resistance mechanism(s):
The tlyA encodes a 2'-O-methyltransferase that modifies nucleotide C1409 in helix 44 of 16S rRNA and nucleotide C1920 in helix 69 of 23S rRNA. Loss of these previously unidentified rRNA methylations confers resistance to capreomycin and viomycin. Many bacterial genera including enterobacteria lack a tlyA gene and the ensuing methylations and are less susceptible than mycobacteria to capreomycin and viomycin. 
    Note, that ribosomes lacking TlyA methylation are capreomycin resistant. This is an unusual mechanism, given that resistance to most drugs that interact with ribosomes has been associated with changes in rRNA sequences, acquisition of methylated bases, alterations in ribosomal proteins, or acquisition of activities that inactivate the drug (PMID:8761724). Although unusual, it is not unprecedented as resistance to kasugamycin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, is due to the loss of a methylase, RsmA (also known as KsgA), which methylates bases 1518 and 1519 of the E. coli ribosomal 16S rRNA (16).
docs.subclass: Resistance to antibiotics and toxic compounds
notes:
7. References:

PMID:16857584
Johansen SK1, Maus CE, Plikaytis BB, Douthwaite S.
Capreomycin binds across the ribosomal subunit interface using tlyA-encoded 2'-O-methylations in 16S and 23S rRNAs. Mol Cell. 2006 Jul 21;23(2):173-82.  

PMID:15673735
Antimicrob Agents Chemother. 2005 Feb;49(2):571-7. 
Mutation of tlyA confers capreomycin resistance in Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
Maus CE1, Plikaytis BB, Shinnick TM.

Johansen SK1, Maus CE, Plikaytis BB, Douthwaite S.
Capreomycin binds across the ribosomal subunit interface using tlyA-encoded 2'-O-methylations in 16S and 23S rRNAs. Mol Cell. 2006 Jul 21;23(2):173-82. PMID:16857584 
Abstact
The cyclic peptide antibiotics capreomycin and viomycin are generally effective against the bacterial pathogen Mycobacterium tuberculosis. However, recent virulent isolates have become resistant by inactivation of their tlyA gene. We show here that tlyA encodes a 2'-O-methyltransferase that modifies nucleotide C1409 in helix 44 of 16S rRNA and nucleotide C1920 in helix 69 of 23S rRNA. Loss of these previously unidentified rRNA methylations confers resistance to capreomycin and viomycin. Many bacterial genera including enterobacteria lack a tlyA gene and the ensuing methylations and are less susceptible than mycobacteria to capreomycin and viomycin. We show that expression of recombinant tlyA in Escherichia coli markedly increases susceptibility to these drugs. When the ribosomal subunits associate during translation, the two tlyA-encoded methylations are brought into close proximity at interbridge B2a. The location of these methylations indicates the binding site and inhibitory mechanism of capreomycin and viomycin at the ribosome subunit interface.
