docs.description:
Cytochromes of the c type bind heme covalently via two thioether bonds to the two cysteines within the sequence motif Cys-Xaa-Xaa-Cys-His located in the periplasmic domain of the cytochrome.  The mechanism of this covalent stereo-specific attachment of heme to the cysteine residues of apocytochrome is the key question of biogenesis of c-type cytochromes.  At least three different pathways of variable complexity have been described so far:

System III of cytochrome c maturation, the simplest kind known, operates in mitochondia (mt) of fungi, vertebrates, invertebrates, and some green algae (i.e., Chlamydomonas reinhardtii).  It has been studied in detail in yeast.  A single enzyme, cytochrome c haem lyase (CCHL) is required for the formation of two thioether bonds.  However, in fungal (and possibly animal) mt two separate CCHLs are used for the two c-type cytochromes c and c1.   CCHL genes are nuclear encoded.

System II is found in Gram-positive bacteria, cyanobacteria and some proteobacteria, and also in plant and algal chloroplasts, and perhaps in archaea.  While the main components of the system II - proteins CcdA and Ccs1 are homologous across different species, protein thiol:disulfide oxidoreductases that are associated with CcdA (ResA in B. subtilis � Erlendsson et al., 2003) can be rather diverse in different organisms.  Based on co-localization of these proteins with CcdA (and Ccs1) they have been included in this SS as possibly involved in cyt c biogenesis (Hyp3, Hyp4).  Generally thiol:disulfide oxidoreductases (i) share an active site with two Cys residues arranged in a motif: C-X-X-C; (ii) despite very low primary sequence similarity often show the same tertiary structure � thioredoxin-like fold.

System I cytochrome c maturation occurs in alpha- and gamma-proteobacteria, Deinococci, and mitochondria of plants and protozoa [1�3,13]. It requires eight or nine specific cytochrome c maturation (ccm) genes often located in a cluster, and three dsb genes (for disulfide bond formation). In addition, genes of the general secretion pathway and of cellular redox control contribute to efficient cytochrome C biogenesis.  System I pathway has a higher affinity for haem than system II for cytochrome c biogenesis due to the presence of ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter that is required for release of the periplasmic haem chaperone CcmE to the last step of cytochrome c assembly (Feissner et al., 2006). This ABC transporter is composed of the ATP-binding subunit CcmA, and two membrane proteins, CcmB and CcmC. In the absence of CcmA or CcmB, holo(haem)CcmE binds to CcmC in a stable dead-end complex, indicating high affinity binding of haem to CcmC (Feissner et al., 2006).
   CcmCDE are involved in heme delivery. CcmC is required for the covalent attachment of heme to the heme chaperone CcmE. CcmF has been proposed to form a bacterial cytochrome c heme lyase complex together with CcmH (and CcmL).  Cysteine thiols of the heme-binding motif of apocytochromes c are oxidized by the periplasmic DsbA. CcmG, a thioredoxin-like protein, and CcmH, a putative thiol-disulfide oxidoreductase, reduce intramolecular disulfide bonds in apocytochromes before heme attachment by transferring electrons from the transmembrane disulfide oxidoreductase DsbD (DipZ)

notes:
A few notable cases:

1.  Systems II and III coexist in a small number of organisms (var.code 4): Bordetella bronchiseptica, B.parapertussis (but NOT in B.pertussis or B.avium); in Burkholderia fungorum and B.xenovorans (but NOT in Burkholderia cepacia, cenocepacia, or pseudomallei); in Ralstonia eutropha (but NOT R.solanacearum).  Recent acquisition of System I by horizontal transfer or its loss ?? 

2. In Xylella fastodiosa (but NOT in other Xylellas) a short form of Cytochrome c heme lyase subunit CcmH is present and co-localized with a protein annotated as �Hypothetical protein associated with short form of CcmH� (Hyp6).

3. In some Clostridia (C.perfringens and C.difficile) a fused protein is present: 
Cytochrome c-type biogenesis protein CcdA (DsbD analog) / Cytochrome c-type biogenesis protein ResA, but their homologs in C.thermocellum and C.tetani are NOT fused.  No cyt c biogenesis-related proteins can be identified in nonpathogenic Clostridium acetobutylicum. 

4. In all Betaproteobacteria (Burkholderia, Neisseria, etc) homologs of CcdA are absent while all other components of System II are present in a nice cluster.  Apparently, DsbD homologs (normally associated with System I) can substitute for CcdA function.  This assumption is based on the clustering of DsbD homologs with System II genes in some of these organisms and on (indirect) experimental data in Pseudomonas (Page et al., 1997) where a CcdA-like protein could substitute for part of the DsbD function.

Note: "Putative arylsulfate sulfotransferase" is included in this SS only due to it's clustering with DsbA-like and DsbB-like proteins.   It is not involved in cyt maturation.

References:

1. Stevens JM, Uchida T, Daltrop O, Ferguson SJ. 2005. Covalent cofactor attachment to proteins: cytochrome c biogenesis. Biochem Soc Trans., 33(Pt 4):792-5. 

2. Thony-Meyer L. 2002.  Cytochrome c maturation : a complex pathway for a simple task ? Biochem. Soc. Trans., 30:633-638

3. Nakamoto S., P. Hamel, S. Merchant.  2000. Assembly of chloroplast cytochromes b and c. Biochimie 82:603−614

4. Meyer EH, Giege P, Gelhaye E, Rayapuram N, Ahuja U, Thony-Meyer L, Grienenberger JM, Bonnard G.  2005  AtCCMH, an essential component of the c-type cytochrome maturation pathway in Arabidopsis mitochondria, interacts with apocytochrome c. PNAS, 102(44):16113-8. 

5. Erlendsson LS, Acheson RM, Hederstedt L, Le Brun NE. 2003. Bacillus subtilis ResA is a thiol-disulfide oxidoreductase involved in cytochrome c synthesis. J Biol Chem. 278(20):17852-8. 

6. Page M.D., Saunders N.F., Ferguson S.J., 1997. Disruption of the Pseudomonas aeruginosa dipZ gene, encoding a putative protein-disulfide reductase, leads to partial pleiotropic deficiency in c-type cytochrome biogenesis, Microbiology 143:3111�3122

docs.description: Disulfide bond formation is critical for the proper folding and functionality of bacterial proteins. It is catalysed by proteins, that introduce disulfide bonds into unfolded polypeptides. Two systems have been described in E. coli, the DsbAB system with broad substrate specificity, where DsbA donates it's redox-active disulfide to the polpypeptide and gets reoxidized by DsbB and the DsbLI system, which catalyses the specific oxidative folding of arylsulfate sulfotransferase (ASST).

notes: Notes copied from Iron_Aquisition:

The methanomicrobiales are able to use methyl groups from a variety of compounds for
methanogenesis.  All of the compound enter the pathway by methyl group transfer to a
corrinoid protein, followed by transfer to coenzyme M.  The resulting methyl-CoM can
be reduced to methane, or oxidized to CO2 (producing 6 electrons that can be used to
reduce 3 other methyl groups.

The initial methyl transfer is catalyzed by a different methyl transferase for each donor,
and is transfered to a specific corrinoid protein.  The subsequent transfer to CoM is by
a less specific set of enzymes.

Methyl donors included:
   methanol
   trimethylamine
   dimethylamine
   monomethylamine
   dimethylsulfide
   methylmercaptopropionate

Known methyl donors not included:
   methanethiol
   tetramethylammonium 

The various methylamine:corrinoid methyltransferases have a pyrolysine amino acid encoded
as a stop codon in the DNA.  Many of the reported proteins are incorrect interupted there.


Methanol to methyl-CoM:

                               CH3OH
                                    |
                                    |  Methanol methyltransferase corrinoid protein
                                    |/
                                    |  Methanol:corrinoid methyltransferase
                                    |\
                                    |  H2O
                                    |
CH3-Methanol methyltransferase corrinoid protein
                                    |
                                    |  coenzyme M
                                    |/
                                    |  Methylcobalamin:coenzyme M methyltransferase, methanol-specific
                                    |\
                                    |  Methanol methyltransferase corrinoid protein
                                    |
                            CH3-S-CoM

       |
       |  Trimethylamine methyltransferase corrinoid protein
       |/
       |  Trimethylamine:corrinoid methyltransferase
       |\
       |  CH3-Trimethylamine methyltransferase corrinoid protein
       |
NH(CH3)2
       |
       |  Dimethylamine methyltransferase corrinoid protein
       |/
       |  Dimethylamine:corrinoid methyltransferase
       |\
       |  CH3-Dimethylamine methyltransferase corrinoid protein
       |
NH2(CH3)
       |
       |  Monomethylamine methyltransferase corrinoid protein
       |/
       |  Monomethylamine:corrinoid methyltransferase
       |\
       |  CH3-Monomethylamine methyltransferase corrinoid protein
       |
    NH3

                                       |/

                                       |\

docs.description:
The products of mixed acid fermentation are succinate, lactate, acetate, ethanol, formate, CO2 and H2 gas.  The route to succinate originates at the level of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP); all other compounds are derived from anaerobic dissimilation of pyruvate.  Product patters vary considerably, even in the same species, depending on a number of environmental factors, including the oxidation state of the carbon substrate, the extracellular oxidoreduction potential, and the pH of the external environment.  For example, the oxidation state dictates the amount of NADH to be recycled and therefore the composition of the excreted fermentation products. The oxidation of glucose (oxidation state 0) into two molecules of pyruvate produces two NADH molecules (4 reducing equivalents). A more reduced sugar alcohol (e.g., sorbitol; oxidation state -1) produces three NADH, while a highly oxidized sugar acid (e.g., glucuronic acid; oxidation state +2) yields no NADH.  Thus, to recycle the larger amount of NADH formed during growth on the more reduced sorbitol, cells must excrete more of the highly reduced ethanol (oxidation state -2). In contrast, cells growing on glucuronic acid are redox balanced and thus do not need to produce ethanol. Instead, they can convert more of their pyruvate to acetate (oxidation state 0). Each of fermentation branches accepts different amounts of reducing equivalents: succinate 4[H], ethanol 4[H], lactate 2[H], acetate 0[H], formate 0[H] (White, 2000). Pathways that utilize 4[H] per PEP/pyruvate molecule are particularly valuable, e.g. succinate branch (it is not encoded in this Subsystem, see SS: �TCA Cycle�).

Similarly, external pH influences the composition of excreted products. Near or above pH 7, the predominant products are acetate, ethanol, and formate, with moderate amounts of succinate. As the pH drops, cells produce lactate and formate (instead of acetate), converting formate to H2 and CO2 (Wolfe, 2005)

Pyruvate formate-lyase (PFL) is the key enzyme for mixed acid fermentation.  However, Pyruvate:ferredoxin oxidoreductase (PFOR) and even Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDH) (normally operational only under respiratory conditions) can be can be used for pyruvate cleavage in fermentation as well.  This was demonstrated, for example, for Leuconostoc mesenteroides and Oenococcus oeni (Wagner et al., 2005) and B. subtilis (Cruz Ramos et al., 2000).  Such cases are not reflected in this SS (impossible to predict from genome sequence alone)
notes:
References

1. White, D. 2000. The Physiology and Biochemistry of Prokaryotes, Second edition ed. Oxford University Press, New York, Oxford.

2. Wagner, N., Q. H. Tran, H. Richter, P. M. Selzer, and G. Unden. 2005. Pyruvate fermentation by Oenococcus oeni and Leuconostoc mesenteroides and role of pyruvate dehydrogenase in anaerobic fermentation. Appl Environ Microbiol 71:4966-71.

3. Alan J. Wolfe.  2005.  The Acetate Switch.  Microbiology And Molecular Biology Reviews, 69(1): 12�50 

4. Cruz Ramos H, Hoffmann T, Marino M, Nedjari H, Presecan-Siedel E, Dreesen O, Glaser P, Jahn D.  2000. Fermentative metabolism of Bacillus subtilis: physiology and regulation of gene expression. J Bacteriol., 182(11):3072-80.
